name: Wathba Hill
desc: Any direction Winds tend to pick up very quickly out here. Flyable wind window is between 18kph to 25kph. Take off is unconventional, lots of glider control and quick responses required in order not to lose any skin....:)

name: Jebel Fayah
desc:
150m-200m MSL. Sanddune in front of Jebel Faya. NW direction (310 degrees). -strong wind condition or sandstorm
-sometimes the wind is from the side. be careful with rotors around the cliff
-the wind can be very strong at higher altitude.

name: Fossil Rock
desc: From the aeolian dune buttressing the mountain

name: Ptukh
desc:
There is a bench about 600 feet above the valley floor offering multiple launch locations. It takes 30 minutes of steep walking out of the village of Ptukh up steep, muddy, moraine until you arrive at this bench. Watch out for sharp rocks, vegetation, and livestock at launch. Conditions are best early to mid-morning. Gets violent mid-day or afternoon in summer.

Flying potential in the Wakhan is limitless. There are Hike-and-Fly opportunities above Sarhad E Broghil as well, and across the valley at Selkemj and Purtwurs. Strong valley breeze most days from mid-day on in spring and summer. I saw numerous dusties late afternoon.

name: Kanine
desc: grassy perfectly inclined take off. enough space for 4 gliders at a time enjoy the flight

name: Eagles-Sky
desc: Shashica, 700m asl

name: Dajti
desc:
The area is small with small rocks and bushes. Impossible to takeoff with no wind.(there are trees at the end of takeoff)

Is possible to fly from 10.30h-16.00h (April-October) and from 11.30-15.00 (November-Mars)
 
This site is not for beginners !!! The place is tricky. Strangers must meet local pilots for advices!!! 

In general the flight is turbulent, so active flying is needed. Some times the thermals are really strong with turbulence. Above 700m and to the landing area the wind comes more from the north, so with a beginner glider is very hard to reach the point. Even at the takeoff, the wind changes from N to NW or W. This is not a good sign.

name: Dhermi
desc: take off a little bit rocky. suitable for pilots after beginner flights.

name: Llogara Antenna
desc: Near antennas on the top of the mountain. take off is highly rocky and moderately steep. not suitable for beginners.

name: korca take off

name: Gjirokastra

name: Gjirokastra

name: Mt. Hadis 300
desc:
TO1: BeginnersÃ¯Â¿Â½ take-off site at 145m from the camp level. The slope is 32%-34% (30Ã¯Â¿Â½-35Ã¯Â¿Â½). The slope is rather rocky with many obsidian rocks. The take-off site is cleaned of rocks.

TO2: Ã¯Â¿Â½300mÃ¯Â¿Â½ take-off site as we call it is 210-235m from the level of the camp site. The take-off area of 80x70m is cleaned of rocks and burrs. 10 pilots can prepare and launch from this site at a time. There is thermo-dynamic activity at about 60m from the slope the width of which is about 350m. If the weather is good cross-country flights are possible. This take-off site is accessibly for 4WD vehicles. The prevailing upper level wind is mostly from the South-East. On the lower levels and close to the ground (surface wind) the air mass circulation is determined by the micro-climate. During the daytime the wind blows on the southern slope and is good for take-offs. The wind is rather gusty 2-4 m/sec, in summer 2-8 m/sec. Sometimes strengthening up to 15 m/sec is possible. Sometimes the weather is calm and the wind direction changes making take-off impossible but this mostly occurs in spring. Overall, the wind direction is mostly stable in this area. Small dust devils sometimes occur and careful attention of the pilots and the flight instructor are needed to avoid the danger. Shifts of the wind can sometimes be observed.

name: Mt. Hadis 500
desc: The third take-off site is located at 1.5km to the West of the camp site at the height of 480m from the camp level (we call it the Ã¯Â¿Â½500mÃ¯Â¿Â½ take-off). More experienced pilots usually take off from here. The site is rather rocky, partly cleaned. The site is accessible for 4WD vehicles.

name: Lernaglukh
desc: The site is on the top of the mountainous range  at the height of ~400m from the flatland. It's clean, grassy and has a plenty of place for simultaneous starts during competitions.

name: Barra do Cuanza
desc: Good, top of the cliff

name: Santiago Centre

name: Deco lado sul da Barra do Kwanza
North Side of Barra do Dande
Santiago Southern Hill
desc: 53m Generally sunny.  Can be blown out in the afternoon.

name: Loma Bola
desc: Nice grassy field with room for quiet a few gliders. There is a bar and toilets. Local pilots pay a annual fee but visiting pilots are not usually charged. This site roughly faces east, however the predominant wind is South. When the South wind gets strong, the area becomes turbulent due to the rotor from the W-E spines going down from the main N-S ridge.

name: El mirador de los condores
desc: 2150 mts

name: Cerro Arco (Mendoza)
desc:
The take off has 270Â°, easiest with easterly winds. Mendoza has a weather condition called Zonda (similar to Foic in the Swiss alps), a turbulent wind system which usually occurs in winter when it's snowing in the andes to the west.

Never fly in these conditions at any time in the day.  As always consult with local pilots before flying.

The following three days after a Zonda are generally excellent, with good themals and southerly winds.

Summer is generally excellent for thermals, with winter being more tranquil.

name: El Bolson
desc:
At the end of the 'Piltriquitron' trail.
Alt. 1180m.

The route up is way up the hill on a long a rough road. Most pilots share taxis up to the car park at 'la plataforma' and the takeoff is 100m to the right of that. There is a clear sign with local instructions. North wind coming suddenly in the valley

name: Merlo
desc: Paved road to 2700ft vertical launch overlooking the resort town of Merlo  4 options for takeoff wind must be westerly and can change mid-flight which means XC but no more launching

name: Concepcion

name: Playa Larga
desc: Walk 100m back along the road and turn right up a wide track, crossing a small fence. Follow the ridge line up to an obvious take off place with a streamer from the local club. Wind is very changable. Seek local advise (it is the Southern most city in the world!)

name: Cerro de la cruz

Medium Level: south wind
Not Possible: west, northwest Dont Fly with pressure under 922 Hp.
Dont Fly  with strong south wind.
Never Fly with zonda wind.

This site roughly faces east, however the predominant wind is South. When the South wind gets strong, the area becomes turbulent due to the rotor from the W-E spines going down from the main N-S ridge.

name: Hohe Wand East
desc:
There are two takeoffs: the most common one is the 'Oststartplatz' (east-TO) which is about 15 minutes walk from the 'Postl' car park. It is used for NE-SE winds, a clearing in the woods, so it may be turbulent if the wind comes over the trees (danger here!).
The other takeoff is the 'Suedstart' used for SE-S winds, a cliff launch just a few 100 m south of the Postl-Restaurant. You should know what you are doing if you launch there. SW-N may be flyable but very sporty if you like lee side thermaling. It is very common that the thermals overlay a wrong wind direction and turn it flyable. 
Stronger westerly or northerly winds (> 10km) are really dangerous here! You will end up in nasty turbulence.

name: Speiereck
desc:
There are 3 different Take offs at Speiereck:
The one at 2000m is mainly used in summer. To get there, you have to contact the guys from DFC Lungau (www.dfc-lungau.com) On weekend they meet at 10:00 at the landing place and go up by car.

In winter time you can go up by cablecar, then it is possible to start at the normal starting place (you have to walk half an hour to reach it) or go down to the second cablecar to go up to the summit and start from there. with North-winds go to 'Aineck'!

name: Rottenstein
desc:
There are 2 take off areas. A big one and a small one. It depends on the farmer wich one to take. The big one is also suitable for hanggliders, the small one is not.

Ask the farmer wich one to take. If he is nowhere to be found, go to the small one, because normally you will have to start from there.

The small starting area can be found by walking up the dirt road. After 4 minutes, you can see a bench to your right, there is the starting area.

desc:
04.01.2018 Edited by Soaringclub Präbichl Member:
!!! NO TAKEOFF WHEN COWS ARE IN THE AREA !!!
We will lose the permission for takeoff, please check www.soaringclub.net , if flying is permitted.
---
After a 1h hike you reach the takeoff area. Its pretty easy to takeoff there, cause there's a lot of space.
the only thing to mention is, that there are some cows how may disturb you.

For taking off you need Wind from South.

about 500m straigt ahead of the takeoff is an area with great thermals. Even in snow-less winters there are some upwinds.

The south takeoff is steep and not for beginners, when it is windy, but you can walk down to the lower south takeoff, which is easy for takeoff. The west, north-west and north takeoff are also suitable for beginners. --- Be aware of the wind funnel at the mountain pass (landing-area)

Takeoff is close to the mountain station of Lazid Mountain (where ever you want). Wind sock is available on one of the poles of the cable car - but not to be seen from some takeoffs. All takeoff directions are easy.
When flying without thermal, check that you have at least 300m above the middle Station - if not, do not try to fly to Serfaus but land upon the meadows of the middle station. There is enough space to land. Check cables... Föhn!!

name: Feuerkogel
desc:
For Hangglider: 5min path towards Hüttendorf (ramp toward North).
 
START DIRECTIONS:

-NORD- Walkway about 10 minutes. behind the hut village towards the north!

-OST - Sidewalk about 10 minutes. the old chairlift terminus.

                  You start right next to the chairlift terminus East.

                  Or - Walkway to Alpenvereinshutte ca 13.min (It starts 200 meters above East..

Or - The most secure version, but about 500 m height loss and ca 17 min. Walking time:

Buchegger curve - One follows the downhill run into the valley. Before coming to the entry point of the chair lift is a longer slope. From there you can easily start East. CAUTION:
If the prevailing wind is West, then Feuerkogel should be avoided as flight mountain!

name: Manilla, Mt Borah (NSW)
desc:
Mt Borah has 4 large launches,all covered in astro turf (N,S,E,W : 340 - 440m AGL) and has a 2WD (with good ground clearance) access road to the launches and landing areas. Avoid flying in a northerly, as it generates rotor along the ridge.
It is a private site, however once you have become a member of the flying association, you  can freely fly (and VERY far)
Because of the world championships held there recently, 200km in each direction people are aware of the sport and usually a lift back to the farm is quickly obtained. However have an ample supply of water with you.

name: Stanwell Park
desc: Sea breeze may get too strong. For PG: Observe the white wash of the waves, when they appear,  plan your landing soon. See what the local pilots are doing.

name: Corryong, Mt Elliot
desc: Westerly launch is a prepared earth ramp suitable for 1 PG/HG at a time.

name: Cottesloe, Perth
desc:
Advanced PG site due to proximity to people/roads/poerlines and street lights.
TO is grassed area in Vlamingh Parklands. Open the wire concertina launch gate. Inflate on the grass in 9-11knot WSW winds and walk forward to launch. Launch towards the north and when you have sufficient airspeed and lift you can then track north and south of takeoff. Bomb out is straight down to the beach but be aware of plenty of dog walkers who do worry about our flying tents scaring their loved ones. Be polite if approached by anyone. WSW -WNW 9-11 knots

name: Greenhills - Penny's Tow Paddock, near York
Mt Trio, Stirling Range
desc: Is a 45 to 60min step hike on a good track the SW and SE side has a good sized clearing on a large rock pad. The north sides are a no go as the bush is thick and deep.

name: Mystic (Bright)
desc: The Mystic take-off is a professionally laid tennis court material (plastic grass) five gliders wide facing due North into the prevailing valley breeze and sun conditions. It is flyable most days. North winds can reinforce the northerly valley breeze and get quite strong. The nth end of the landing paddocks are in the lee of trees and should be avoided in strong conditions. The bowl in front of launch can be turbulent in westerlies.

name: Flowerdale (3 Sisters)
desc: Launch is either side of the middle knoll. The northerly launch is completely open and the slightly rounded knoll allows a straight launch with slight amounts of NE to NW winds. The south launch with the close proximity of trees can be difficult due to the turbulence generated and is thus less forgiving. Access to the top of the hill is STRICTLY 4WD ONLY, you must park 2WD cars near the bottom sign. Please keep the number of vehicles on the property to a minimum and strictly stick to tracks to avoid cutting up paddocks. Erosion , dust and other visible impact from too many vehicles running up and down the hill is much greater than the impact of flying overhead. In summer, drive very slowly along the dusty track from the highway to the LZ, because in a N wind, the dust blows onto the two or three houses along the way. There is a power line directly below the northern launch at the foot of the hill. There are also power lines in alternative landing paddocks on the south side. This site can become very turbulent in NE or NW winds, be extremely careful when low either side of knolls.

name: Mt Bakewell
desc:
Takeoff: perfect spring day, main ridge
There are 3 takeoffs on top, -see Launch Options above.  On the ESE launch it is usually easier to inflate a paraglider as far back from the edge as possible, the airflow near the edge causes the glider to overshoot and requires a sharp run toward the edge before the glider is flying properly. As with any inland site this hill can feature strong lift, strong sink and turbulence.

Beware of powerlines and aerials, with attendant guy wires near the top launch. In addition to the obvious powerlines on the spur to the right of the east-southeast launch there is another running up the gully to the left of launch, this powerlines has very few poles and is very difficult to spot.

There is a strip of paddock in front of launch west of the powerline and east of the gravel pit access.  This is not a permitted landing area, as the constriction of powerlines and trees on three sides and a significant slope mean it is easy to get into trouble if your approach is not perfect.

The gravel pit landing is very small and has numerous large painful obstacles it should only be used by intermediate pilots. All pilots should inspect the gravel pit on the ground before flying Bakewell for the first time.

There is a large commercial skydiving operation behind the hill. Watch out for the plane and don't fly over the airfield, which is also the drop zone.  It's a good idea to check in at the skydivers before flying to let them know you are in the area.

name: Mt Tamborine - Brisbane
desc:
Launch: Sealed road to the site along Main Western Rd Mt. Tamborine (Refidex 
Gold Coast Map 23, L4). 


Rating: Paragliding - Intermediate; Restricted only if under 
supervision of Instructor or Club Safety Officer 
Hang Gliding - Restricted 
Wind Direction: NW-SW 
Height: 1916ft/584m ASL 
CTA: 7500ft 
Facilities: A Weather Talker can be accessed on UHF Channel 25, Tone Squelch 97.4 
(6 clicks) or via phone on 0408 744 791. 
Wind Talker partially funded by the Gambling Community Benefit Fund 
Toilets at launch site. Shops within 5mins drive north. 
Waypoints: 
Launch: 56J 0517723, 6908105 
Old Training Hill (NO LANDING!): 56 J 0513330, 6906409 
Wonglepong Paddock: 56 J 0515524, 6905690 
Model Air Field: 56 J 0511686, 6905937 
Long Road Paddock: 56 J 0518725, 6909225 
New No-Landing Area (waypoint XANGRY): 1200m around 56 J 508938, 6906688 A Weather Talker can be accessed on UHF Channel 25, Tone Squelch 97.4 
(6 clicks) or via phone on 0408 744 791

Spring and Summer see strong thermals with the possibility of major sink cycles 
A common situation is a westerly wind in the morning and a SE or NE sea 
breeze reaching Tamborine launch in the early afternoon. Once you are about to 
launch a Hang glider it is hard to see the wind streamers behind you and it is 
worthwhile to be assisted by a sensible person who can watch behind you for the 
onset of tailwind. 
Be aware of the wind strength and the distance to the bombout areas. 
Beware the level and degree of the sink cycles. 
Launch slope is shallower than ideal and is troubled by turbulence from the shelf 
in front of the launch and from the trees on the sides of the launch. 
Face landing for Advanced pilots only when there are no public or Hangliders on 
launch. 
Refrain from setting up landing approach low over houses near main bombout. 
The trees on the north side cause turbulence and wind shadow in a northerly 
wind. 
Beware of 7500ft height limit. See airspace map.

name: Beechmont
desc:
530M altitude facing Easterly. The launch can get strong thermic gusts. Pilots must contact the Canungra Hang Gliding Club before flying. The well maintained launch is on private property beside a road and easy to access. Watch for other gliders face landing prior to take off. The site is flyable most afternoons during summer.
Power lines go from the left (North) of the launch down to the valley. They are clearly visible on one of the pictures of the launch.
A windsock is available at launch. There are no bins so please take your rubbish with you.. A cafe has been built across the road from launch and a web cam has been installed (http://www.chgc.asn.au/Webcam).There is no water available at the bombout so make sure you pack enough before you go for the walk back up the hill. Look for yourself but listen to the local pilots!!!!

name: Killarney - Queensland
desc:
There are 3 launches on top of the hill facing South-East, South and West.
The altitude of the launch is 1023 m.
A windsock is available. Pilots are allowed to camp at the launch.

name: Peeralilla Hill
desc: Small rounded bare hill to take off from. Once launched, fly to the west, if you have reached the rounded point, and no lift present, start heading for landing across road.

name: Winton
desc:
Grassy south facing ridge that collects the afternoon seabreeze. Can give good thermic flying (leading to XC) at times.

NB: This site is only open October thru April. Contact the THPA (see below) for detailed info. Watch for a sudden increase in strength of the seabreeze.

name: Breeza
desc:
This is a private property, you must contact the owner, who will also do the towing ( he has his own tow setup).
Air space 5km behind the take off at the Hills to the north

name: Crackneck Lookout
desc: 100m ASL

name: Adelaide River
desc: Rocky hill facing SE near some radio towers. Not very high altitude ~95mAGL.  With the prevailing SE wind during the dry, the face has the potential to be soarable. Dry season flying only.

name: Crommarty Hill, Forresters Beach
desc: 120m ASL

name: Moonies
desc: 50m ASL

name: Catherine Hill Bay
desc: 50m ASL

name: North Brother
desc:
495 meters above sea level 450 agl. This site takes Nor-Noreast winds around to east- Nor east.

Private and club site must be a member, distance record 130 kilometers Many pilots have eaten trees here , not undertsanding that sometimes the wind up the face can be rotor from the Nor- west. Landing field can be dangerous due to venturi draw across the lake. You must take real care if wind is from east as you may not make the landing field

name: Canberra, Lanyon
desc:
Nice clear top of the hill.  Need keys as there is locked gates to be able to drive up, but free to walk up. Warning, if the wind is north the take off can get some nasty rotor...

Only take off if the wind is coming straight up the face.

name: Shelley Beach
desc:
One of the best known coastal sites in WA, a large coastal site suitable for beginners with fantastic scenery, good access and a developed take off area with wooden hang glider ramps. 
 
Getting There:laning on the beach (photo Georgina Bass)
Turn Left off Lower Denmark Road at the signposted turn off to Cosy Corner. Turn Right up hill after the Torbay Hotel, then left onto a good gravel road at the top of the hill. Follow this to the end where it splits right to the lookout/takeoff and left down to the bottom landing, beach and camping ground.
Flying:
Be aware of other pilots attempting to top land when setting up. Rotor behind take off and at often at SW end of main ridge. There is a steep valley between the take off hill and the main ridge. In more Southerly winds the main ridge may be unflyable due to Rotor, but the take off hill OK. In a more Easterly wind the take off hill will generate very little lift and it may be necessary to glide straight across to the main ridge. This can make top landing impossiblke if the wind is light as the valley cannot be crossed back with sufficient hieght. There is a substantial wind gradient at take off so the wind may be stronger than it feels on the ramp.

No commercial activities including teaching and tandems are permitted in the National Park without the relevant Dept of CALM permit.  Flying from Shelleys is an approved activity in the National Park Management Plan. http://www.naturebase.net/national_parks/management/index.html#management_plans

name: Point Cartwright 'Carties'
desc: Closed

name: 80 Meter Dunes
desc:
Fantastic Freestyle and dune flying, fantastic low level freestyle.

Launch on top of the main front Dune. Works in ESE, SE  Winds, If the wind gets strong the launch from the lower bowl on the beach. NE, NNE, N, NNW, NW, WNW, W, WSW, SSW, S is NOT flyable.

Only ESE, SE, SSE is flyable. Go to Orservation-High ridge (light wind) and Salmon beach-Low ridge (Strong Wind) is the wind is S, SSW, SW.

Helfire Bay (Low Ridge) in the Nature 47 km east of esperance reserve is also flyable in E, ESE, SSE.

name: Tunkalilla Beach
desc: Smooth Grassy Hill Venturi to the left of launch, especially in SW. Power lines low down to the right of launch. Rotor if you go behind back fence in launch paddock in PG

name: Long Reef NE
desc: A grassy area near the crown of the headland that is approximately level. There is space for a couple of gliders. This launch gets quite a lot of compression in stronger conditions. Strong compression at times, getting blown over the back would not be good for your health.

name: Cooks Terrace
desc:
When launching, do not step on the low wooden fence and un-load your canopy right on the edge. When conditions are light and North of East, in order to stay up, pilots adopt a pattern whereby the upwind leg of a 'circuit' is flown close to the ridge and the downwind pass is executed out to sea. Be aware of this possibility and don't force your right of way. There are often many many spectators. There is rotor behind the bush on top of the cliff near the northern end, best to stay out of the hatched section on the site map. When conditions are crowded and there are hangliders in the mix, things can be very 'busy'.

Keep an eye on the wind direction. When the wind is to the South don't fly the North East facing part of the ridge. However it is possible to fly into the bowl behind Warriewood beach, (though best not to go into the lee of Warriewood headland). If the wind moves more to the North the reverse becomes true.

Radio Control aircraft often operate on the northern end of the ridge.

There are power lines running from the toilet block on Warriewood beach.

It's an unleashed dog park.

name: Gundowring (SavHill) NW
desc:
SW, W, NW
4WD access only Weather station link
http://freeflightwx.com/gundowring/

name: Forbes airfield
desc: At the northeast end of the airfield. Aerotowing of hang gliders only. Cu-nimbs

name: Tunbridge Tiers
desc: A wide clearing in the trees on the steep face of Tunbridge Tier. Thermic from 11:00am on a good day, but watch out for turbulence from cross winds, or lee conditions.

name: Cape Jervis
desc: Take off from in front of carpark on a small cliff (40m) Caution - the valleys along the cliffs here are prone to catabatic winds which can cause nasty rotor.  Most likely in late afternoon or with prevailing Easterlies (even if locally it is a Westerly)

name: S.E Middle Brother
desc:
SE take off near communication towers on top of hill.

Altitude 465m asl.

Private and club site must be a member.

name: S.W Middle Brother
desc: 449mtr asl

name: Blackheath
desc: A small astro-turfed launch to the west and an even smaller ramp to the north

name: Strzelecki
desc: SE 6-8 Knots

name: Newcastle Beach
desc: North side of picnic table.  Watch rotor and fence.

name: Bombala St
desc: Very small take of short walk down trail

name: Indian Head
desc: SSE to ESE 8- 15 knots

name: don heads
desc:
Coastal site no trees and all grassy slopes towards bass straight,flyable between nnw to nne on private property there are no weather hazards 

you dont have to que to launch,its suits 3 maybe 4 gliders at the same level,you get the hill all on your own sometimes,very freindly place to fly so drop in for the view or a yak..:)

name: Seaford
desc: Launch from the top of a small section of W-SW facing cliff.  Need to clear a waist high fence on your takeoff run.

name: Jeff Hoffman's
desc: Paramotor launch

name: Argalong
desc: Permission from land owner to fly

name: Sand Patch
desc:
Launch . Made ground directly in front of 
3rd Wind Turbine from south. Clear for one PG or one HG at time. Rigging area for several. Gated access via Wind Turbine trac (contact locals for info on key access). Otherwise park at Wind Turbine centre and walk 10-15 mins along bordwalk and tracks to 3rd Turbine. T/O
Takes SSE to SE be wary of down-wind speeds/  lift band. Serious cliff lines to 300m along ridge. Long sections of cliff with no bottom landing. Beware of rapidly changing weather. Storms approach from all windward directions. !!. has 8 km ridge to Soth to Sharp Point and 7km ridge to North to Mutton Bird ave heights 150-300m... 30 km round trip !!> Cliff Site. Soaring. Weather can be quickly changable. Rain bands and gust fronts can develop quickly in Spring/ Autumn. Pure ridge line on spine back so less likely to maintain seabreaze effect. Has some potential for XC from  Mutton Bird (Nth) end of ridge however this will be limited by Albany Airspace.
Superb high cliff flying in region.

name: Mt Stringybark
desc: Located on private property. Access has only been granted through negotiation with landowner. Please be considerate and contact a Wicked Wings member before flying.

name: Mt Storey
desc: Located in a private residential area. Please be considerate of the neighbours and contact a Wicked Wings member before flying.

name: Fitzy's Launch
desc: Paramotor launch, Permission Needed To Fly From Here up to 18kph winds

name: Khatabundah
desc:
S.E Launch - First flat area (next to the fence) you come to as you drive up the 4wd access track.    .
E Launch - About 200mtr above S.E launch. Small flat parking area where the hill flattens a bit and faces East.
N.E Launch - Continue up hill from East launch to trig point at top of mountain. (** 4wd access only as the hill is VERY steep **)

name: Crookes Airstrip
desc: Paramotor Launch. Permission Needed To Fly This Site, Suitable for towing

name: Tri Reserve
desc: Paramotor Launch

name: Honeysuckle
desc: Intermeadiate rating launch Good to 20kmph wind

name: Coolawang
desc: This Launch is only accessible through private Property, and  the owner  has since  declined access.  This site is now CLOSED.

name: Bells Beach
desc: Winkipop(E-SE) 30m / 100ft asl. Rated Advanced, HG only - the local foreshore committee does not permit PGs to take off or land on Winkipop launch. The vegetation here is sensitive to trampling. Hang gliders must set up on the west side of the road then carry across. Do not set up on launch as this will jeopardise the site! It is your responsibility to ensure the gate is closed after you. Please ask spectators to keep out of the fenced off area. It is not advisable to takeoff at Winkipop in a light wind. There is no beach ... ever! There are minimal landing areas available along the entire coast run, and even less at high tide, so treat this run with extreme caution. Be aware that these popular beaches will always have people on them regardless of the weather conditions. It is recommended that all pilots fly with instruments and UHF radio on channel 16. Be warned, highly experienced inland XC pilots have come to grief on this run.

name: Sunnyside
desc: Takeoff is a small grassy clearing on the ridge.

name: Spion Kop / Fairhaven
desc: The site permit allows set up only within the marked areas.

name: Oil Refinery Cliffs (Hallett Cove)
desc: Large paddock on top of cliff from which to launch from. Small fence to launch over, but you should be airborne before the fence.

name: Warriewood
desc:
A small grassy park on the western section of the cliff. After launching you should always turn left towards the beach, as it is only just possible to make the glide if the lift is too light to stay up.

Gain height on the lower slope and once level with the sandstone lookout, cross onto the main face. When conditions are good, pilots often cross from here to Cooks Terrace. It's a long way to the beach if the wind is light. Don't cross onto the main face until your body is level with the sandstone lookout. Lower down on the face there is a often a dead zone and you may find you are not climbing, it's truly a long way back to the beach from this situation.
If the wind moves to the north, the landing on Warriewood beach becomes affected by rotor from the Cooks Terrace headland. 

Pilots making the return run from Cooks Terrace will come around the Northern end of the ridge quite low and cannot be seen from the take off.

name: Portsea
desc:
The site is within the Mornington Peninsula National Park so pilots should respect and enjoy the environment. Most importantly that means take-off cleanly from the ramp, land on the beach and return via the main access track. NO scrambling up and down the cliffs or dunes!

The path to the launch from the carpark leads to a glider set-up area, out of the wind on the right, and the synthetic turf take-off ramp to the left (see photo). Pilots should set up with the aim to being airborne about 1m before the edge of the ramp. For paragliders that means standing about 3m back from the edge before inflating the glider and being sure to keep quickly pulling the canopy up until its flying above your head - if you don't you'll get dragged back into the scrub!

The total flyable distance is 8km. When flying below the point to the left of takeoff, be wary of the slight rotor which has claimed many kites.

Flying to the Rip should only be attempted when the wind is off to the right (south) at takeoff. The dangers to watch out for are:

    * The rotor behind London Bridge (more than one glider has crashed behind the Bridge).
    * At high tide there is no landing area on the beach at some sections.
    * The points in between the bays can be hazardous, and even more dangerous if the run is attempted with a wind which is not off to the right at takeoff. If at any stage of the run you should land, a long hard walk is in front of you, and if you are injured, help may be some time in getting to you.

Spectators crowding around the takeoff and landing area, small or nil landing area at high tide, and power lines near the life saving club.

name: Flinders
desc: Ground ramp.

name: Cairns Bay
desc: Park in the small parking area off the road and walk down the track to the coast. When you reach the gully at the bottom cross over to the left hand side and make you way to the left hand side cliff top. Take off is just to the right of the bowl on the cliff top, all of the cliff top is a good grassy area. Avoid Beach landings, as the beach is very small or non existent. Beware when flying around cliff corner on left hand side of Launch that you have enough height to get around - a number of pilots have been hurt in emergency landings due to insufficient height to capture lift band. Beware rotor/turbulence that can occur on point to left hand side of launch if wind is too cross.

name: Kilcunda
desc:
Kilcunda

The Graveyard site consists of dunes on the stretch of coast between the town of Kilcunda and Cape Patterson, and is suitable for STUDENT rated pilots upwards. It may be soared, and offers a glide for learners when the tide is out.

In June 2009, Launching from the disused railway embankment within the coastal reserve close to town has been temporarily prohibited for use by Parks Victoria and VHPA.

Flight

In lighter winds, the dune takeoff at the Graveyard (on west side of the path in to the beach) is preferred for hang gliders, as the embankment take off further West around the rocky point is quite low and is suitable only for stronger winds.

The dune face is broken and uneven further to the East, but there's a good high soarable dune face about 400m long at the Graveyard takeoff. In a good wind (15kts), it is eminently soarable, but beware - this site has claimed a life in light winds when scratching the low dunes The takeoff at the Graveyard is directly above a popular surf fishing spot, so beware of people and fishing equipment on the beach when landing.

The Graveyard launch does have a limited takeoff run. It has become very overgrown, so watch out for undergrowth snagging the hang glider control bar on the takeoff run. Paraglider, student and novice pilots should consider walking along the beach to the East about 150m and launching from some less overgrown although lower dunes.

There is very little beach at low tide.

Be careful not to catch a wingtip in the face of the dunes when scratching if the wind is light.

name: Middletons
desc:
Located on private property and requires a 4WD to reach. Please be considerate of the neighbours and contact a Wicked Wings member before flying.
Cleared takeoff on top of ridge. Best direction is SSE.

name: Ma Ma
desc:
Located on private property. Access has only been granted through negotiation with landowner. Please be considerate and contact a Wicked Wings member before flying.
Launch is a grass clearing on top of the range within the large the bowl.

name: Teewah Launch
desc:
A casual walk from the bottom on the dunes up wooden stairs, along a 200m path to the launch ramp. CAUTION.
This is an advanced launch. DO NOT attempt to launch on the ramp! launch from up the path and once your wing is established walk your wing down on to the ramp and take off. The air flowing through the launch ramp will throw even the best ground handlers wing in to the pandanus tree next to the deck. Sea squalls and gusts.

name: Shoreham
desc:
Walk around the cliff point on the right hand side of the beach. Launch is around the point and up on the more clear part of the cliff top. It is important to get the canopy up cleanly as launch is covered in small bushes etc that is easy to get your lines snagged in.

There is a beat of up to 1km. An easy 100' to 150' above Launch and up to 500' above Launch achievable. This site can be only usually flown with a good ESE wind as takeoff is quite low and the cliff is not that steep. However once up and flying it can be quite good. For paragliders this site has a very limited range of flyable conditions. If it is windy enough to get up from the low takeoff there is a danger of being blown back once higher.

name: Flinders Monument
desc:
Grassy cliff edge.
Flight-

From the Monument the trip up to Shoreham is exciting. Generally flown in October/November when there is lots of easterlies, this site has a difficult cliff takeoff and often major tubulence low on the cliffs.

It can be very difficult to get up in light conditions. in fact, in very light conditions it can seem soarable, but there appears to be some form of thermal block which destroys lift below cliff level. In good conditions, however, excellent height can be achieved, and you can fly all the way down to Shoreham, though it is very difficult to get all the way back. (You need a touch of North in the wind for this).

The boats anchored by the pier in front of the site offer a good indicator of wind direction. There is an excellent, and usually wide beach available to the right for landings, and plenty of lawn beside the car park there to pack up on. Watch out for wind lines & white caps approaching, get out of the air if they appear to move in.

name: Lady Bay
desc:
Cliff launch, with surprisingly strong lift in light winds. Launch close to edge.

Soaring is very easy in light winds, and in right conditions, you will also get thermic lift off rocks on cliff. Easy to gain good height and do coast run to the SW.

name: The Bluff
desc:
Takeoff either to the left of the top carpark, as close to the cliff edge as possible. Beware that this is a venturi area though, so windspeed can only be judged by walking to the bottom of the cliff or along the track to the top of the bluff.

If too strong to launch here, walk to both of cliff, and launch there. Wind is weaker. Venturi bowl on takeoff. Rotor behind rocks at very left of soarable ridge.

Wind has been known to switch direction 180 degrees at random times. Keep a close eye on weather.

name: Tappanapa
desc: Air often turbulent for first 50â€™ or so after take off. Rotor and heavy sink behind road on top.

name: Blowhole Beach
desc: Good rounded takeoff

name: Sellicks Cliffs
desc: Cliff style launch, be aware in strong winds or cross winds. Beware if blown back, will end up in houses, power line and a tree. Powerline behind launch.

name: Snapper Rocks
desc:
Cliff Launch Conditions   degrade if wind  goes NNE
 In summer,  conditions  will  vary as  sea breeze kicks in.

name: Fryer St
desc: Takeoff from small park, surrounded by power lines and houses on three sides. Park has one large tree in it, and waist high fence to clear before cliff launch. Don't want to by flying when whitecaps hit

name: Mount Terrible
desc:
Rounded grassy takeoff. Rounded inland ridge with series of spurs and gullies. 
Deep valley behind take off; often rough air with punchy thermals.

name: Boomer beach
desc: Take off on beach, with out trespassing or damaging the fenced off sand dune area. Needs a strong southerly wind to be soarable. Powerlines and houses behind ridge.

name: Middleton Beach
desc: Low sand dunes, requires strong wind

name: S.E Bonny Hills
desc: South-East 8-15 knots

name: N.E Bonny Hills
desc:
North East to East

8- 15 knots

name: Point Pass
desc:
Easterly facing Site on Private Property.  Contact S.A. pilots for details.
Easterly facing escarpment approx 300ft AGL.
Escarpment is approx 7km long and runs N/S Potential for Rough thermals in summer.

name: Cape Liptrap
desc:
A beautiful coastal soaring site consisting of five large bowls and approximately 11km of low sand dunes. The five bowls cover a distance of about 3km. Launch is ideal for paragliding and adequate for hang gliders although not really steep enough. In a firm wind, launch is no problem.

Takeoff-
Rounded ground ramp cliff top. Hazards/Comments-

Do not fly at Cape Liptrap alone. The site is relatively remote and has few visitors. There is little or no mobile phone reception. Only fly this site in winds strong enough to stay up due to the lack of bottom landings.
If the wind shifts to the west or south the points create turbulence. The bowl adjacent to the lighthouse faces SSW, the remainder of the coast faces SW. 
It is a long walk out if you bomb out on the beaches to the north.

name: Landscape
desc: A west and North facing ground earth ramp.

name: Mt Dandenong
desc: Takeoff is a steep metal ramp (just above ground level) through a slot in the trees. There is limited clearance directly in front of the ramp. The width of the slot is not excessive and tall trees are predominant on both the Southern & Northern sides of the slot. Care must be taken in choosing the appropriate launch time & technique, so sufficient flying speed is available to clear the treed slot. Due to this sites closeness to Melbourne's main airport it is critical for pilots NOT to infringe on controlled airspace. Controlled airspace is at C LL 4500 over launch (only approx. 2000' above takeoff) and drops to C LL 3500 in the suburbs out in front of launch. Pilots must carry altimeters and strictly observe these restrictions.

name: Donna Buang
desc: Drop gear off at the cleared setup area above the road and then park cars clear of the ramp being aware of parking restriction signs. Beware of traffic when carrying gliders across the road from the setup area and make sure not to block traffic. It is essential to begin launch at the apex of the ramp at the base bar chocks. Launching further back along the lesser incline is a practice which is absolutely unnecessary and only invites a nose high launch. Valley wind can be very different to that on Launch

name: Hallett Cove Lawns
desc:
Shallow grassy lawns Hazards:

Park is public and shared with families/children. Beward of crowds, and buildings/play equipment.

Nothing behind launch apart from houses and suburbia...no XC

name: Eaglehawk Neck
desc: Eaglehawk Neck - Lower Launch

name: Boree Creek
desc: Farm Paddock Used for Paramotoring

name: Leeton Gliding Club
desc: Leeton Aero Club

name: Minnie Waters (Nth Beach)
desc:
Sand blow about half way along the beach.
T.O from beach also possible (kite wing up slope a little and launch) Coffs Harbour Weather report is best to use for forecasts and updates for this site.

name: Minnie Waters (South)
desc:
S.E Facing small ridge.
About 12mtrs ASL.
Take off into small bowl.
Be careful of Spur to the right as it can cause rotor into the bowl.
After the spur there is 2-3kms of SE facing ridge to fly along (up to 25mtr ASL) Coffs Harbour weather report is best to use for forecasts and updates at this site.

name: Ocean Grove
desc:
Coastal sand dunes from Collendina to Point Lonsdale. Height of dunes: 15 metres max. At some gaps, the front dune height drops to 2 metres.
Takeoff
Access to takeoff is along the old road below the lookout. Assistance on launch is recommended and a positive takeoff is required. The site looks small, but provided you stay within the lift band it is possible to get high over the lookout. Paragliders may choose to take off on a shelf below the path if the wind is on the strong side. People on beach, especially near beach access. Narrow beach (or none) when the tide is in. Turbulence when the wind is off, especially if the wind is around 20 knots.

name: Broome Cable Beach
desc: On the Cable beach grass area on in the dunes on the left of the pub. none

name: Rabbit Hill
desc: Yallingup - North of top carpark, walk past the lookout to a small open area where you can lay out your wing 10-14 Knots westerly breezes only.

name: Quinns
desc:
Beach takeoff for ridge soaring.
Park in the Ocean Drive and Camira Way car park.
Walk north onto the beach and launch off the sand dune ridge.
Do not walk on or damage vegetation on the dunes.

There is also a new top Launch and Landing pad just south of the Jindalee Beachshack cafe up on the ridge. Fly in Westerly 9-15 Knots to get sufficient lift on the dunes.
Proximity to roads and power lines.
Severe rotor to the East of the ridge line

name: Contos
desc: Limestone ledge off the main access road Westerly but not above 8kts

name: Long Reef SE
desc:
A grassy area part way along the walking track on the southern face. The grassed area is at best
level and at worst slopes backwards away from the ridge. In order to launch you will need to be a
few steps down the steep 'goat track' that goes directly over the edge. There is space for only
one pilot at a time. If other pilots are present, they can hold your leading edge up which will 
simplify things, although experienced pilots regularly launch here un-aided.
Because the hill rises towards the east, pilots flying eastwards tend to be lower and 'hug' the cliff
those flying west are usually higher and often pass out to sea. This is opposite to the normal right
of way rules but the pattern helps everyone to stay up. The two main hazards with this site are the launch and the small areas to land below the launch 
at high tide. If you choose to scratch here in light conditions at high tide, you will probably get 
your gear wet.
On launching, the steep slope means that your wing will quickly overshoot attempting to fly 
parallel with the apparent wind coming up the face. You need to be prepared to check it early. 
The normal approach is to just kite the wing and walk backwards up the slope a few steps back 
onto the level ground before turning and taking off. However should you fail to control the 
overshoot be prepared to become airborne facing backwards. In light to moderate conditions 
launching is relatively easy, however good ground handling skills are required in strong 
conditions.
Novices are encouraged to get some help with their first few launches from this site. By having
another pilot hold the leading edge of the wing up, the need to be standing down the slope is 
reduced and thus the chances of the wing over shooting is negated.
When the wind is from the west of south conditions become more gusty and the lift becomes 
uneven. It is strongly recommended that Novices do not fly this site in these conditions.

name: Mona Vale
desc:
Use the lower grassed area just above the vertical cliff. The grass near the top of the
headland isn't really steep enough and suffers badly from compression. Southerly winds tend
to be 'gusty' and there can be rotor from Warriewood h eadland. Check the ocean for signs of
what's going on. The steep cliff lower down on this site creates a wind gradient that can mask the true wind
strength. After taking off pilots find themselves climbing into the stronger wind and struggling
to push forward. Over the back on this site is a sheer cliffwith serious rotor. Don't get blown
over the back! If you do the onlygood news is that you'll be over water, everything else is
bad. There is also sometimes severe compression out on the point.
Don't fly this site when the wind is from the West of South as the landing on the beach is in
the lee of the pine trees.
A single strand power line runs out to the pool.

name: Newport
desc:
here are two launches 15m apart, use the one most appropriate for the wind direction.
Because of the height of the hill behind, the launch can be in a bit of wind shadow. If there
are white caps inside of Newport reef it's too strong for Paragliders. When the breeze is too
far to the south for safe soaring, 'darkies' appear on the water behind Bungan Headland.
Don't cross over the road until you have 100' above it. Keep in mind that the only safe
landing option is the beach. Paragliders don't go into the southern bowl as the ridge is not
that steep and it can be very difficult to penetrate out. The launch is very small with trees close by, you need to begood at ground handling to fly
this site. There is a sewer vent pipe below launch. There are power lines on the side of
Barrenjoey road.

name: rex lookout
desc: Flights to Port Douglas and Mossman are relatively easy, but you must be aware of the specific pitfalls if flying north.

name: Nambucca Heads
desc:
Coastal headland, Caution: clearing amongst bush land  - tight narrow launch.
Wind direction 60degree from North.
Lat.     -30 38 08.2026
Long. 153 00 50.0574 Northeasterly winds can quickly increase in wind speed !

name: Long Reef Northfacing
desc:
North wind needed , take off in leeward side on small sport , need to jump
Over a fence

Help for launching the paraglider since u need to start in Lee side of start point and get the wind into the airflow of the breeze
When wind is on lower end max 1 paraglider so u have the chance to really squeeze out all gusts to stay up

name: North Head
desc: T/O into E- Wind. Strong wind recommended since no landing except when soaring all around the cliff site ( severeal km to manly beach ) or be able to top-land ! U dont want to go into the water, high waves and rocks !

name: Burns Beach
desc: This site takes a SW  to a W (certain sections can been flown in a SSW e.g the dunes to the far north, but not worth the effort). Go there if the bom is registering 10-17 kts at the Ocean Reef weather station and at least 9 kts at Hillarys, over 17 kts you need a mini wing or you risk being blown back. You don't want to be blown back as there are heaps of snakes, rocks and fences there. To launch - go down to the beach, ground handle your wind up, then walk up the dune into the lift zone and push off (don't go too far up the dune or you will been dragged back over the dune).  Stay in front of the dunes to be safe.

name: Mutton Bird Beach
desc: From the dunes unless Easterly when you can take-off from below lookout rotunda. fly from 8kts SW to SE.

name: Lights Beach
desc: Follow paved track around 200m from carpark until you get to saddle between 2 hillocks leave path and go to front of hill. From 8kts SSW to SSE

name: Bunbury Back Beach
desc: Take-off, light winds, from grassed area adjacent to carpark but for stronger winds use the beach. Road behind is quite busy ! Westerlies !

name: Warnbro Beach
desc:
Access the beach from the Hilda Road or Michael Road carparks. Inflate on the beach (wind may appear light) and then crab up next to the dune. Move sideways and up building momentum, launch pointing the wing at approx 45 degrees to the dune. You should quickly get airborne and then try stay infront of the dune top as there are houses, powerlines, light poles you can easily get blown back into in anything above 11 knots.
Dunes are 4-16m high and you can get a great run on a decent 9-11knot WSW. SW to W above 9-10kts.  Works best on WSW.

name: Wamby Dunes
desc:
SSE is best direction. 13-16 knots.
Careful not to be blown back.
Start on beach and kite backwards up dune until takeoff is possible.

name: Gerrards Lookout
desc: Site takes NE to E/SE wind but is best at E/NE above 18kph. ...

name: Red Bluff
desc: null

name: Gundowring (Savhill) W
desc: null

name: Gordon
desc: null

name: Ben More
desc: null

name: Black Hills 1
desc:
Best to approach from the East side of the twin shaped ridge. A walk to the top is required. Small, sharp rocks and scrubs make launching a challenge.

Ridge peaks at around 380m AMSL.

name: Black Hills 2
desc: A walk to the top is required. Small, sharp rocks and scrubs make launching a challenge.

name: Lokbatan Views
desc:
Small, sharp rocks and scrubs make launching a challenge.

Access from a unpaved road the begins at the rear of the Lokbatan cemetery. See breeze is usually between 10:00 - 14:00

name: Beshbarmag
desc: A range of take offs available. Best to dive around on top of the hill until a nice one is found.

name: South face
desc: Approximately 1850m at it highest point, the long ridge extend east-west and gets higher down the valley. Rought track that is accessible by 4WD. Otherwise, horse or 3hr + hike from villages below.

name: NNE face
desc: huge open and nice

name: Masally Views
desc:
Quite a nice grassy take off area on top of the hill that the road leads all of the way up to.

An alternative take off is a little lower down the face of the mountains, this one is quite easy to see from the road on approach.

name: Kyiryizdakhna Gates
desc:
There is a few different options here. 

1) There is a short 200 - 300 meter walk from the highest point accessible by car. From this point turn left. Walking towards the spur high point (in the direction back down the valley,.. ESE)

2) Otherwise, turn right and walk up as high as you want to launch from, depending on wind direction. It looks (have not down it) possible to drive up quite a bit of the high section here,.. possible to the very top. This would then enable launches in many directions, Hangies as well! Will update soon once I investigate further! hmmm, the narrow gorge (appear like large gates) would act like a pretty mean venturi at time I imagine,... Not sure. 

Please mind the fog or low clouds

name: Radar
desc: one quite nice ENE facing launch (70o), just walk past the strange radar building at the top of the hill /end of the well maintained track. I have been told it is for phone relay,.. but it does not fit the typical shape. As standard if you run into army guys try argue a bit, if they have some serious secrets there you will have to leave.

name: Siezan Slinger
desc: Lots of options, however best at the northern end of the ridge as this is higher and has little no no trees

name: bombakimmi
desc: a little rough, but covered in grass. A little steep, but OK for reverse launch. Getting to take off required a 10 min fight though scrub from the road that passes nearby.

name: Gicki mountains
desc: Grassy with a wide rage of locations possible. Just arrive and pick based on wind and your wishes. the valley behind can funnel the last ESE wind. Look out for venturi points if completing a small XC and looking to land in the valley near the HWY.

name: Prish hill
desc:
A number of options. The hill is steep and pointy and thus limits potential for extended soaring flights. But plenty of take off options to suit all wind directions. Choose the best spot and go for it.

A track suitabel for 4WD and maybe 2WD in the dry leads to the very top.

name: Northern dream (Pirikishgul)
desc: 2 step take offs. small ridge and higher top. Accesable by cars Wind electric generator at far East (you can see them on the way to) and fog from Sumgait factories on the far North are very good marks for global meteo identification. Also help to notify wind changes well in advance

name: South Point
desc: Just walk up to the top of hill and you can do groundhandling or soar. Easy place for beginners.

name: Prickles Hill 1
desc:
A number of options. The hill with a lot of prickles, be careful when you doing groundhandling or want to take off. Plenty of take off options to suit most wind directions. Choose the best spot and go for it. 
there is cleaned zone on the top

name: Prickles Hill 2
desc: Just arrive and pick based on wind and your wishes.

name: Paragon
desc:
Anywhere on the ridge
Best place for soaring near the hill. cars can be stacked if heavy rain. please leave the side if you feel to be rainy

name: Goyler
desc:
Choose South-West facing hill next to the road.
Starting is on grassy are, no rocks or sharp objects. A bit bushy in places

name: Shusha
desc: Very good start point from various sightseeing plateaus

name: CanFly Lokbatan
desc:
Small, sharp rocks and scrubs make launching a challenge. 

Beware of power lines behind.

name: Safronova
desc: almoust any place on the ridge S, SE, SW

name: Spirit
desc: plenty of starting places from the hill facing North / North-East

name: Ferz
desc: Good for Thermic flights. XC

name: Bajenov Team Qabala Spot
desc:
Upper start at hinge zone on start is small with steep slops on both sides. Be aware of possible rotor very close to start position
Preferable start some feet's below from skiing start plate (as spotted location) Rains are often at the place. Winter time is covered by snow.

name: Xanyalaq Dağı (MARXAL-SHEKI)
desc: The road to the top goes from Marxal Resort. You can pay for transport from resort parking to the top (20AZN per person) bumpy often

name: CavFa (Hungu) Laza Gabala
desc:
Easy take off site. 
See the photo for the launch steep. It is cloudy and rains often at the place. Winter time is covered by snow.

name: Mostar - Planinica
desc:
Two take off places.

1.
 facing SW it's 790m ASL. It's a rocky place with a little grass. 3 gliders can start at the same time. Flying time afternoon ridge and thermals soaring.

2. facing E Take off time from 11:00 to 13:00 during first morning thermals Avoid flying N NE strong winds called BURA

name: Biljaca
desc: Facing S SW, 1300m ASL. wide open but little difficult to take off.

name: Kocerin
desc: Short tight and steep take off

name: Mostarsko blato
desc: Winch towing - Big field 12 km from Mostar, there is a road in all directions

name: Gljiva
desc: At the very top of the Gljiva hill, above Trebinje city.

name: Kupres - Stozer
desc: easy

name: Pyramid
desc: west, easy

desc: easy

name: Sinjakovo
desc: Wide takeoff for south and north wind directions.

name: Zenica
desc: E/NE

desc: NE/E/SE/S/SW

name: Gostilj
desc: NW,N, NE

name: Ruj
desc: SE S SW W NW N NE

name: Ljubuski
desc: Smooth and easy. Just

name: Bjelasnica
desc:
North start, mountain peak. GPS: N 43Â°42.240, E 18Â°15.420, Altitude: 2068m/6784ft 

Start for takeoff is on NE side, providing takeoff ability from NNW winds to pure east winds. Takeoff is possible from stone plateau, couple of grass covered flat fields, or from steep grass slope. These are not high demanding starts so less experienced pilots can find their place for takeoff and enjoyment. 
In south wind directions  experienced pilots can start just below Observatory on south side, while those less experienced can go about 200m ESE and find grass fields to spread wings 

They are lots of other starts on Bjelasnica on lower altitude, oriented for all wind directions. Some of them, in winter time, are posible to reac with cable car.

name: Igman
desc:
Rough, and not suitable for totally beginner, especially when is calm air. We are working for many years on this takeoff but every year there is some new things to do, new trees growing..
Site is suitable for East and North - East wind direction. Site is fabulous, you can feel really strong and wide thermals when working so you can go around during the long ridge and you can reach easily to Bjelasnica.
In front of takeoff approximately 4km located is Sarajevo Airport, so we have agreement to contact control dispatcher on number +38733779166, just to inform them about paragliding activity on site. There is asphalt road parallel between flying site and airport so you need to watch to be on this side of the road near takeoff, that's deal with them. But, you have beautiful hill behind and you don't need to think about walleye where is airport :)

name: Mrkovici
desc:
Pretty nice gras field, oriented to South - West.
Best period for flying on this place is early spring. Altitude difference between takeoff and main landing area is not so big, approximately 400m but is far enough to reach easy when is calm air with every type of glider. If you have nice weather, you can reach a high altitude like 4.000m or more.

Please contact local club for more info about this place and other places around.

name: Bihać zavalje
desc:
Do samog starta mozete doci kolima sa asvaltiranim putem ,samo zadnjih 200 metara je makadam .Moze auto a mozete i prohodati
Start je trava  gdje se mozete zaletjeti 30 metara ,savjetuje se let uz povoljan odgovarajuci ceoni vjetar.
(You can get to the start by car with an asphalt road, only the last 200 meters is a gravel road. You can drive a car and you can walkStart is a grass where you can run easy 30 meters, it is advisable to fly with a favorable appropriate headwind.) zima i proljece omogucavaju vise sansi za padinsko jedrenje zbog jacih vjetrova.Ljeti je vrijeme stabilnije sto znaci i slabiji  vjetar. udaljenost od centra grada 8 minuta autom
(winter and spring give more chances for downhill sailing due to stronger winds. In summer, the weather is more stable, which means a weaker wind. distance from downtown 8 minutes by car)

name: College Savannah
desc: take off on top

name: Coo
desc:
Probably the bigest take-off place you can find in Belgium.
Two take-offs one W one S :
- West side No major obstacles exept a series of trees 20 m below. 

- South side No major obstacles exept a series of trees 20 m below. Should not be attempted with the tiniest tendency to East wind, it becomes very very turbulent and nasty. - West Beware of the venturi on your right

- South Beware of east wind on the south take off, it becomes turbulent and you can make some tree landings.

name: Les 7 Meuses
desc: Small take-off place requiring a good handling of the wing.

name: Rochefort - Rond du Roi
desc: The short cliff take-off is quite technical and touchy under light wind condition and turbulent under strong or west wind condition.  The place is small and can be used by only one wing.  The area has to be particularly respected because of its location in the National Park 'de la Lesse et Lome'. Always turbulent with NE wind or strong wind conditions (>20km/h)

name: Olne
desc: Very narrow, very steep takeoff. There is only place for one person to takeoff. There is no place to run. And barbelwire on the upperside of the takeoff. Should absolutely not be attempted by a beginner paraglider. Never takeoff without the thermal breese or without wind. You'll eventually end up in the trees in front. Before taking off put your canopy above your head and only if you feel it's carrying your weight you can takeoff (jump). very turbulent with wind over 20 km/h.

name: Winterslag
desc: the site now has signs saying no entry and private property. I think we can consider it to be closed.

name: Terril du Roton (Farciennes)
desc:
Pas de problÃ¨me pour dÃ©coller et la pose au sommet est possible.

Ã‡a reste quand mÃªme technique car les arbres sont proches

name: Avister
desc:
240m above sea
The takeoff is a steepy strip in a forest.
Very dangerous take off if the wind is not straight. Don't take off with nil wind you'll end up in the trees.

XC is only possible east and north-eastward due to Liège TMA High current cables behind the takeof
turbulent with N-W wind

name: Bredene
desc: From the dunes.

name: Beauvechain
desc: Only winching.

name: Oostduinkerke
desc: From the dune.

name: Hamoir - Hai des Laies
desc:
* Only one glider can take-off at a time.
* Pay attention to the trees near take-off.

!!!!  There is no take off anymore, plant regrows ... Impossible to fly !!!! (August 2015) * This site can be quite turbulent and dangerous when flying it on a non-supported orientation.
* Do not take off if there is a north-component in the wind.

name: Knokke - Het Zoute
desc: Somewhere on the small dune.

name: Waremme
desc: Only winching!

name: Maillen
desc: EBML, ultralight airfield, towing operations for hang gliding Turbulent in N wind conditions.

name: Sopot
desc:
lots of take off points, all kinds of levels, large, small, tight, open, steep, shallow, something to suit everyone.

main take off is at the top of the lift, other sites hike or drive.

name: Koniavo
desc: Very big, suitable for S and SW winds. There are stones on the take off, careful with the lines. Take off at 1470m ASL. Eventually flyable in any winds, in thermal summer days if the main wind is weak. Turbulence in strong side winds.

name: Shumen
desc:
Shumen: N, NE, E, ESE, SSE, S All
http://shumen-xc.org/meteo-new/data/view/360

name: Topola
desc:
Topola
ASL: 160 m
Direction: 180 degree
breeze or S wind

name: Partizani
desc: Partizani

name: Biberna/Kableshkovo
desc: Actually all upper part of the slope is naked, so you can choose yourself where to launch. This flying site is not suitable for strong winds. In summer, the sea breeze blows ordinary from 3PM to 8PM.

name: Topolitsa South
desc: The takeoff is large and clean, perfect for beginners. If the wind at the South takeoff is from west direction, be careful, it  might be turbulent!

name: Веренишко Бърдо
desc:
Препоръчително е за по-лесно излитане вятърът да бъде 2-3 m/s!
За по-малко от 2 m/s се изискава много тичане за да се излети!

name: Kopitoto
desc:
Very, very dangerous!

Very short and ends up with an almost vertical drop of about 8 meters with sharp rocks and trees below. Very narrow - just about one wing span, almost vertical drops from both sides with trees below. Not enough place to make several steps when rising the wing, if necessary to move sideways.

Any failed attempt to take off will almost certainly end up in the trees or over the rocks.

name: Bej bunar
desc: Big, grassy takeoff, clear from rocks. In S,SW winds good for ridge soaring!

name: Sea Garden
desc: The takeoff is located in the central part of the Sea Garden park, between 'Casino' and 'Summer theatre' In summer, the sea breeze blows ordinary from 3PM to 8PM.

name: galata
desc:
Meteo station
http://nikisurfsport.com/weather/station/

name: Tash Tepe
desc: The start is at 1920m above sea level

name: Yastrebetc
desc: Direction NNE-N-NW. 300 m below the upper lift station, walk to walk the runway for about 30 minutes. The place is enough to stretch a dozen wings simultaneously. Very good able to fly even in a major wind from the south the most common race of nort.I only in good condition.

name: Rouen
desc:
Big takeoff covered with grass and rocks!

High voltage electric lines passing the area, eazy to pass over or land before them in case of altitude lost!

name: Cherni vrah
desc: Takeoff covered with grass and some bushess

name: Rido
desc: Big and clean takeoff covered with grass.

name: Gledkata
desc:
Clean takeoff covered with grass.
Suitable for  beginer and training flying.

name: Karierata
desc: Small, covered with grass. One glideder at time can takeoff. Mostly for training fying

name: Krusta
desc: Small takeoff, one glider at time!

name: LB22 - Stanke Dimitrov
desc: Airfield 3 km long run

name: Mosthanets
desc: Clean takeoff covered with grass. Suitable for 2-3 gliders at time. Mostly for training and beginer flyung. Saorable with winds more then 4 mps.

name: Stefanovo
desc: Big, clean grassy takeoff

name: Robovitsa
desc: Wide grass take off with good inclination.

name: Дъбова глава

name: Chernomorec

E,SE

easy

name: Govedarnika
desc: It's a forest clearing suitable for take off of one glider at time! Flyable only in weak winds les then 4m/s. Danger from rotors in strong wind conditions!

name: Paniciste - Bekyara
desc: Small ski run Avoid winds stronger then 5/ms with more then 30 degree deviation from main wind direction.

name: Medovo
desc: The takeoff is steep and offers place for 2 gliders only. It is not recomended for beginners.

name: Klisura
desc: Clean takeoff covered with grass, there are some small rocks. Saorable with winds about 4 meters/second.

name: Brejani
desc: The take off is next to the electricity wires. If the wind is strong from the west, then it could be possible that you are blown back to the electricity wires.

name: Ploski
desc: Grep fields

name: Topolitsa East
desc: The East takeoff is steep and clean. There are actually no landing places below this takeoff, so if the lift is weak right after launching, it is better to turn right to be close to the landing below the South takeoff.

name: Rebarska Mogila
desc: On ridge northwest of antenna

name: Rutovu
desc:
Very big takeoff with grass suitable for many wings. It's possible to soaring and to catch some nice thermals

VIDEO : https://vimeo.com/78469133 Usually the wind is coming from east. Sometimes it can be strong, or like evrywhere else in burundi, the weather can change quickly.

name: Mutumba
desc:
It's possible to takeoff in diferents places on the top of the mountain.
video : https://vimeo.com/80343384 Look the clouds and the lake...

name: Kabezi
desc:
Takeoff in the middle of rocks on the top of a quarry. Need at least wind of 20 km/h to soar the small ridge. For good pilots only... Usually the wind is south. It's better with south-west or west wind.
Wind could increase quickly. Look the water of the lake to see if it's getting stronger...

name: Rutovu - Ouest
desc:
It's really big with no trees and you can take off every where, fly soaring, play, do nice touch and go,...
Be carefull with the rocks! Usually the wind is coming from east and is better to go to fly in Rutovu just behind the Nile Pyramid. But if the wind is west, it's a good alternative to fly soaring at 15 minutes from Rutovu.

name: Banga
desc:
Small take-off on the  top of the hill. You need some wind to take-off ant take imediately some altitude because there is a High Voltage line just in front!
Its' possible to fly soaring there...
FOR EXPERTS PILOTS ONLY!!!

name: Kabezi 2
desc: There is different places where it's possible to takeoff. They are all small and technical!

name: Huayllani
desc: Located at 3300 masl as part of Tunari mountain range, acces is by stone paved road (really good) until the exact take off (around 25 minutes from the landing zone by car, almost reaching a small village called Sapanani. Just fly in the mornings, wind gets crazy (and tail wind) after 2:00 pm (aproximately), be carefull in August and first weeks of september since wind gets crazy earliear, around 11-12 am

name: Copacabana
desc: Ceroka hill, 4,150 meters height. Be careful, considering the strong wind in August and September.

name: Tiquipaya
desc: Despegue descampado, el transporte llega hasta el despegue, 40 min de subida el clima es ideal en la zona, entre 20 a 28 grados normalmente casi todo el año

name: Yanari
desc: Ample grassy slope with room for 6 to 8 gliders. It's not clean grass as it has got some rocks, but it's fine.

name: Cap5
desc: Take off at 3222 m and 800 m above the landing with orientation E, NE. the flight is very thermal with little wind, it is possible to fly all day

name: Vinto
desc: El despegue esta a 30 metros del camino, buena pendiente  para la carrera , el despegue es sin obstaculos, viento de frente o un poco cruzado por las mañanas, a veces pasado las 12 el viento se vuelve de cola, desnivel respecto al aterrizaje de 1005 metros aproximado El clima en la zona es buenisimo en general, templado por las mañanas, y un poco de frio en el despegue por la altura pero solo por la mañana, pasado las 10 am ya es un clima templado y agradable que se mantiene durante el dia

name: Colomi
desc: Despegue alto,viento enfrentado buena brisa por la mañana hasta las 10 a 11, pasado esta hora el viento en despegue es fuerte y la condiciones turbulentas en vuelo El clima en la zona es muy frio  por la noche y  de 10° a 27° en el dia, normalmente templado agradable.

name: Municipio Oruro
desc: despegue un poco complicado hay piedras y  es pequeño

name: Governador Valadares - Pico do Ibituruna
desc: Nice ample grassy slopes facing both north and south.

name: Andradas - Pico do Gaviao
desc:
10 different concrete and natural ramps for take-offs on a huge well-cared ï¬eld, allowing for simultaneous take-offs. Wide and strong thermals make the flght non-advisable for rookies at noon time.

Meteo: http://www.picodogaviao.esp.br/meteo/

name: Jaragua
desc:
Alti: 1013 m
Good, 3 to 4 paragliders at once. Turbulence around the take-off when the wind is coming from the right (east wind). With such wind it is better not to turn right inmediately after launching, but rather fly straight away from the ridge or left.

name: Ipora
desc:
alti: 850 m
Grass ramps, the smallest of which allows three simultaneous take-offs.

name: Quixada - Morro do Urucum

One wooden ramp for hang-gliders and natural dirt ramp for paragliders. Wind can be (too) strong on TO from September to January.
'Paulo' (TO-director) will 'find' a window for a safe launch...

name: Morro do Diabo (Sao Vendelino)

Landing on top is easy and safe. Great view of the valley below. In case of west winds, there is an small take off site a few steps away.

desc:
2 large, well maintained TO's: grassy slopes; also a HG ramp on each TO; about 150m apart.
main TO's: SE facing/ SW facing http://agvl.esp.br/index.php/meteorologia/

name: Baixo Guandu - Monjolo (ES)
desc:
Take off: 200m wide for multiple take offs.
Recently the ramp by way of the local club has undergone several improvements, such as bathrooms, shade, web-cam, new lawn, ramp extension.
Most importantly the location offers great year-round flight possibilities. In a northerly wind, the left side of the bowl, looking north from the take-off, can get very turbulent. Avoid flying low directly over the spine-backed ridge, as this can be both strong and rough.

name: Pirapora Bom Jesus   Capuava Hill
desc:
Grass covered in the the top of the mountain for all directions, you can Takeoff from NE, S, SW.
NOTICE: Do not takeoff with N wind, great turbulence and risk.
Always get informations with local pilots. they are fridly and will instruct the foring pilots where to to get the best moutain conditions. Always talk to experience pilots in area, this region has strong shifting winds conditions and turbulence.
Avoid take off in N winds.

name: Serra grande - BA
desc:
-14Â° 28' 29.27', -39Â° 1' 49.02' or 
-14.474798, -39.030283
Elevation 80m + / -

The map on googlemaps (not satelital) shows the takeoff as 'on the sea' however if you find the coordinates in the satelital view you'll find the right place for takeoff and landing. Otherwise look at http://here.com Just look at the sea and follow the clouds...and keep attention on the wind direction and power.

name: Morro da Santa
desc: Very wide and grassed. The start is on a little slope, you shoud make an energic take off. The mountain has low altitute, so go directly to a thermal. The flight is thermal based, take a look on the clouds and try to ride them. There's just a little lift. If you catch the thermal you can travel to the mountain range.

name: Ilha Grande Rampa Mauricio Klabin
desc: Risky for inexperienced pilots, most are made â€‹â€‹in the thermals, with a chance to enter descendente. The biggest problem is the southwest wind that comes with many many forces in the village and the pilot can be taken to the sea should also watch for the eastern gusts that can be strong too.

Timbé do Sul
desc: Very wide, up to 10 simultaneous take off. There some rocks on the way but still easy for a begginer take off. You will maximize your take off chance by looking the wind forecast 15 km upside the hill, if the wind still in tha same direction of the border, you will be able to take off. After that, take a look if the cloud altitude and if its above 1400m.

Large setup and TO area, perfectly prepared. Excellent infrastructure: toilets, restaurant. It's even possible to rent tents and sleep there. Normally (too) strong winds in the morning. 
Generally ok after 1200. Later in the afternoon watch out for the approaching sea breeze, which can be (too) strong again!

desc: Very easy to notice the launch site from the city. The take-off is short and very risky. As there is no space for corrections, the place is not suitable for beginners. It offers an splendid view of the valley and it is located just a few kilometers from the highest point of the state.

name: Bom Retiro (SC), Costao do Frade
desc: The take-off is 10km far from the city and is very easy and calm, suitable for all kinds of pilots, including beginners. It offers a great view of the adjacent lands and it is located just a few kilometers from the highest point of the state.

name: Bom Retiro (SC), Morro Do Claudio 2
desc: The take-off is 3km far from the city and is very easy and calm, suitable for all kinds of pilots, including beginners. It offers a great view of the adjacent lands and it is located between two beautifull valleys just a few kilometers from the highest point of the state.

name: Bom Retiro (SC), Morro Do Opa
desc: The take-off is 3km far from the city and is very easy and calm, specially suitable for beginners. Advanced pilots will not have much fun here. It offers a great view of the adjacent lands.

desc: The takeoff is wide and is about 520 m above sea level. Four paragliders fit into the ramp at one time. The location is not yet suitable for hang gliders

name: Rampa do Pombal
desc: Not easy.

name: Paramotor-PR
desc: Área gramada com 200m X 60m

name: Conquista D'Oeste
desc:
Rampa Paraíso
Quadrante: SW, W, NW, N
ELEVAÇÃO: 640 m

name: Morro da Lagoa (MDL)
desc: Big and easy SSW, S, SSE

name: Farol de Santa Marta
desc: The mountain is almost all grassed, this means you can take off from anywhere. A perfect wagga place. Cause theres have low elevation, we fly with strong winds and sometimes, because of that, we chose to take off below.

name: Divinéia
desc: Wide, good for beginners.

name: Winch Take Off - Dia de Voo Parapente
desc: Large beach, easy take off. If you want to do any course like SIV or Acro, call us on @diadevoo. We should care about the tide and wind directions.

name: Três Cachoeiras
desc: Grassed, easy take off.

name: Santinho - S SE
desc:
A rampa baixa é boa para parapente, mas existe uma outra rampa mais alta, do lado da “santinha sem cabeça”, boa para asa delta.

Decolar de asa delta na rampa de parapente é possível, porém arriscado, pode dar prego. Deve fazer primeiro um bordo pra direita e rezar pra ganhar. Caso contrário, direto pra areia.

name: Rampa do Bode
desc: Quite small, one at once. Trees on the both sides.

name: Rampa do Moisés
desc: NE, N, NW grassy ramp with simultaneous takeoff for 2 paragliders. null

name: Caramandu
desc: Large ramp for take-off of 5 paragliders simultaneously. NE, N NW.

name: Cachoeira do Bom Jesus - W NW
desc: Fica na pista de motocross. Rampa ainda é precária, precisa mais limpeza. Quadrante W. WNW - WSW

name: Lagoa da Conceição - HG
desc:
Rampa de concreto em más condições, porém funcionando.
Acesso com 4x4.

name: Rampa da Fazenda Dona Mariana
desc: Easy. Takeoff for 4 paragliders simultaneosly. N-NW

desc:
