desc: Usually with strong wind

name: Rampa do Cleiton - Rio Bananal
desc: Take-off with high level of difficulty, because of the wall perpendicular to the ground 400 meters. Takeoff of Many paraglider at a time. Land takeoff covered by grass.Decolagem com ni­vel alto de dificuldade, devido ao grande paredÃ£o perpendicular ao solo de 400 metros. Decolagem de vários parapentes por vez. Terreno da decolagem coberta por grama ou tapete.

name: Lago Kite Surf - Asas do Vale
Lago Kite Surf 2 - Asas do Vale
Santa Maria - PNMM Fêmea
desc: Wide natural takeoff location, to the southwest. The flight in this place is recommended after the cold fronts, after the rains, as soon as the weather is good.

name: Pico do Pontão
desc: null

name: Faxinal - Cerro Comprido / São Pio S
desc: The takeoff location is a natural grass ramp. The ramp is a little tight due to a fence. No observations on the weather. In summer, tropical storms are common, with cumulunimbus (CB) formations.

name: Rampa da Ruvina (AVOARC)
desc: NW

name: Uibaí
desc: fácil semi árido

name: Patrocínio Christ Paragliding Ramp
desc: Grassy take off on the left, outside of the Christ statue area. Good flying all year round.

name: Coromandel Cruzeiro Paragliding Ramp
desc: Grassy large take off near the Cruzeiro Cross and Paranaiba River.

name: Patos de Minas Paragliding Hill E/NE/SE 50m
desc: Small hill and take off, but amazing flying conditions.

name: Praia de Palmas
desc: Small grassy takeoff, suitable for one paraglider and a couple more setting up Site is flyable with E, NE winds all year round. This is a soaring site

name: Falésias de Marataízes
desc: null

name: Morro da Concha
desc: Permite decolagens de S, SE, N, NE. Para o voo de nordeste evitar rajadas acima de 30km/h e direção menor que 55º. null

name: Rampa da Serra da Ventania-Miracema-RJ
desc: ...Decolagem para os seguintes quadrantes: SE, S, SW, W e NW. Fácil decolagem com amplo espaço gramado. null

name: Krutaja Hara (Anoshki)
desc: 'Krutaja Hara' hill near Anoshki village provides takeoff in West North-West direction.

name: Varonickae Balota (Viezhy)
desc: Only towed takeoff is possible here

name: Zaozerje
desc: Takeoff in South, South-West direction

name: Tenas Hill
desc:
Old fire lookout at top of hill. Great scenery, ferocious bugs. Flying Season: Assign value 0,1,2,3 0r 4 (highest)
Spring 3 Summer 4 Fall 2 Winter 0

name: Pemberton
desc:
Elevation: 2500ASL, SW, suits HG & PG, room to set up many HG's.

Head east out of Pemberton take the road which heads north just after crossing the bridge over the Lillooet River on the road to D'Arcy. Turn left (west) at the power lines. There is a dirt road that will take you to the takeoff. Stay on the road. Do not be tempted to turn right. You will need 4X4 vehicle if you do not want to trash your nice car.

name: Mt 7 - Golden
desc: Main Launch is the lookout directly SE of Golden and is a combination of ramp and slope launches. Be sure to check the forecast. Nearby fronts and thunderstorms may send 'gust fronts'. Do not fly close nor downwind of peaks.

name: Woodside
desc: Launch is a groomed gradually steeper slope facing WSW at 2250' (680 m) ASL. Set up area for 10+ gliders. Large parking area. Clean takeoff. Wire men required in strong thermal conditions. In poor conditions there is a good HG ramp lower down the slope. Leave for the LZ when no more than 50' below the old lower launch. Use small field ( http://www.canadarasp.com/windgrams/?region=0&location=0&plotType=0

name: Grouse
desc:
Grouse Mtn. ski area. From Highway #1, travel north along Capilano Road/Nancy Greene Way to the end and then take the Gondola to the top.

4000' (1200 m) ASL SSW facing launch with excellent groomed slope on ski hill. Moderately sized set-up area on rocky and bushy ski slope. Get a good clean run as sink could be present just in front of launch. Grouse is a very restricted site. Grouse Mtn. is privately owned, next to one of the main water reservoirs for the city, and the landing field is a sports-field in an upscale area of greater Vancouver. Because of these circumstances, in order to fly Grouse, you first have to get onto the guest pilot list. To be accepted as a guest, you have to have an intermediate or advanced rating, liability insurance, a reserve, and you have to be a responsible pilot (You will be asked for a contact person who can vouch for you). Once approved as a guest, you can fly Grouse, but you must always be accompanied by one of the members of the Grouse Mountain Flying Team. The team member will brief you on the site, sign you in, and see you off at launch, etc.

name: Yamaska (Montreal)
desc: 6 launches all around the mountain: 2 North, 2 West, 1 East, 1 South.

name: MacKenzie
desc: There are three main launches in the lower ski area, two for PG and one for HG, as well as an alpine meadow at the top of the mountain that could launch 100+ gliders.

name: Swansea
desc:
Of the 3 launches the NW is the best followed by the West launch.

Mt. Swansea Ridge Launch Site is a nice grassy SW launch site.

name: Mont-Sainte-Anne
desc:
Altitude at the summit : 805 meters (2 625 feet) 
Vertical drop : 625 meters (2 050 feet) 
takeoffs : , ski trails, 6 orientations, NO (expert only), O-NO, O-SO, S, SE & E (wind lower than 20 km/h only)
1 high speed gondola system open 10 months per year or paragliding school shuttle during closing times (contact Aerostyle : 418 955 3117) August and July : Strong breezes starting from 13h PM during

name: carlosparaglideclub
desc: BY carlosparaglide scootertow

name: Mont St Pierre
desc: Mont St-Pierre

name: Cochrane
desc:
Altitude at the top: 1288 meters (4225.5 feet)
GPS: N 51 11 53.17, W -114 26 58.82

Takeoffs : South facing hill is flyable in wind directions from East, South & West winds.  Grassy launch location is well maintained and has a gradual slope for easy takeoffs. High winds can close the site.  Wind gusts come out of nowhere so be very cautious.

name: Dennis Beach
desc:
Private, secluded, Mowed lawn on top of shore slope..35 meters msl.
Cottages next door & B&B to rent..see Ashak Fog from the Bay
Sudden transfer from zero to 30km/h in 30 minutes is very possible.
Wind above 20 is usually 50% stronger on TO.
Verify the tide schedule prior.

name: Sim Site
desc: I'm using this as something to try out sites that haven't been flown before on the simulator, feel free to move it to whereever you want

name: Point Prim
desc: Sheer sandstone cliff, Freshly groomed (06/2012) natural sloped launch with laminar conditions. Launch winds reflect actual soaring conditions. Tide Can remove beach bailout

name: Halliday Bank
desc:
Farmer's active pasture to fenced Sheer Cliff Cross Wind can throw mechanical off undercut areas. Flights beyond point to left of launch in crosswind (N)conditions may push a pilot toward Belfast highlands golf course, which has denied access for fliers. High tides remove beach bailout other then old pier near launch.
Tides: http://www.marees.gc.ca/eng/station?sid=1690

name: Mont-Edouard
desc:
Three different take-off place between N-W to N-E.

Elavation is 450 meters.

Chairlift going up

name: Ymir - Mt Dundee
desc:
South ramp is excellent for HGers, but aging and a little rickety. Difficult rock face for NW launch. Setup area for about 10 gliders. The PGer launch is on a bluff above the HG launch and is usually very easy to launch from.

Contacting KootenayParagliding.com the evening before flying is imperative

name: Robotham Ridge
desc: Take off for Robotham ridge is at 3450 feet over looking the gulf.

name: Mount Prevost
desc: 3 Launches, three wind directions. 2 are cliff launches.

name: Ottawa paragliding school
desc: SCooter Towing

name: Fox River
desc: This sw facing site has a manufactured earthen slope cut into the profile of the ridge to allow a clean flow of air for inflation and launch. It is good for both HG and PG. The set up area is behind the top of the launch slope.

name: White Mountain
desc: There a several along the way.  All require a 45 min to hour hike. The better launches are higher and there is a windsock.  The view is worth the hike. Watch for overdeveloping and wind changes (don't get caught leeside)

name: Vista Mountain
desc: Hike two minutes back down the road from the radio tower to find the trailhead. There is a cutline along Ta'an KwÃ¤ch'Ã¤n Council settlement land to the launch which will take 45-60 minutes hiking in summer and over an hour in spring with snow shoes. It's a beautiful view. Weather can develop quickly here.

name: Sodbusters
desc: There is an access road to a NWTel building with a large field. Follow the ridge trail up and then hear to an small plateau above the building and field. The take-off is a little tricky to the the sharper edge and there is only enough room for a single wing.  In a westerly winds, the angle of the cliff provides lots of lift and the view of the highway,  Lake Laberge and even a small mounting lake make this a fun site to fly.

name: Little Fox Lake
desc: Erik lives near this site and has put a lot of work into cleaning up the launch.  There is lots or room to lay out a wing or two and a brush free slope.

name: Eagle Site - Jakes Corner
desc: A lot of work has gone into clearing the launch. Thanks Karl.  An old mining road will take you most of the way to Launch. There are three options. The first is a steep sloping launch, the second and third more gradual. Watch for converging weather between the two mountain ranges. This can cause big lift in the middle of the valley and making landing at the LZ almost impossible. Fly downwind out of the valley (10+ km)  and out of the venturi to get into calmer wind and to get down.

name: Minto Landing
desc:
Take dirt road to radio tower. Launch is a short hike. Gentle slope for take-off with lots of room. 

View of turnoff to get to launch (heading North on Klondike Highway) http://maps.google.com/maps?source=earth&layer=c&cbll=62.596572,-136.855376&cbp=13,8.8,,0,8.39&ie=UTF8&ll=62.596373,-136.855091&spn=0,359.987168&z=17&panoid=zH_iuefPRB0mIBUVkbj7qg

name: Stewart Crossing
desc: This is only a theoretical take-off. Nobody has flown here yet.  If you take the dirt road to the radio tower about half way (4 km), which is reasonably close the the ridge, you may be able to hike out to the ridge and launch.

name: Klondike - Tombstone Campground
desc: Turn right on the dirt road a few kilometres past the Interpretive Centre.  The road overlooks the Interpretive Centre area and is a good first flight location. Lots of soft moss and not too high.

name: Klondike - Tombstone Goldensides
desc: Steep slope

name: Klondike - Tombstone Angelcomb
desc: Need more info

name: Dawson - Dome
desc:
Primary launch is the south facing launch at the top of the dome which you can drive to. 

There is a North Launch which is recommended only for more advanced pilots. See North Launch listing for location. It's about a 5 minute walk from the parking lot.  To get there, walk down the path in the Northwest Direction and you will find it.

name: Klondike - US-Canada Border
desc:
Several opportunities for new launches. The ones that have been flow include a short hike up a small hill beside a pullout on the right hand side of the road. The pullout is just before a long stretch where the road sidecuts into a valley ridge. From that launch, you can fly the entire valley, evening glass-off works really well for this site.

Other launches are a short hike from the highway. 

All launches are from a relatively high ASL already, so its not a great thermal location.

name: Fraser Lake
desc: Walk, ski or snowmachine from the Canada Customs/Border parking lot until you get to a slope suitable for launching. There are several directions to choose from. Wind can pick up quickly from the south.

name: Dawson - King Solomon Dome
desc: Hike up to radio tower. Be sure lift is good or it's a long hike up.

name: Carcross Desert Training Hill
desc: Top of tallest sand-dune.

name: Teslin Tower
desc: At tower. Advanced launch.

name: Richards Roost
desc:
The hiking trail starts at the south side of the gravel pit.
About 20 minutes to walk to launch.
About 600 feet vertical.

name: Haines Junction Paint Mountain
desc: The takeoff can be reached either by hiking a rarely used trail with some steep parts or by being dropped by helicopter. There are two launch possibilities. One launch is an overgrown clearing for an old tram line (several concert blocks still remain). The second launch is a natural grass slope on the southwest face. Both launches are difficult and expiatory. The view and area are unique compared to many other Yukon flying sights. Strong wind gusts from the nearby Kluane Ice fields. Sometimes unpredictable high winds can occur without notice.

name: Three Guardsmen Pass
desc: Follow an old mining road to an alpine launch spot. You can ridge soar just above the highway. There are many other spots to fly in this area. Coastal/interior transition zone

name: Mountainview
desc:
Hike down dirt road to lookout. Hike up to your right were there is a tree just in front of launch. Use the hump beside the tree, not the slope behind it. Your wing is too easily blown back if you launch behind the tree, plus there is some rotor there. Winter / Spring flying only while river is frozen
Only land on frozen river if wind picks up.

name: Klondike - Keno
desc: Need info from Stan, Shawn or Russell

name: Tally-Ho
desc:
There are a few options. At the end of the road, you will see a dome-like option for take-off. It is a 15 minute hike and provides easy take-off from many directions. This is a good take-off for beginners as due to the various direction options for take-off and landing. There is a second advanced launch over the southeast ridge. If the wind is not constant, you will be in for a long, long hike back up. It may be possible to launch from the dome and thermal over to the ridge. If you take the 4x4 road to the north-facing side of the mountain, there are other launch options. You can choose to fly-down and land on Annie-Lake road. August 15 to September 16 is hunting season and Carcross/Tagish First Nation ask people not to hike there during this period. 

We saw large snow devils forming along the southeast ridge and stayed clear.

name: Dawson - Dome North Launch
desc: Very shallow and advanced launch. Do not launch here without speaking to local pilot. Launch has recently been improved (trees and brush removed) making is easier.

name: Pt Burwell
desc:
No longer trailer park.  Ask on SOUNYPG. Windfinder:  http://www.windfinder.com/forecast/pt_burwell

NOAA MAPS Sounding:  http://www-frd.fsl.noaa.gov/mab/soundings/reply-skewt.cgi?data_source=MAPS&lon=-80.7925&lat=42.6439&airport=%28none%29&add_hours=-3

name: Blue Point
desc:
North facing steep slope launch located in a residential back yard. Check with resident on status.

This is not a public site. Charlie owns the property we park and set up on. We have kept the pilots to a minimum and always call first to OK it with him. In other words this is not a group site. Set up on the other side of the tree line if possible. Not much lift if the wind more the 30Â° off and ruff

name: Bridal Falls (Lower)
desc:
Takeoff is at 2500 ft in a WNW direction.

http://www.westcoastsoaringclub.com/sites/bridal_falls_lower.php

name: Blue Grouse
desc:
Elevation: Launch 2950' ASL - GPS: N 49Â°57'05.70' W 119Â°30'56.30'

Direction of Launch: NE

Vehicle Requirements: Rugged High Clearance 2WD or 4WD 

Outstanding scenery overlooking Okanagan Lake. 
Good smooth round Paragliding launch not visible from the LZ. Kelowna WebCam, looking North West across the lake, looking at Blue Grouse Launch:
http://www.wolfhomes.com/webcam.php

name: Saddle Mountain
desc:
Launch is at the summit of the mountain North West of Lumby BC.

The road up has a LOCKED GATE as the mountain is an active Mine Operation.

Visiting pilots MUST be accompanied by a Lumby Air Force Member Key Holder.

NO OTHER INFORMATION WILL BE PROVIDED ABOUT THIS SITE AT THIS TIME. http://www.theweathernetwork.com/weather/canada/british-columbia/lumby

Atmospheric Soundings. Click on WLW for the Kelowna Airport Soundings:
http://weather.uwyo.edu/upperair/sounding.html

http://www.windfinder.com/forecast/vernon_kalamalka_lake#
http://www.windmapper.com/?Loc=NW

name: Rainbow Mountain  (BC)
desc:
Spectacular Scenery -exact location to be verified!!

Anahim Lake - In the Chilcotin Plateau of Central West B.C. Canada http://images.drivebc.ca/bchighwaycam/pub/html/www/139.html

name: LaFramboise
desc: Nice cliff take off on the stone; place for one paragliding at a time for inflation ;

name: Mont Pelneault
desc:
Large takeoff oriented south; also takeoff possible s-e 
and s-o ; N/A

name: Bald Peak
desc: Need to buy a pass to drive past the gate

name: Gardner's Creek
desc: flat, A ridge strong wind

name: Red Head
desc: Flat river valley sucks the wind inland alot

name: Welsford
desc: 80m rocky

name: Florenceville
desc: small

name: Thompson's lookout
desc:
Direction of Launch: West
Elevation: 7100'asl

name: Cliffton
desc:
Ridge by the beach Small beach & not high cliff=wind gradient effect apound landing on beach

http://www.gnb.ca/0113/cameras/stonehaven-cam-e.asp

The wind gets very strong because of the farm field above the ridge that sucks the sea breaze inland. This site is good on very light wind condition, just like mountain flying almost.

name: Hidden Falls
desc:
Slot facing sw. The launch is 60' wide and 40' deep, basically flat and smooth. The slot extends in front of launch 100 ft. Initial vertical drop of 12 ft then 45 degree slope. Stunted hardwoods to either side of launch. Top landing is very condition dependant for PGs , not recommended for HGs. The site should not be flown in a southerly flow by student or novice pilots as there is a ridge up wind that can throw off nasty stuff in the LZ.
The site is home to some rather scrappy thermal release on hot days at mid day.

name: Cape Chignecto
desc:
Cliff. PG - Groomed launch and set up area. 
Cliff HG - 500' east of PG launch. In development NB. The Bay of Fundy exhibits a phenomenal tidal range. At certain phases of the moon the high tide can reach the base of the cliffs. Low tide is equally exaggerated.

Southerly winds, necessary to fly the long (10km)high cliffs beyond the arc of the bay are short lived in the summer making that section of the ridge difficult to fly. The intertidal zone on this side is also very narrow. It is recommended that only pilots very experienced in coastal flying attempt this ridge.

name: Economy Mountain
desc: Launch is a 60' wide  and extends back 100+'. The front drops off very quickly making a run off difficult.

name: Half Island
desc: Severe Back slope requires cliff side or beach launch significant backslope with much rotor depending on wind speed.

name: West Bay
desc:
HG & PG - Groomed launch and set up area. Launch is 60' asl and is the saddle at the west end of the bay between much higher cliffs. The resultant venturi exaggerates typical wind strength. The bowel shape does not allow for accurate wind direction indication. (See endnote) The land owner appreciates politeness. Important Note: If the wind direction shifts into the south there is a danger of leeside rotor at launch, behind Cape Sharp and that can happen here very quickly.
The Bay of Fundy exhibits a phenomenal tidal range. At certain phases of the moon the high tide can reach the base of the cliffs. Low tide is equally exaggerated.. SE winds have a nasty habit of being short lived before they shift into the SW.

name: High Head
desc: 40' wide and 50' deep grass area. Drive up to launch is requires 4WD

name: Hugh's Brook
desc: Launch is 40' wide and 30' deep very tight for paragliders. At one time or another the Trees at this site have eaten most pilots who have flown here

name: High Perspective Tow
desc:
Trailer mounted tow with trained operators and stepping capable in very large field.  Fairly flat. Ontario summers include the threat of thunder storms.  Call ahead.

Good thermals on occasion.  Here's the NOAA MAPS sounding link for this site:  http://www-frd.fsl.noaa.gov/mab/soundings/reply-skewt.cgi?data_source=MAPS&lon=-79.15&lat=43.90&airport=%28none%29&add_hours=-3

name: East Point Park Scarborough
desc:
East South East facing bluffs that are permit ridge soaring in (moderately rare) ESE onshore winds off of Lake Ontario. Windfinder:  http://www.windfinder.com/forecast/east_point_park_scarborough

NOAA MAPS Sounding:   http://www-frd.fsl.noaa.gov/mab/soundings/reply-skewt.cgi?data_source=MAPS&lon=-79.15&lat=43.7631&airport=%28none%29&add_hours=-3

Pearson high-accuracy forecasts:  http://www.emc.ncep.noaa.gov/mmb/nammeteograms/stations/716240.html

name: Centennial Park Etobicoke
desc: This is a suitable training site for slope gliding and some slope soaring if the wind is right and strong enough.  It's a 90 foot hill used in the winter time as a children's ski hill.

name: Tofield
desc: Launch from gravel road, best tows are in S - N directions but there is also a chance to go W-E.

name: Brennan recreational farm
desc: Large takeoff for 4-5 wings in preparation; grass and cliff; The ridge is long and beautiful ; Be Careful for Antennas !!

name: Riverdale Park
desc: Riverdale Park is a wide open toboggan hill on the Don Valley in downtown Toronto.

name: Kings Forest Park Hamilton aka The Nest
desc:
****This is has officially been closed by the City of Hamilton***

Open meadow, 30 degree hill, lightly covered in grass, shrubs. Windfinder:  http://www.windfinder.com/forecast/kings_forest_park_hamilton

NOAA MAPS Sounding:  http://www-frd.fsl.noaa.gov/mab/soundings/reply-skewt.cgi?data_source=MAPS&lon=-79.8146&lat=43.2136&airport=%28none%29&add_hours=-3

Hamilton airport high-accuracy forecast: http://www.emc.ncep.noaa.gov/mmb/nammeteograms/stations/712630.html

name: Atlin - Monarch Mountain
desc:
It's a 1.5 hours to get to the launch. 

Grassy area on the ridge to the right of the trail near the summit. Watch for quickly building winds coming from the south in the afternoon.

name: Cathedral Bluffers Park (Toronto)
desc:
Cliff launch, fairly rough due to the turbulence at launch. Not suitable for beginners.

Awful take off site, especially in the summer with all the plants and trees that can snag on your glider! The cliff doesn't have a slope at all, its basically a small patch of flat(barely big enough to lay your glider down), and then a straight drop! No room to run! it would only work at perfect wind and absolutely no gust or cross wind!

Behind this place there a park where if you are a paramotor pilot would work great. Launch is in a bowl and can create turbulence at launch. 

Windfinder:  http://www.windfinder.com/forecast/cathedral_bluffers_park

Unlikely to thermal, but here is NOAA MAPS sounding link:  http://www-frd.fsl.noaa.gov/mab/soundings/reply-skewt.cgi?data_source=MAPS&lon=-79.2281&lat=43.7165&airport=%28none%29&add_hours=3

desc:

name: Mt. Sima
desc:
Ensure you check-in with guest services prior to flying or contact the general manager if during off-season. HPAC insurance must be presented and site orientation completed. This is not a beginner site due to the distance to the LZ presently and the complications of the LZ (buildings, traffic, power lines).  There are three launches. Two South Launches and a North Launch. To get to the North Launch (closest), take the chair lift and go right. It's right there on Dan's Descent. During skiing season, be sure to leave enough room when setting up your wing to allow skiers to pass by.  To get to the south launch, go straight, then left when existing the chair lift. Hike up to the Observation Tower (about 5 minutes). The SouthEast launch (new) is directly below the tower. For the South Launch, follow the Lefty Loosey bike trail called  down (2-3 minutes). You will walk right past the open open clear launch. Hard to miss. Float Planes do approach over Sima on route to Schwatka Lake. Contact Air Traffic Control (867) 667-8426 prior to take-off. 

http://mountsima.com/Mountain-Info/Weather

name: Prarie Mountain
desc: Big grassy field facing SW, nice to wing. No major obstacles. The hike is approximately 1.5 to 2 hours depending on fitness and weight of gear. The site has strong winds pretty often.

name: Anarchist (Osoyoos)
desc:
A small crude grassy slope over a rock bluff. A short steep 150' hike in up a 40Â° slope.

Direction of Launch: SW
Site Suitable For: PG & HG
Type of Site: Mountain
Type of Flying: Thermal, Ridge, Glass off
Elevation Launch: 4200' asl
GPS: N 49 02 42.8 W 119 24 09.4

Cross Country Potential: Excellent
Rated: PG: Int. HG: Int.
Location: Osoyoos BC, Sth Okanagan Valley - at the summit of the hill heading East out of town.
Site Regulation: SOAR Anarchist Summit Webcam, east of Osoyoos, looking east.
http://images.drivebc.ca/bchighwaycam/pub/html/www/64.html

This is a SW facing site, but it is best in NW cross winds.
North winds can come up suddenly on an otherwise south or no wind day, and they can be rather hairy, so keep an eye on the north end of the lake.

name: Blackstrap Ridge / Saskatoon Ridge
desc: Walk up, about 150' of vertical. Launch to the west, hope for about 18-25kmh W, WNW, or WSW jump off, beware the prickly hawthorn brush off the the north, it won't let go your glider.

name: Nares Mountain
desc: Visit http://www.yukonhiking.ca/nares.html for detail of how to get there. Wind can pick up quickly.

name: Mount Mac
desc: This is one of the few North-facing launches we have around Whitehorse. Do not confuse with the Mt. Mac Ski Lodge. To get to the flying site, you need to drive through the gravel pit at Lowbird Road. Follow the gravel road up to Mount Mac, just below the gated tower. Walk to the launch at the left.

name: Camping Ste Veronique
desc: small hill covered with grass... one wing at a time

name: Mont-Blanc
desc: large take off at the top of the hill ; good for 4-5 wings preparation ; grass

name: Nadahini
desc: Hike in on the old mining access road about a mile to a rocky knob on the right. Head up the south facing slope to a suitable launch site. Mountain flying, coastal/interior transition zone.

name: Teston Rd Vaughan
desc:
Small artificial hill formed by construction waste, fresh clean dirt fill on top at present, but grown over a couple of weeks ago.  West facing.

About 300 meters long, 25 meters high.

Chance of rotor is great as is it only a small elliptical hill.

Top of the hill is quit long and narrow and is full of broken glass and metal pieces sticking out.

Also, consider health risks as this is a construction waste landfill. fine dust is picked up at every gust and if it gets into your glider its not coming out! its a fine mixture of cement and gypsum dust. Windfinder:  http://www.windfinder.com/forecast/buttonville_airport_toronto

NOAA MAPS Sounding:  http://www-frd.fsl.noaa.gov/mab/soundings/reply-skewt.cgi?data_source=MAPS&lon=-79.505138&lat=43.8763&airport=%28none%29&add_hours=-3

Pearson high-accuracy forecasts:  http://www.emc.ncep.noaa.gov/mmb/nammeteograms/stations/716240.html

name: Teston Rd Vaughn 2nd site
desc:
This site is a closed and under remediation landfill.  It's covered in short weeds.

The hill itself is a stepped hill with the peak around 890 feet above sea level that has good exposure to SSE and NNW. 

There is also a W facing shallow slope that is a good beginners hill. Windfinder:  http://www.windfinder.com/forecast/buttonville_airport_toronto

NOAA MAPS Sounding:  http://www-frd.fsl.noaa.gov/mab/soundings/reply-skewt.cgi?data_source=MAPS&lon=-79.505138&lat=43.8763&airport=%28none%29&add_hours=-3

Pearson high-accuracy forecasts: http://www.emc.ncep.noaa.gov/mmb/nammeteograms/stations/716240.html

name: Intrepid Park Whitby
desc:
Intrepid Park behind Canlan Ice Sports Arena. Windfinder:  http://www.windfinder.com/forecast/oshawa_the_vicarage

NOAA MAPS sounding link:  http://www-frd.fsl.noaa.gov/mab/soundings/reply-skewt.cgi?data_source=MAPS&lon=-78.879862&lat=43.853964&airport=%28none%29&add_hours=-3

Pearson high-accuracy forecast: http://www.emc.ncep.noaa.gov/mmb/nammeteograms/stations/716240.html

name: Thickson Rd Whitby
desc:
Lakeside cliff, quite steep.  Rotors fairly close to edge. Not suitable for beginners. Windfinder:  http://www.windfinder.com/forecast/oshawa_the_vicarage

NOAA MAPS sounding: http://www-frd.fsl.noaa.gov/mab/soundings/reply-skewt.cgi?data_source=MAPS&lon=-78.9000&lat=43.8499&airport=%28none%29&add_hours=-3

Pearson high-accuracy forecast: http://www.emc.ncep.noaa.gov/mmb/nammeteograms/stations/716240.html

name: Fly Hills Lower, Mid and Upper Launches.
desc:
Turn south - west off highway #1 onto Salmon River road. Follow (snowmobile signs) Go about 3km  and turn right on Christionson Rd.  Keep left at the fork and follow up to skidoo parking lot which is at 1 km. 

Luke's Launch is about 150 yard walk due East from the SE corner of the parking lot.

Fly Hills Mid Launch.
From the skidoo parking lot continue on up the logging road to 7.5 km. where you'll find another parking lot to the left. Hike the half km to the Fly Hills Mid Launch. (Carpeted)

Fly Hills Upper Launch
Higher yet is Fly Hills South launch at about 14km. 
Keepi left at 12.25 km. Park at radio tower and find the quad trail off the road 50 m due south of the parking lot along the road. http://www.theweathernetwork.com/weather/canada/british-columbia/salmon-arm

Salmon Arm Airport (CZAM) Webcam - A view in southeastern direction away from Fly Hills
http://www.metcam.navcanada.ca/hb/player.jsp?id=85&cam=194&lang=e

Some chance of rotor over the trees with west winds on the Upper (South) launch.

name: Fly Hills north
desc:
Small newly cleared fall 2012 
About 4300 feet ASL 
 Around the 14km marker on the Fly Hills logging road west of town. 
Turn west off highway #1 onto Salmon river road. (look for skidoo rec signs)Travel about 3km turn right onto Christionson rd. staying left continue on up to the Fly Hills logging road. Km signs start at cattle gaurd at the end of pavement. At 1km is the skidoo parking lot. Luke's launch is a short 200-300 yard walk due east from the SE corner of the parking lot. 
Continue on up to 7.5km to another parking lot. Again take the SE trail to the carpeted Fly Hills north launch. Have a look around then head on up to the Fly Hills south launch at 14km staying left at the fork at 12.5. 
Park at the radio tower and find the quad trail over the bank and across the road (due south.) If upper winds are from the west/northwest watch for roter over trees on Fly Hills South launch. Watch your ribbons.

name: Petite neigette
desc:
take-off
Description: No obvious. Very steep slope.
Coordinates: Latitude N 48 Â° 26 '48.7 '(48.44686 Â°)
Longitudes 68 Â° 18 '02.7 '(68.30074 Â°)
Surface: Natural.
Elevation: 300 m. (700pi.) AGL
Orientation: North West (330degrÃ©s)
Portage: 2 minutes
Windsock: Yes
4X4 only access mode or walk (2 km from the parking lot of the Neigette fall).
Space Position: 8 wings. Avoid to take off in strong N-E or S-W. Those winds are know to cause strong turbulence.

name: Coopers ('Thermal Rise')
desc:
Direction of Launches: East, North East, South East and South
Site Suitable for: Hang Gliding and Paragliding
Type of Site: Mountain
Type of Flying: Ridge / Thermal / Training
Elevation Launch: 3450' Asl 
GPS Launch: N 118Â°59'09.79' W 50Â°17'08.30'

Excellent, large rounded grassy clearing overlooking the Freedom Flight Park LZ.

No further information is provided.
You must stop off at Freedom Flight Park to sign the Lumby Air Force Waiver. 
You will then be given directions to the launch site. http://www.theweathernetwork.com/weather/canada/british-columbia/lumby
http://www.canadarasp.com/windgrams/?region=4&location=0&plotType=1

Atmospheric Soundings. Click on WLW for the Kelowna Airport Soundings:
http://weather.uwyo.edu/upperair/sounding.html

http://www.windfinder.com/forecast/vernon_kalamalka_lake#
http://www.windmapper.com/?Loc=NW

webcam/ wind: http://osa-weather.weebly.com/coopers.html

name: Le Grand Morne
desc:
Plateforme de bois avec revÃªtement anti-accros pour parapente.

46Â°08'14.4'N 71Â°06'00.2'W
(46.137341, -71.100049)

name: Dawson - Sunnydale
desc: Take the Ice Road (or Ferry) over to West Dawson and head up the Top of the World HIghtway. When you come to Sunnydale Road, stay right, then pull over just before the road banks right. The trail head is there and is about a five minute hike. The launch is fairly small, there are trees to clear as well as a river to fly across to get to the LZ. Due to the river in Summer, this makes the launch for Advanced pilots only. In winter or spring, when the river is frozen, this site is safer to launch from. The Yukon River.

name: Diefenbaker Training Hill
desc: Takeoff from one of the three sided hills depending on the wind

name: Haeckel Hill
desc:
There are three potential takeoff's
1) Southeast (Intermediate)
2) South (Beginner)
- In front of main windmill. Lots of room.
- Watch of snaggy bushes. 
3) West (Advanced)
- a bit of a hike and you need to ensure the wind is stable or you may sink out and won't reach the LZ
4) North (Possible, but not practical) - A tricky, rocky launch that is soar-able in only perfect conditions. Landing zone is huge, but it's a long hike back up. Possible to take ATV Trail, but it's also long and technical. Windmills, Power lines. Air traffic.

name: Schwatka Lake
desc: So long as the lake is frozen, this is an easy launch for learning to fly. A few minutes hike from the parking lot, wings have lots of room to be laid out and there is little bush to get in the way. Winter and spring only while the lake is frozen.

name: Havelock
desc:
2 official runways
290'&110', 250 & 80' Wind gradient, thermals, planes

name: Tyler's Bay
desc: Tides: http://www.marees.gc.ca/eng/station?sid=1800

name: Little Nic
desc:
WSW facing Slope between the trees. 1500'(480m)site set up for 2 gliders.
Ridge soarable in light west to southwesterlies.
If you take off from the slope make sure your wing is level or you will end up in the trees. Usually the last site in the fraser valley to get blown out but summer sea breezes june-august can become quite strong at times.

name: Ripley
desc: Ripley lower launch is a gentle grassy slope with an elevation of 770 meters. About a 30 minute easy hike up the north side.

name: Mont Ste-Marie (MSM) South
desc: Large take off oriented south, south west and west from a cliff.

name: Hedley
desc:
Very large grassy slope easy to drive to.
Gravel road in good condition maintained all year. Strong weather systems, valley winds, venturi effects, and strong thermals can make this an unforgiving site.

name: Cawston
desc:
Small grassy outcrop amongst the scrubby slope. The notorious Cawston blast off must be regarded. Serious winds in this valley.
Otherwise, it can offer sled rides, soaring or xc to another valley.

name: Mont Ste-Marie (MSM) West
desc:
place for one wing at a time
In front of a rock cliff

name: Mont-Megantic
desc:
Cliff type with space for one wing at a time. In low wind conditions paraglider's may need to take speed running in trail under antenna auban.

Enough space for setting up 5 to 6 wings.

name: Mesa Butte
desc: Nice grassy top and slope.

name: Pin rouge
desc:
this is a shi hill 450 meters
we use run #4 ,5,9

name: Elk Mountain
desc:
Alpine meadow launch facing SE-SW at 1440 m asl. Excellent angle for beginners to expert pilots. Alpine weather should be thoroughly checked before commencing challenging hike. 
Winds can get very strong

name: Mount St. Benedict
desc: W/SW, with carpet and room for 1-2 gliders. 2 nice winds socks, with some rotor possible on the takeoff Good summer location, when Frazier Valley sites are getting blown out. Be careful about cloud suck.

name: Stawamus Chief Mountain
desc: Squamish is known to be windy! Not flyable on a N wind. Best to have SW direction for the takeoff. It is smooth granite slab with a nice sloped launch that eventually cliffs out. You should have more than enough room to be flying before it does but be aware of it. 20-30 seconds after you take off you are hitting the edge of the Chief, and it is a 600m vertical cliff. Make sure mid valley winds are not crazy. You could be doing forward launch in zero wind on the summit, and there can be 30-40km winds over the valley. Pay attention to what the water is doing in the valley - if there are white caps it's too windy. watch crazy mid summer winds. Usually in the summer you can only fly before 10 am and right before sunset

name: Go Parapente
desc: Pente École Goparapente.ca

name: Orofino
desc: Rough drive up, 4x4 needed to launch.  Stick to the radio tower road and park off the road as it is narrow.  Walk up the 400m to a crude dirt/grass slope.  Launch can work facing west or south.

name: Mount Kobau
desc: Drive directly up to Mount Kobau parking lot and hike the last kilometer to launch.

name: Benny HG
desc: Short approach ramp so better for Hang Gliding launch than PG.

name: Horsefly
desc: Sketchy takeoff from an old logging road. You only have about 2m (after laying out your glider, before the terrain drops to a 55 (plus) degree slope, covered with debris from logging. Crashing on this takeoff would be simply catastrophic or fatal. It's located in sub alpine, so it has all the mountain hazards. There are 2 places- one more East, one more West, depending on wind cycles (site works with N and NE only. http://www.canadarasp.com/windgrams/?region=0&location=18&plotType=0

name: Ross' Ridge
desc: Launch is large enough to set up only one wing at a time. It has an excellent slope. Do not walk through farmer’s crop.  Go around field perimeter to launch. Launch  is short –maintained natural grass with some roughness to ground.

name: Cousins Shore
desc: Nice grassy area to set up and launch from. can sometimes be hard to inflate with the sharp edge of the bank. Try to stay out of the fields. Launching is usually best between the small point and the little gorge that is on launch. NNE winds 20-35 Km/h is ideal.

name: Shaws Bank
desc: Tides: http://www.marees.gc.ca/eng/station?sid=1715

name: Fitzpatricks Mountain
desc: Foot launch, slot, NW NW, excellent thermic site, look at upper winds as well as surface winds, winds can be crossed outside of slot but straight in at launch

name: Savona
desc: null

name: Rainbow Mountain (Alpine Meadows)
desc: This is an advanced site. Launch is treed in so be careful if winds are strong, particularly from the south or could get a collapse when u fly out from trees.

name: Mont-Ham
desc: Décollage sur rocher

name: Grand Valley
desc: Club-based aero-towing for hang gliding only.

name: Pokeshaw Cliff / Air Exploration
desc: Good Paramotor training Ground, lite sea breese in the spring and summer super smooth conditions, nice free flight cliff also. Air Exploration offer paramotor Training, no hill around that creates rotors and Low thermal activities environment.

name: Athabasca Lookout
desc:
HG and PG flyable, however more convenient for PG as there is a hike to launch from the top parking lot. 20 minute hike or so. 
There used to be a HG ramp on the second peak to the right from the Lookout Towers, long since gone.
Launch either next to the antennas, or where the HG ramp used to be. A grassy area good for launching available as well. Takes WSW-W-WNW winds. Due to its position, the sun heats the slopes of the ridge later in the day and it's not a primarily ridge soaring site (even if it can be soared when the wind is right) so, generally, later launches are rewarded with better flights due to better thermal formation.

name: Les Dunes
desc: null

name: Fiesch -Kuehboden (Heimat- Galfera)
desc:
'Heimat': mostly used in the morning;
'Galvera': used in the afternoon;
HG-Ramp in front of cable car station AVOID: 'Bise' (NE-wind), 'Foehn' (S-Wind).
Wind in the valley can become quite strong in the afternoon. 
When flying East: 'Grimselschlange' (N-wind flowing over Grimsel-pass) can cause problems.

Weather info:
- Fiesch: http://www.meteocentrale.ch/de/europa/schweiz/wetter-fiesch/details/N-3514048/
- Wind etc:  https://www.meteoschweiz.admin.ch/home/messwerte.html?param=messwerte-windgeschwindigkeit-kmh-10min
>> zoom in for winds on Eggishorn etc   (The MeteoSwiss App for Iphone etc is much better!)
- Föhndiagramm:  http://www.meteocentrale.ch/de/wetter/foehn-und-bise/foehn.html
- https://flugplatz-schaenis.ch/

name: Fanas -Hörnli -Eggli
desc:
Main launch sites: 
-'Eggli' (1650m): about 200 meters to the SE of the top of the cable car;
- 'Hoernli' (1800m): on top of the mountain about 20 Minutes uphill. Both sites are easy and large enough for many pilots. 
HG's use 'Eggli'
Alternative launches:
-'Mast 4' preferred by HG, as easily reached by car
-'Plandadein' -outside vegetation period only!!! (turns on only in the (late) afternoon) Not recommended when wind is strong NW to NE. Do not fly when 'Föhn' is blowing or predicted.
'Föhn' is a strong, turbulent (south-)wind over the Alps due to large pressure differential between south and north side of Alps. ('Nordföhn' in Ticino/ northern Italy also exists and is normally even more turbulent!)
- Föhndiagramm: http://www.meteocentrale.ch/de/wetter/foehn-und-bise/foehn.html;
- Webcam: https://www.bergfex.ch/sommer/fanas/webcams/c6204/

name: Obere Wengi
desc:
Large moderatley sloped field. Easy take-off. Heavely frequented on good days. Thermal 100 meters to the left of the take off. 
Launch site belongs to the farmer running a small restaurant next to the site, it is expected to consume something before taking-off (instead a launching fee). Bise (NE - E Wind) must not be too strong. Do NOT take off if wind is westerly, north-westerly or north, it will put you into the trees below take off.

name: Grindelwald - First
desc:
huge TO area, suited for all levels; easy access by gondola from Grindelwald, TOP-landing also possible... Föhn!!
Weather info:

TO 'Fontanets': walk for about15mins, facing SW, W. (46.0842 N, 7.2583 E)
TO 'Attelas': rarely used anymore; small/ steep Weather info:

name: Baldern (Uetliberg)
desc: Small clearing on ridge. Just wide enough for one paraglider. Wind has to be easterly (so called Bise) between about 15 and 25 kmh. Only flyable when Bise is blowing (Easterly wind).

name: Oberrieden
desc: Large field just above a little road. Easy. This site is only flyable when the Bise (easterly wind) is blowing. Wind must be 15 - 25 km/h at launch. Observe the strenght of the wind. Getting blown over the back is not an option.

name: Engelberg - Brunni - Schonegg
desc:
Big, nicely sloped field with windsock. Advanced pilots usually walk up into the steeper part of the slope to get an earlier take-off time.
Thermal is usually over the trees slightly to the left of the launch.

BrunnihÃƒÂ¼tte take off : 46.8426 N; 8.41008 E, 1860m. 
Schonegg: take off : 46.8435 N; 8.41665 E, 2080m. Can get rough when the easterly wind (Bise) is strong. 
Do NOT fly when there is FÃƒÂ¶hn (Southerly wind combined with high differences in pressure between the south and the north of Switzerland Locarno - ZÃƒÂ¼rich > 3 hpa difference).
Be aware of turbulences when the wind is westerly.

Just 2min walk from cable car Station 'Braunwald'.

name: Buochserhorn
desc: Easy large sloping grassy takeoff right next to the large white cross on the summit. Can handle S to W winds. Be careful of a small cable crossing the field just below the takeoff - but it is plainly visible.

desc:

desc: Easy to medium difficulty. Steep alpine meadow oriented towards south west. Light west wind is ideal.

In summer, starting around noon, the 'Malojawind' is normally blowing!

name: Schänis / Hüsliberg
desc:
Hüsliberg: NO parking available at launch!!! > use shuttle bus from LZ (or hike: 1.5hrs)
In summer (June and September) the launch will be temporarily closed for a few weeks (cows in the field)!
Use only dedicated TO: other possible launches higher up are in wildlife protection area and therefore not allowed! Dangers: Föhn and (strong) Bise!

name: Mornera (Bellinzona)
desc:
By far the best takeoff for cross country in Ticino.
Not as known as Locarno-Cimetta but still very good, as it is easy to close triangles when you start from there.
You have to BOOK you cablecar the day before, otherwise you will never make it up to the take off in time (april-october). This spot is very subject to north wind situation, as the wind is canalized through the San Gotthard Valleys (Rivera, Leventina).

name: Zermatt -Rothorn- Blauherd- Sunegga
desc:
1) Rothorn TO:
* Take off 3100m facing North and South.
* Most common Winter & Summer take off site. Generally good snow coverage with light winds. Stronger during Spring.
* Rocky coverage in Summer with strong winds to be expected in afternoons.

2) Blauherd TO:
* Take off 2'600m facing West.
* Generally a Summer take off site.
* Approx. 5 mins walk downhill from Blauherd Station.
* Grassy slope in Summer with light winds increasing with thermic and valley winds in afternoon.

3) Sunnegga TO:
* Take off 2'200m generally flown during the off season when Blauherd and Rothorn lifts not operating.
* Wind starts moderate and increases beyond launchable by early afternoon.

name: Arosa -Weisshorn
desc:
TO's are on top of the 'Weisshorn' (>> see pictures).
In Summer the only direction available is SW, in Winter it's also possible to TO towards NE.
In Winter TO is performed on the (groomed) ski slopes. Theoretically this is not allowed in Switzerland. On the Weisshorn it's tolerated, as long as one leaves enough space for the skiers/ snowboardes to pass...
TO to the NNW: VERY short, there is NO space for an aborted TO!!! (see picture). Föhn!!!
As the 'Weisshorn' stands virtually alone and is looking like a pyramid, the wind situation can be VERY tricky!
If in doubt take the cable car down (free for PG-pilots, when not flying due to wx!)
So far several accidents due to wind!!!
Webcam: https://weisshorn.roundshot.com/
Weather info:
- Wind etc: https://www.meteoswiss.admin.ch/home/measurement-values.html?param=messwerte-wind-boeenspitze-kmh-10min
>> zoom in for winds on Weissfluh etc
- Föhndiagramm: http://www.meteocentrale.ch/de/wetter/foehn-und-bise/foehn.html
- http://www.wetter-arosa.ch/
- http://www.schaenissoaring.ch
- 7-day Fcst: https://www.meteoblue.com/de/wetter/woche/arosa_schweiz_2661712
- https://www.windfinder.com/forecast/arosa_weisshorn_2600

from 9:00am to 17:00 in the summer

desc:
The takeoff is situated at the top of chairlift in Champex, 2192m.
There a west wind take-off and a east one. In summer it is recommended to exploit the thermals with the east wind. In winter it's easy to take with west wind and eventually do some soaring. DO NOT FLY WITH SOUTH WIND!!! FOEHN = DANGER!!

Wind can get quite strong. But often it's already easier to launch if you just walk down a few meters to get out of the strongest compression zone.

Max 15-20 meteo wind. See the windbalise of 'MÃ©tÃ©oSuisse' at 'La DÃ´le': http://www.meteosuisse.admin.ch/web/fr/meteo/temps_actuel.par0023.html?allStations=1

desc:
Ca. 200 m on the left side of the top station of the new cable car coming from Siviez. Best takeoff direction is facing eastwards. 
For good pilots the takeoff on the west side is an other possibility. But it is a very short takeoff track followed by steep cliffs. Better have a stronger wind to take off westwards!

name: Bogiàn
desc:
Decollo Torre di Bogiàn
Situata in una zona storica di Roveredo GR, la torre di Bogiàn è molto interessante in quanto si necessitano solamente 35-40 minuti per raggiungerlo. Il terreno è privato e quindi si necessita una cura ed un rispetto degni di nota!
Il sito si presta in modo ottimale per dei voli serali in dinamica. Se le condizioni lo permettono è possibile pure fare dei voli con tramonto del sole a vista! Quando andare: Primavera - Estate, decollo serale 16:30 - 18:00.
Direzione ed intensità del vento: Sud/Sud-ovest ~15-25 kmh.

name: Camou, Pian San Giacomo
desc:
Take off is possible right over the water station.
The best solution is nevertheless to take off from the lawn at the end of the street, beneath the trees. This avoids taking off with side wind. This is a good spot to fly in the afternoon. It is possible to do soaring or thermal flying. Best conditions are to be experienced during late spring and during summer.
Watch out for storms in summer. This is an alpine area. The weather can change quiet quickly and sometimes the weather forecasts aren't fully trustable, because of the near, north end of the alpine chain. Always carefully plan your flights in function of the weather conditions.
If you don't know what to do, contact us. We will be pleased to help you fly with the best conditions and in full safety, by giving you the right advises.

name: Soglio
desc: Big alpine pastures with lots of space. Please take care of high grass and grazing animals! The valley wind in the Val Bregaglia can get quite strong in summer time.

name: Hirzli
desc:
Nice grassy hillside, oriented towards northwest. Flyable with wind directions from NW to NE.

Be mindful of the potentially strong valley winds around Niederurnen! In doubt, land to the northwest of Niederurnen.

DO NOT land near the cable car station in Niederurnen, there is a dangerous rotor!

name: Cousimbert
desc: not allowed from december to june

name: Randonnaz
desc: Nice meadow Dangerous when the south wind (Foehn) is blowing, and tricky in the afternoon during the summer (valley wind).

name: La Tourche
desc: deep meadow

name: Ceta
desc:
From the top south of the alp of Ceta, there's a corridor free of trees and cables that leads directly straight to the main thermal source, over the  lower easternmost houses of Ceta.
It's good in the morning up to 12:00 since it's east facing. Typical valley wind, check wind forecast and Föhn previsions on https://cvlt.ch/vento/ . it is recommended to use this takeoff with pressure difference 0-4 hPa from south. IT'S DANGEROUS TO FLY WITH NORTH WIND!

name: Suossa, San Bernardino
desc:
Easily accessible from the Du Lac parking lot, this takeoff is suitable for summer evening thermal flights because it lets you easily reach the west face of the mountains. Being in a small valley just south of the main alpine ridge, be really careful about weather conditions. FLYING WITH NORTH WIND CAN BE DEADLY! 
Check the wind conditions on www.cvlt.ch/vento

name: Bocchetta de Curciusa, San Bernardino
desc:
this takeoff has a short "runway", and is recommended only to pilots with a lot of alpine experience. Being over the altitude of the main pass, this takeoff is easily influenced by valley winds.

PLEASE BEWARE THAT THIS VALLEY IS ORIENTED TO NORTH (the water flows to north, the valley wind to the south)
This actually means that even if the wind condition is south, in summer and generally on thermal days, the start could be totally lee side and therefore you cannot start. This happens becaus the breeze is coming from NORTH as the valley is directly connected to the NORTHERN side of the alps!

name: Bocca de Rogna - San Bernardino
desc: This takeoff is really good for morning hike & flys from San Bernardino. Recommended is the panoramic route going through Pass di Passit, Pass de la Cruseta, and further south to takeoff. Being at high altitude and close to the main alpine ridge it is recommended to check the föhn previsions very carefully. This can be found on www.cvlt.ch/vento . FLYING WITH NORTH WIND CAN BE DEADLY!

name: Confin, San Bernardino
desc: easy grassy takeoff, suitable for easy hike & flys. This takeoff works best in the morning, with weak south wind. Be wary that this takeoff is close to the main alpine ridge. FLYING WITH NORTH WIND HRE CAN BE DEADLY!

name: Bochèta de Vegeina
desc:
Take off is situated on a grassy top, signed by a pile of stones (Stone man). https://bit.ly/2OqkMvE Good spot to start when there is inversion below 2000m.
Whatch out the east wind. Better conditions are to be found with southern wind or very low northwind conditions over 2500m (max 5-10kmh).

desc: Plusieurs possibilités au sommet. Attention au lignes sur les roches.

This site was abandoned by it's French owners due to the First Ivorian Civil war (2002-7). It will need to be weeded. Cost estimate €20 for a day's work. The wind comes from the East, so I'm not sure why this north facing site was created, or how it worked.

Wide take of area. Condition: thermals, with highest thermal activity in Summer between 12.00 and 16.00 hrs. Best hour for leasure pilots: from 16.00 to 19.00 hrs. Best time for beginners: 19.00 to 20.00 hrs.
In Spring and Autom, condition is moderated and easy for all kinds of pilots. Winter May, June July is not recomended: rain and temperatures may fall below 0...

name: Bucaramanga - Las Aguilas
desc: A long windward mesa overlooking Bucaramanga with 2 launches that are top landing too. A large main LZ serves both sites below, with several alternative bailout landing areas. It's an excellent training site, featuring early morning and late afternoon sled rides for the novice pilot, mid morning thermic and XC flights, and afternoon dynamic ridge lift that transforms into glass-off conditions into sunset. Incredibly consistent conditions where you can practice kiting, top landing, and playing all day every day. http://www.weatherlink.com/user/lasaguilas/index.php?view=main&headers=1&type=1

It's an excellent training site, featuring early morning and late afternoon sled rides for the novice pilot, mid morning thermic and XC flights, and afternoon dynamic ridge lift that transforms into glass-off conditions into sunset. Incredibly consistent conditions where you can practice kiting, top landing, and playing all day every day.

name: Cocorna

name: Sibundoy
desc: Takeoff facing south east slope suitable for paragliding and hang gliding Strong winds in July and August

name: Calima
desc:
Area pilots say that the infrastructure is good, bringing all his knowledge and candles for free flight and paramotor.
At the edge of a lake is located Calima complex alpine style chalets for guests willing to accommodate horseback riding, sailing and kayaking, plus gliders. The scenery is superb and offers two departures with lake view. The best conditions for flight are in the morning, and locals say there 300 days a year of good time, besides the tropical exoticism, its colors and flavors ... Great weather, 365 per year

name: Altos Las Tres Cruzes Soacha
desc:
The take off is great with possibilities to do top landing, if you are new to the area Please get in touch with one of the local pilots to prevent issues with the locals.

El despegue es increible con posibilidades de top landing. Si eres nuevo a la area, porfavor contacta uno de los pilotos locales para prevenir problemas con las personas que viven en esa localidad 300 meters away from take off to the left, there is a rotor that forms, stay away or cross with enough altitude to prevent collapse. Do not fly if winds exceed 15mph

300 metros saliendo de el despegue a la izquierda se encuentra un rotor, mantengase fuera o cruze con sufficiente altura para prevenir colapse. No vuele si los vientos exceeden 22 kmh

name: Cordoncillo
desc: This is a nice, very big takeoff site covered by grass. The thermal upwind makes it easy to takeoff.

name: Bucaramanga - Las Aguilas
desc:
Altitude: 1148 m

Large grassy field sloping Northward towards a cliff.  Privately owned club site.  Cost is 10.000 COP daily or 40.000 Monthly.

There is a hostel next door to the launch, http://colombiaparagliding.com Strongest winds are mid-day after the sun has been out for around 4 hours.  Overdevelopment common around mid-day.

name: Calentón
desc: On this small takeoff there is a very narrow space which only allows one paraglider to prepare for takeoff. Wait for a good headwind to takeoff. Normally in the mornings there is a nice headwind. In the afternoon wind can turn and come from behind.

name: Titiribí
desc: The very big and wide takeoff field is covered by grass. With a nicely blowing headwind which is created by thermal activities, taking off is very easy.

name: Fredonia
desc: The takeoff is very planar, that is why you should wait for a good squall to take off. Next to this field there is a very steep field from where taking off is possible despite of slow wind.

name: Jericó
desc: ECOLAND has a new take off area with more than 3000 thousand square metters wich makes this place very safe for beginers and advance pilots. we fly all year

name: Pantanillo
desc: This was the birth place of paragliding in Antioquia and has a a nice, big takeoff where taking off is easy because of good thermal upwinds.

name: Jardín
desc: This flying site has a big field with a nice inclination as a takeoff. This makes it easy to take off for every type of pilot. flight often under a north component in altitude, but the site is protected

name: Arroyo Piedra
desc: The take off is short, completely flat, with gravel, on a vertical cliff. The wind generates a rotor on the launching site which, when the breeze is weak is manageable as it stays lower than three meters. When the wind reinforces the rotor increases, making the take off impossible. It is a technical take off. Not for the beginners or the faint hearted. Very unforgiving. Not much. It is a pure ridge soaring flight. You can stay up for ages until the wind reinforces. You will have a good clue when you see the top of the waves far away getting white. Then is time to land.

name: Florida
desc: Large area, grass, top landing possible. Infrastructure on the takeoff in development (in the future restaurant, accommodation etc.). Currently accessible via a car - must be 4x4! in order to be good, this site needs sun in the flatlands/ foothills, otherwise it's not worth going there.

difficult : short and steep
The launch lies northeast  of Dora village, just off the main road at the north end of the bowl. It is about 1300 feet above the river plain, faces southwest and catches the prevailing breezes coming up the valley from the coast.

name: Cirium (Kourion)
desc:
There are actually  two launch sites at Kourion that are regularly used for paragliding. A brief discussion of them follows.
Armpit: This is probably the easiest launch and is the most often used. It is also the easiest to get to. But this launch should not be used when the wind is westerly because of turbulence, which can get very strong.
Lower Sand Pit: This is used when the wind becomes strong, or when a new pilot needs a less vigorous launch breeze. Take great care not to get blown back. The road, power lines and obvious rotor are real hazards, not to mention the antiquities sites. Sea breezes can start quickly and can catch you unaware. As a rule of thumb, at the first sign of white  waves on the sea surface please land quickly.

If you think that it is too windy to fly, it probably is - donâ€™t take off.
Be cautious of the rotor when wind speed are high, especially around the areas marked on the map.

name: Stavrovouni
desc:
There are actually two takeoff fields - one situated towards north-east, and one towards north-west.
The north-east field: not a big field but with some upward wind takeoff will be much easier but in any case not for beginners.
The western field has slightly smaller slope but more rocks.

name: Lefkara
desc: The take off area is clean of any plant life or rocks that would snag lines and the area to launch from is large. Most sites in Cyprus are small, with rocks and little thistley type plants that love to snag lines, making a clean 'pull-up' very difficult.

name: Avdellaro
desc: There are a couple of launch points on this hill though one (the nicer launch) has fallen into disrepair and the track to it is overgrown and would require 4x4 for access.  The other is at UN control point 111 and so this is how we refer to it.

name: Vougies
desc: There are three launch points on these hills.  A NNW Launch on the Western Hill (To the left of a metal shelter structure) and a NE (On the nose of the Eastern most point of the hill) and Southerly launch (At the highest point of the track) on the Eastern Hill. In a strong Southerly be careful not to be blown too far North as it could be possible to fly over the border which would cause an incident!

name: Javorovy
desc:
From ski-slope just below the Javorovy Chata.
It is wide enough to put 3 gliders at the same time.
Getting to takeoff: zake ski-lift (9-17 on round hours, 60KC, buy ticket directly from the operator on the platform, cash only, no credit cards, no english speaking personnel).
After arriving to the top, take the wide footpath to the right. Follow it and before going up the slope towards Chata take the small footpath to the right in the forest, and walk 5min until you arrive on a big skislope with Chata and antenna visible on the top. Alternatively, you can alsdo pass Chata and then descend to the launching area. be careful with westerlies. If on the landing it is windy and on takeoff calm - the takeoff will be on leeward side. Expect turbulence just after the takeoff, and may be better reconsider flying at all on that day.

name: Lovos
desc:
Kuzelovity kopec s prudkym sklonem svahu. Misto pro starty je travnate s kameny, v okoli stromy. Rizikovy start. Pozor na zvlastnosti obtekani kuzelove hory vetrem! Prevyseni 350 m.

Be careful about the wind direction 'cause sometimes (better to say manytimes) it looks good but above the trees it will be very different. Both wind direction and velocity. Is good to climb up the transmitter to check it. Nothing special - it is friendly area. Just the wind direction was mentioned in the start specification

name: Klinovec
desc:
Best take off on Klinovec is the steepest slope (U Zabityho) leading to the NE side of the hill.

This slope is widest and is not crossed by any cable-lift. If something goes wrong you just follow the slope to the landing place.

1225 meters above sea As with any 'slope' take-off - watch out for the real direction of the wind, which might be quite different from what you feel on the ground. 

Just in front of the take of there are 3 wind-mills.

name: Penensky Tynec
desc:
On the airport of Panensky Tynec there is commercially operated towing device. 

Towing is usually operational during fridays and weekends in summer time - depending on weather conditions. It is possible to call Mistral Paragliding to arrange it to be operational even in week days if there is enough of pilots to come.

name: Tegelberg - Allgaeu
desc:
Upper takeoff direction NW (besides the cablecar mountain station): Mostly a lot of pilots - you have to queue already prepared for take-off. This can cause quite a lot of sweat. Often wonderful smooth flights with still good thermals in the late afternoon - about 5 pm.
In case of constant wind from NE experienced pilots can also take off to NE over a ramp - 
but first ask one of the locals/tandem pilots if it is safe enough!!

lower takeoff (picture 2 & 3)is a bit of a hike from the top, but easy set up.  Lower take off is a narrow chute and winds will rotate in there. Watch the winds comming up carefully as there is a rock wall on right side that can cause pain. Gets cloudy quick, rain and fog settle in fast as well.

name: Oppenau Zuflucht/Rossbühl/Sandkopf
desc:
Large takeoff situated at the black forest's "main ridge" and thus thermally very reliable. The site also serves as the primary LZ.

Use the northern half for takeoffs, and the southern part for landing. South wind is flyable but dangerous when starting.
Strong wind from North-West may be also dangerous all around the takeoff: very bumpy.

name: Hochblauen Nord
desc:
Nord takeoff sites (NNW-NNE)on top of the mountain. The N Site is litte smaler but also feasable with a tandem. German pilots need a B-Licence to fly here because its a longer way to the landing field. 
Both sites are also very good for hanggliders. West wind is flyable but dangerous when starting. East winds are very dangerous.
No starts on winds over 25 km/h.

desc: Easy takeoff in a forest clearing Too much northern wind.

desc:
NW only.

Verbose 4h+ briefing mandatory due to the site's delicate location and the hard LZs south of the Neckar. If you stay in Heidelberg just for a couple days, chances are you won't get to fly here. 

This restriction was necessary to allow flying above one of the world's most famous castles in the first place, so please respect it and visit the club's website to arrange for a briefing. Straight NW only.

Very wide, but steep and short takeoff facing WSW. 
Also works with south SSW to some degree, but NW is dangerous.

The NE takeoff has special rules, see website if you wish to fly there. See https://www.schwarzwaldgeier.de/wetterstation-merkur/ for the current situation.

Local wind is often a good deal stronger than meteo wind. Perfect groundhandling skills are a must.

toplanding is best on the vast meadow about 200m to the right of takeoff just need to get the weather right: from east to southsoutheast; northeast is a nogo.

name: Gräfenthal
desc:
No car autorised, only park at landing. Controlled flying place, no smoking, no cars in forest, respect the schedules of takeoff (3 different periods, Winter/Spring/Summer).

Possible takeoff under winds of NO, or if the wind comes from left (ONO-wind of Grafenthal), but not good if it comes from right-hand side (East -wind of Zopten), you can check all winds-intakes from Takeoff. Very unfavourable East wind

name: Ascheloh-Hermannsweg
desc:
cleared area in the forest, LZ out of view.


Das GelÃ¤nde Ascheloh Hermannsweg wurde mit viel Arbeitseinsatz erschlossen und unterhalten. Der Startplatz kann nur zu FuÃŸ erreicht werden und liegt in einer Waldschneise am Kamm des Teutoburger Waldes. ACHTUNG: Nicht bei Seitenwind starten. Starke Turbulenzen! Startbare Windrichtungen sind W-SW. Ideal ist WSW. Gelandet wird im unteren Teil auf der Wiese im Hangauslauf auf dem Ãœbungshang der Flugschule Bielefeld. GelÃ¤ndehalter des StartgelÃ¤ndes ist die Flugschule Werther-Westfalen (Udo Wilhelm). Starts dÃ¼rfen nur nach Zustimmung von Udo Willhelm durchgefÃ¼hrt werden once you are airborne, the clearing will appear much smaller than from the ground ;)

check windmills in the distance for wind direction, even with a SW or W it might seem to be WSW when standing in the clearing. expect turbulence at TO if the wind isn't blowing straight into the clearing.

desc:
Jenzig is a site barely 10 min from downtown Jena and its tallest 'mountain'. Best site of the local club 'dgfc-jena', this orientation is northwest. Great site for soaring as well as thermalling - winter and summer.
Do not consider this site if you are not absolutely certain of your take-off skills - you only have four steps and limited space on either side!

name: Leuchtenburg
desc:
a small hill just in front of the Leuchtenburg - a castle situated above the town of Kahla.
the takeoff is a nice grassy plateau inclined towards southwest, the takeoff direction, but it drops of steeply - enough room to start your wing comfortably even in nil wind though!
beware of winds coming from southerly directions: at the landing zone you will almost certainly encounter shear winds and rotor. watch out for southerly winds! (see above)

name: Laucha
desc: takeoff at the edge of the plateau where the little airport is located. Very easy takeoff - superb soaring and thermalling. winds can be a lot stronger than predicted on the net - this was a record site for 24h constant sailplane flying

Exit Grevenbroich-Kapellen, direction Kapellen, then exit left inside a turn, to the rocket station. Attention, arriving from the south on A46 you just have to go straigth after the motorway exit, then immediately left inside the right-turn.

Ask locals for basic advice about the terrain, even if you are a very experenced mountain pilot. Never fly behind the dunes. If there is white tops on the waves (strong wind) and no pilots flying, maybe you should go for a beer in town an check out the girls (or boys) inthere...

name: La Silla (The Chair)
desc:
It is a broad flat mountain top, and it is a point of convergence of thermals from different directions. It is better to place a few windsocks in different points of the take-off and at the centre and only take off when a consistent cycle comes in. The cycles are short and come every 15 or 20 minutes.

[ES] Se debe alquilar camioneta o motocicleta para acercarse al despegue de ahi se camina 25 minutos hasta llegar al despegue, esta es una explanada amplia pero con 3 puntos de convergencias de termicas por lo que se coloca mangas de viento al filo del despegue y en el centro y cuando las dos apuntan al mismo lado se puede despegar, los ciclos suelen ser cortos y separados entre si con 15 o 20 minutos. When the Pacific wind (west) sets in, gusts of over 30 km/h may occur. We recommend caution when landing

[ES] Al entrar el viento del pacifico pueden producirse rafagas de mas de 30 km/h por lo que recomendamos precaucion al aterrizar

name: Paldiski
desc: Take off is here 59.378448,24.036923 Launch is quite simple with modarate wind and a bit more challenging with more then 8 m/s. In winter time consider to fly with winds 1-2 m/s less. Currently no windstation around.

name: Turisalu
desc:
It is near second parking (not official) a bit to the right (see the GPS data).
Launch is triky because you inflate a wing in the lee. Better to use A and B riser technique if you know how. Take off only if you are sure to soar the cliff otherwise it would be difficult to find landing down. Do not launch with wind exeeding 7-8 m/s!

name: Alajõe
desc: 59.0075, 27.4432 is the TO point. Naturally you may TO from anywhere you can on the dune or down under from the beach if the wind is strong. It is not huge, approx glider high but soarable in summer with wind starting from 6 m/s. Nice playground for low and speedy flying but trees are always near so not really a Wagga place.

name: Kakumäe
desc: TO is somewhere this point 59.4481, 24.6083. The spot is not so commonly used because it faces same direction as Tabasalu. But it can be usefull if the wind is stronger then 6 m/s what make launch at Tabasalu tricky and here you may fly more or less calm. By ware trees are near.

name: Tehumardi

name: Galala 1 Ain soukhna
desc:
865 meter in front of red sea
clear no sharp rocks
you have to be familiar with cliffs take off

P3 pilot requerd

name: Organya
desc:
Ample site to take off. Worlwide known acro site. Is a place where thermals can be real strong on hot days, so be careful in the hot hours of the afternoon.  Also when the conditions are strong, care must be taken not to fall off to the back of the mountain since there's venturi effect there which accelerates the wind and also in the ridges to the east. A good rule of thumb will be not go northern past the antennas on the top unless you have quite a lot of altitude above them. So if the conditions are strong the best is to stay well on the face of the mountain. Landing options are not appealing in case one can't return to the valley and land north. Going down is easy, just fly south above the village and soon you'll get into the descendence. It's called the 'magic mountain' for a reason ;)
Also keep an eye for too much cloud development. The weather can change rather quickly. The pre-storm gusts can be dangerous.

name: Algodonales - ALL launches
desc:
Different launches for different wind directions:
- Levante: huge! E to S possible; Toplanding possible. 
- Poniente: wide
- Norte: small: you'll pass it when going to 'Levante'. http://www.civalgodonales.com/meteo

name: Otivar
desc:
Nice clear slope, with enough room for 2 gliders to launch at same time.  

Tricky top landing because of cables directly behind, but can be done if thermals are not kicking right over launch. Do not fly if the upper winds are moving west, even if the wind is coming up the slope.  This will often turn into a very rough convergence, that will kick you around like a beach ball.

name: Castejon de Sos - Liri
desc:
There's taxi services in the local paragliding shops in CastejÃ³n. Usually around 10â‚¬ to go to the top. It's not recommended to go up by car, but it's doable, since it's a 4x4 track. As a high mountain zone, the weather can develop quickly so it's good to keep an eye on the conditions and cloud development.
It's also good to keep the radio on the frequency of the schools, they usually report the conditions.

name: Piedrahita -Pena Negra
desc: * Altitude: 1.909 metres (6204 feet) ASL * Top to bottom height: 900 metres (2925 feet) * Orientation: NW Access Tarmac road linking Piedrahita to the Pena Negra pass. On strong eastely forcasts it often appears fine at take off. This is shielding form the mountains, and out in the valley the wind can be strong and turbulent.

name: Lanzarote -Famara (Tequise) HG-TO
desc: Of course -if the wind speed is ok- PG's can also takeoff (and land here)

name: Segunda Maria  - Berga
desc:
Takeoff faces South-South-West.
Is quite abrupt so in strong weather breeze can become quite vertical. In this case it is best recommended for experienced fliers.
In high summer it may become a thermal.
At any other time, no problem at all. Beware of strong winds from the West! Also beware when wind comes from the East, the windsocks may give a false head on breeze reading!

name: Rasos de Paguera
desc: Leave the car in the parking and 30 minutes walk up to the summit.

name: Arcones
desc: Wide takeoff. Strong winds closed 14:00

name: Pedro Bernardo
desc: The predominant take-off is the West facing one, thus it has been accommodated accordingly. It's very spacious and easy. There is a fountain for water and shade where you can rest. It has a large patch of fake grass for taking off and this makes inflating the canopy all the easier. Cars are left near by and there is room for plenty of them. It has the possibility of top landing

name: Tenerife - Taucho
desc:
One of the most frequented sites on Tenerife.
Good access by car. Parking near the start.
Very large space on the mountain, no grass, carpets for takeoff Do not fly if local pilots are on the ground.
Check for hard left or right wind on the start.
Try to land fast if you see white waves on the sea.

Taucho is in the lee side of the Tenerife Island. Best flying is when the main wind to the island is NE. 80% of the year wind direction is NE. 

This gives SW lee side winds on the start and landing and good thermal conditions with a possibility to thermal the 25 km length  of SW side of Island.

Check the weather on:
http://www.aemet.es/es/eltiempo/prediccion/modelosnumericos/hirlam005?opc2=coo&opc3=vi
zoom in on AEMET for details.

Conditions on the start can check on:
http://www.windguru.cz/ru/index.php?sc=438711
!! Need to see the WRF 9Km !! 
!!! Not the GFS 27Km !!!

name: Cenes de la Vega (Granada)
desc:
Large and easy for all kind of pilots
Orientation from SW to NW.
Top-landing possible Don't fly with N wind, very turbulent!

name: Siete Pilillas -Pegalajar -Jaen -Mancha Real
desc: very nicely prepared launch. The mountain forms a 'venturi', so if the wind is a bit strong, it is very strong on take off.

name: Ager
desc:
There are 4 takeoffs:

lowest take off is RAUDORAL.
Recently created, it allows take off without going all the way up to the top of the Montsec.Its a clean fairly steep takeoff that take a single paralider (while another prepares). It is faced South and is the first take off that comes the breeze while the slope is heated. BEWARE OF EAST WIND when we do not recommend use. Height to the Camping landing field: 500 m.
GPS: 31T 312693, 4656422

- GABRIELO.
It is a take off with a spacious zone to put the hang gliders and paragliders. We take off only for one point, and we should look all the streamers, because it is a technical take off. It is South faced, and not suitable with West winds. It is a good take off when the North wind on the top of Montsec. Height to Ager: 550m.
GPS: 31T 315102, 4655761

MAIN TOP TAKE OFF COLL D'ARES.
It is very big and clear take off. It has a few streamers to show the wind. It is South faced, but it allows to take off with West winds. If there is East wind, it is slightly in rotor. In an east it's better to continue to the Sant Alis take off. The height to Ager is 960 m. 
GPS: 31T 313555 , 4657599

- SANT ALIS.
It is geodesic vertex. It offers an incredible view: The Montseny, Moncayo, Guara mountain range, Pyrenees from Navarra to Girona, Montserrat, Monte Caro, Prades and Montsant mountain range. The take off is just on the left and in front of the firewatch cabin. It is South-East faced. Don't use with West winds. The height to Ager is 1050 m.
GPS: 31T 315237, 4656809 Beware of the East wind!
http://www.meteo.cat

 South slopes are very turbulent with east wind and in south take off zone the wind seems like it comes strong from that direction, but it's a rotor a dangerous trap for experienced pilots.Â¡Go and fly from the east take off zone!
there you are going to have perfect conditions.

Pretty rough, take off.  And we are not allowed to clean it up.  Part of the mountain which is protected. Winds can pick up late afternoon rather quickly.  Also near spring and summer, check if breeze is not kicking in from the back.   In 15 minutes you could be flying in the lee without knowing.  
Call us to make sure the flying is safe :
0034 606 781 180, Nick

name: loarre
desc:
S , SW (1275 m agl)
There's a forest trail/broken road turning to the left just before arriving to the castle. It can be done with a normal car without problems but avoiding the holes on the pavement. Not possible to flight when wind is N.
Inspect landing zone first. It's a little bit small. But there are bigger fields around to choose. (Care has to be taken not to damage the crops).

There's quite a number of power lines. So it's good to keep an eye on them, specially below the castle.

name: Montseny - Turó de l Home
desc:
-Altitude: 1,700 m. 

-Altitude: 1400 m. 

Guidance: SO. and S. 

Low-finesse: 5.5. 

-Access: a road paved with the intermediate section of track, but in good condition. 

-Off, flight, landing: progressive and off easy, comprehensive and grass. Flight thermal and dynamic throughout their side, then a 7-km long glide. (power line in half). Landing better Mosqueroles fields, with some alternative, should check beforehand. 

Conditions favorable winds and breezes loose component S. 

-Plan: S.G.E., Series L, No. 364, E / 1:50.000. Spanish pilots prefer the winter season to fly here, because of heavy wind and rocky thermals in summer.

name: Cura
