name: Rosbeigh
desc:
Take off just above the beach at 250m just in front of the car parking area.
There is a second take off 50metres below the top for when the wind is more than 20km/hour. Wind compression at the top launch area shows 10km/hr more than the actual wind.  For a lighter wind launch then go 50 metres below the top take off (below the wire) where there is an area which has been cleared for launching  2-3 gliders.  Wind speed here is the actual wind speed.

name: Lough Bray
desc:
You can take off right on top at the hill.
 53.188696, -6.309538 Avoid take-off with SE wind - take-off site will experience rotor from the spur between the two corrie lake bowls

name: Monavullagh
desc: Several take off areas along the top. Sometimes a 'valley effect' can be felt on landing, especially with a stiff SW wind.

name: The Vee
desc: From the top of 'Sugarloaf' mountain. there is also a take off area a little below the top if the wind is too stiff on top. Mountain area and weather can change fast.

name: Knockanaffrin
desc: Several. All have to be walked up to. Mountain, can be a little turbulent.

name: Knocknarea
desc: Choose suitable take-off spot- depends of the wind direction

name: Bray Head
desc: from Bray Head

name: Minaun, Achill Island
desc: quite nice and easy

name: Seefin NE (Co.Kerry)
desc: 52deg 3.55'N 9deg 53.9'W Take off is on the low ridge below the main mountain. NorthEast direction. You may have to walk up a bit of the way as the track has been eroded over the winter months. Now only a good 4X4 will get you to the take-off area. Sometimes the windspeed increases without warning. If so then it should be ok to top land on the large flat area behind the take-off. If wind goes Easterly then stop flying as there will be rotor from the hill beside the lake to the east. Instead leave and go to Ballaghasheen Gap for more flying.

name: Trawalua Strand
desc: Dunes gusty winds

name: Clara
desc: Take off at the top, but you must walk up. Wind can gain strength quickly in this part of Ireland.  Always be prepared to use the speed bar.

name: Gneeves NE
desc:
The take-off is located 100 metres in front of some wind turbines.
Park beside the wind turbine directly behind the launch area. Beware of a sudden increase in wind speed.
Beware of rotor if the wind turns North-Northwest direction. The flight will become very bumpy.

name: Mweelin
desc:
Take-off anywhere in the bowl that faces directly into the wind.
Take-off by the gate on top is the best place as the better house thermal is out in front of here. the site experiences rotor in the bowl when the wind comes from the Southeast/East.

Beware the wind strength increasing suddenly, especially when flying in a southerly as landing options behind the gulley are going to be bad.

name: Dingle Bowl
desc:
Take-off into the southerly facing bowl.
There is a 5 minute walk to take off if you have a 4x4.  Otherwise it is a 20 minute walk from the Connor Pass Car Park. Sometimes the wind strength increases without warning.  Watch for wind on the water out in Dingle Bay to the south.
Site is sometimes affected by the westerly sea breeze.

name: Caherdaniel - Cahernageeha Mtn.
desc: Launch in a suitable area at the top of the hill. There is often a sheet of white clouds on top of the hill.

name: Ballyvaldon beach
desc: 52.463287,-6.296976 No turbulence, rotor, or other similar phenomenon.

name: Ballaghasheen Gap
desc:
Take off 100m due south of the road at the top of the Gap. Just climb up for about 4-5 minutes at most and lay out.
You can launch for a north, northeast or east from this place. The wind may increase quickly due to the 'col' effect and wind compression at the end of this valley.

name: Devils' Ladder  (Carrauntoohill Mtn)
desc:
again.....
The wind at take off is always at least 10-15km stronger than the forecasted wind.
The temperature is also 10 deg.C less than the valley floor (its very cold always)

name: Mullaghmesha Mtn. (W)
desc: There is a track to the top but it is not always passable for cars due to grass on the track. extra strong winds may build up while flying.

name: Musheramore (W)
desc: On top only.  45 minute walk up (minimum) for Pg Beware a sudden increase in wind speed.

name: Mt.Gabriel
desc:
Follow the tarmac road up to the Satellite domes. There are no marked launch areas.
Large tufts of grass everywhere.
Find a suitable place to launch facing into the wind. Site takes NE, SE, W-NW  only. Beware strong winds at the top.......and winds increasing rapidly....at any time.

name: Dunworly Bay
desc:
In the front Garden of the Yellow House... near the co-ordinates for the Take off for northwest winds.  This Launching area is small here....but very convenient.

If the wind is more Northerly, then follow the track, through the Gate behind the house, and into the field at the end.
This is also used as a launch area. The wind is usually Lighter here than forecast elsewhere.
It is usually similar to 'Cork Airport' current weather reports.

name: Old Head of Kinsale (Cork)
desc:
Take off beside the road on the west side of the peninsula
Do not launch from the cliff beside the gates to the Golf Club! (Danger of death... or serious injury at the very least.

Note: There is no take off area on the Easterly side. Extreme wind.  do not get blown over the back.
The normal wind is double what the current 'Cork Airport Weather report' indicates...
see www.xcweather.co.uk

You will certainly land in the sea.
If the wind turns to the northwest, then you will be unable to return to your starting place or the top landing field.

name: Aconeera or Cnoc Mordain
desc: Find suitable grassy, clean of rocks spot on the slopes of the massive. Increasing wind speed

name: Benglenesky
desc: Few possible take off spots- from the summit to lower elevation of Mount. Little tough hiking- rough territory. As usual in the mountains- Increasing wind speed mostly.

name: Maumturk Mts
desc: Various take off options: from the summit to lower elevations. Plenty off clear from rocks spots sufficient for launching. Part of hiking is on the trail- about 200- 300 meters before chapel Travers the slope to chosen take off spot. Typical coastal mountain weather patterns - be alert of strong wind and suddenly unexpected lowering cloud base- coastal fog, appearing fog Mist from the ocean below the peaks.

name: Croagh Patrick
desc:
Actually current location is not perfect- fully covered by sharp stones spot on summit create no comfortable, difficult and unsafe for the glider take-off. Commonly used take-off's sites to North West are on the east shoulder of Croagh Patrick. Take-off to West South or South-West are on Ben Goram- West shoulder of Croagh Patrick.
Detailed location will be provided as soon as possible.
Additional information you can get from local pilots. Increasing wind speed.

name: Croaghmoyle
desc: On the top beside towers.Find suitable  grassy spot clean of rocks. Increasing wind speed.

name: Nephin
desc: Variety of take-off spots- from lower elevation of massive slops to the summit.

name: Gleninagh Mt.
desc: Any clean of rocks grassy slopes face to N-E. Increasing wind speed, sudden low cloud base development.

name: Inchadoney
desc:
There is a nice gently sloping field on top....sometimes with young cattle there, but they are only curious and move away when gliders are flown. check out a webcam from the hotel, overlooking the beach, before you go.
http://www.onitsurf.com/surf-cameras/inchydoney-surf-camera.html

name: Knockgour / Allihies
desc:
Launch from near the masts (there is a track to the top to access the radio masts) .  Strong compression on the hill in W wind, often flyable in the evening as the sea breeze dies away.
Frequently mountain is in cloud! Frequently blown out, and the hilltop is frequently in cloud.

name: Mullaghanish
desc:
the top is not suitable for take off....  proceed far enough down the appropriate side for take off.

note, the south take off is on a spine that goes out west from the top of the mountain. and it looks onto the same bowl as the SW take off.

name: Arra
desc: Near car park Strong wind

name: Devil's Bit Mountain
desc: Various take-off spots along the slopes. Don't take-off from the spot with the cross- strong turbulence. Increasing wind speed

name: Mushera (N)
desc:
Follow the forestry road up the hill (across the road from the Car Parking area). It is no more than a 10 minute walk.
Launch anywhere after the road ends.
In high winds it is possible to launch from a small ridge (knob) 20m below the roadway.  If you decide to launch here, then there expect very strong winds at top of hill level.... stay well out in front. It can be very windy here.

name: West Carpark take off  Mt. Leinster
desc: Just near parking lot wind speed increase, coastal fog appearing.

name: Loughcrillan RTE Transmitter
desc: Flat grassy area in front and to the right of the RTE Transmitter.There is a road to the gates of the transmitter and then a dirt road from there on running across the top of the ridge.Beautiful view of the mountains and the sea beyond and the hill can be climbed further above 200 m for a higher takeoff. None

name: Lachta
desc: You need to hike- if wind is strong not need to go to summit- half or 3/4 elevation will be good enough to take off and soar above massive. In the case of week wind is better to hike to summit- about 40 min. hike Unknown yet.

name: Sky Road
desc: Right beside parking lot. Increasing wind speed.

name: Ballyelly
desc: Nice grassy big spot on the top and few others bellow top. Increasing wind sped.

name: Silver Strand
desc: Site not recommended for beginner pilots- rather for some pilots with at least intermediate skills. Take-off can be difficult- you need to find the right spot to inflate your wing to avoid rotor from the cliff (in strong wind). In my experience: in wind from WS-W is the best way to inflate the wing on westerly site of the cliff and walk to the age of the cliff. In the case of the wind from S- SE the best way is to do it on the east wing of the cliff and do the same way. Good luck! Strong wind.

name: Abbey Hill
desc: Big grassy gentle slope. Increasing wind speed.

name: Inch Beach - This site is currently CLOSED to all Flying
desc:
SITE CLOSED - NO FLYING HERE

Take off in the field as shown beware strong winds if you can get high above the site.

Webcam looking southwest is here....
http://www.onitsurf.com/inch_surf_cam.html

name: Knocknakilton
desc:
There is a very large open area usually cleared of turf on top to park in...
All cars etc will make it up the track (in 2012)

name: Glengarriff
desc: The take off are is free of trees etc and flat with a small cliff edge.

name: Gneeves (E)
desc: A narrow take off area between mature Christmas Trees

name: Knocknakilla    -   NW-N
desc:
Difficult take off area alongside the road, either below or above it. flying here really only happens when winds are too strong on the higher local sites.
Take care when you get altitude as the wind strength may increase.

name: Croagh Patrick East Site
desc: Top of east shoulder of Croagh Patrick or slope below. Increasing wind speed.

name: Ben Goram
desc: Find suitable spot on the summit or the slopes.

name: Silvermine Mts.
desc: Plenty of options on grassy slopes or summit of the mount. Increasing wind speed.

name: Slivecarran
desc: Dependable of wind direction- plenty of grassy spots for take-off

name: Slievecarran North
desc: Any suitable clean of rocks grassy spots Increasing wind speed and direction rapid change

name: Gleninagh Mt. lower launch
desc: Grassy clean of rocks field Increasing wind speed and coastal fog

name: Shannakeela Mt.
desc: Find suitable clean of rocks grassy fields on the slopes of the mount. Low cloud base coastal fog appearing suddenly, increasing wind speed.

name: Redeemed Siner
desc: Find suitable, clean of rocks grassy fields on the slopes of the mount. Low cloud base coastal fog appearing and increasing wind speed.

name: Gleninagh North
desc: Grassy field Increasing wind speed and coastal fog appearing.

name: Breanlee (Hydro Road)
desc:
NOTICE:  Flying here is now SUSPENDED until a suitable agreement has been reached with the local landowners to use the site.
Walking up the track is still allowed.

Take off above the track just after the locked gate. Winds may increase suddenly in these mountains.
wind at the top is usually quite strong.

name: Gap of Dunloe
desc:
500m after Kate Kearneys Cottage is a Walking track up the Reeks ridge.
(if you reach the bridge then you have missed the track)
Follow this to the single tall tree that you can see on the crest of the ridge.
take off near this tree.

It is at least 30mins from the bottom of the track to the take off area (walking).
There is no access for vehicles to the take off area. Beware of winds increasing suddenly in this part of the southwest of ireland.
The wind up the Gap of Dunloe will be stronger than you expect it to be.

name: Gougane Barra
desc:
Take off is located on the hill across the lake, behind the church.
Take the road from the pub and go in an anti-clockwise direction around the lake... follow the track up around the side of the ridge and behind...  climb up here as it is easiest.
It will take you about 45-60 minutes to get to a suitable take off area on the top. The better launch areas are further to the southwest.

name: Skellig Michael
desc:
Take off from CHRIST's SEAT (the grassy knoll between the South peak (Hermitage) and the Monastery peak.
NE-N-NW
or 
SE (keep left of take off ONLY -see flight regulation) High winds from the Atlantic.

name: Parkana
desc:
Take off at the top of the track off the public road.

take off is also possible from the road in places.

name: Madman's Seat
desc:
South-East of the Madmans Seat is the knob of a hill to take off from. It is small and a bit rocky.
You will have to walk up (circa 20 mins) from the Madman's Seat.
HG's could possibly get away from the road as it goes down the south side into the Black Valley. Stronger winds blow through the Gap and this area should be avoided for flying.

name: Minister's Fall (Tomies Wood)
desc:
Note: Launching a glider ('Flying from') the Killarney National Park is not permitted by the rules of the park.... however this does not exclude flying above the park.

Talk off area is a clear field, at the far end of the Tomies Wood walking track.
(there is a long 1 hour walk (4km) from the car to the take off area, along a well maintained off road track.
The take off looks out over Lough Leane to the North and East Watch the surface of the lake for indications for an increase in wind.
There is a much bigger mountain behind the take off place and the winds are 10km per hour faster at the top, usually.

name: Triskbeg (Kerry Head)
desc: Take off Near the structure on top of the hill. Kerry Head is a very windy place.

name: Maulin Mtn (Kerry Head
desc: Flight is on the NE side of the hill.

name: Kerry Head (West)
desc:
Take off on the ridge between the TWO Promontory Forts.
It is about 60 metres down to the ocean. Kerry Head is Notorious for High Winds

name: Kerry Head (NW-N)
desc: It is about 60 metres down to the ocean. Kerry Head is Notorious for High Winds

name: Kerry Head (Northeast)
desc: Kerry Head is Notorious for High Winds

name: Ballyheigue
desc: take off near the roadside.

name: Mweelin N-E
desc:
Walk north of the Mweelin (south) launch area.
The take off is well overgrown and cliff like..take care

name: Sillaherdane
desc:
Walk up to take off via the track to the windfarm.
there is an older track a little closer to the take off.

name: Knockboy (Caoinkeen)
desc:
Its a good walk in and up (2km).
take off high up so that you can know the real wind.

name: Priest's Leap
desc:
Take off near the public road.
Fly only in a south/southeast wind.

name: Caum
desc: nice open field on top of the hill.

name: Stookeen
desc:
You have to take off East of the fence.
Do not walk on the land along the top of the ridge....and he gets very upset

DO NOT take off above the Lake..the farmer gets very angry.

name: Top of Bealach (Millstreet)
desc: The take off is in a field beside the road

name: Rossacroo
desc: The take off area is Rocky. Find a suitable area to please yourself.

name: The Paps
desc:
Take off from either of the two peaks

For southwest launch, go 1km south of the peaks.

name: The Paps (Southwest site)
desc: Take off from the top of the spine overlooking the Clydagh River valley.

name: Knocknabro
desc:
Take off is from the Peak beside the Paps mtns.
its a long way up.

name: Knocknagowan
desc:
Rocky open mountain... but there are nice areas in between the rocks.
it is a very long walk up.

name: Killeen
desc:
The take off areas are very rocky with some suitable areas for laying out a glider.  
Be careful

name: Coolcurtoga
desc:
This is a cliff site.
take care on launch.

This site can also be flown on the west side and this is the end of the Killeen site.

name: Crohane
desc: Take off from the very top.  Walk up from the landing field....there is a farmers track... ask permission to go on the land from the cottage beside the landing field.  The man is very nice.

name: Torc
desc:
Located on the hill top overlooking Muckross Lake.
Do not fly out beyond the first lake as you will be entering controlled airspace.

name: Rosbeigh Dunes
desc: Take off from the beach

name: Bentee
desc: Take off from the peak.

name: Aghatubride
desc: There is a track up to the top of the mountain, but the gate is usually locked.

name: Knockavahaun
desc:
East and west take offs can be from the track on the way to the peak.
You have to go all the way to the top for the southerly site.

name: Coomduff
desc: The site is rocky.

name: Kilkeaveragh
desc: There is a tarmac road to the take off area near the transmitters.

name: Coonanaspig
desc: This is a cliff launch.

name: Foilnageragh
desc: This is a cliff site.

name: Connor Pass
desc:
Take off near the Public parking area at the top of the pass.
The take off is very steep.
beware northwesterly winds at the take off as there may be rotor from Mt.Brandon.

name: Croagh Sceirde
desc: On top of the hill....lots of space It can get quite windy on the Dingle Peninsula.

name: The Hags' Teeth
desc:
Be prepared for a long walk up a steep slope.
best approached from Lisleibane car park. Beware high winds at the upper level of the top of the mtn.

It is 10deg.C colder up on top than in the valley.

name: The Windy Gap
desc: Avoid the top of the Gap (its usually windy). High wind around the Gap.

name: BallyMac.@Seven Heads Bay
desc:
Take off beside the walking track down to the sea.
This is a coastal cliff site with NO bottom landing.

name: Coolim Cliffs @ Seven HEads Bay
desc: Difficult take off at the edge of a steep cliff.

name: Shehy Mtn
desc: Anywhere on top......but remember Killarney NP law forbids launching within the park boundaries. Look at lake surface for wind direction & strength.

desc: The site is great for Training, GH, and beginners. Parking good. there is also a spring where people come for miles to get water.

Landing in Water

Use your head lads, Fly Safe!

desc: ridge - windspeed > 15kmh requires for soaring Winddrection:  260-320 / speed: 15-30kmh > requires good reverse launch technique!

name: Balleira Beach
desc:
WNW
Be careful not to be pulled back over the bushes into the car park. Inflate and walk your way as high as possible giving the best chance to get round the corner high enough to lift above the cliffs. The launch area has recently been extended. 10-12mph WNW works best at this site.

desc: NW

name: Peel Hill
desc:
NW     
Warning – this site is unsuitable for inexperienced pilots. Ideally you will have at least 50 hours post Club Pilot, be competent in ground handling and have recent flight currency. You will need to be able to quickly recognise diminishing lift and make timely, accurate and safe landing decisions.
It is recommended that you do not use this site if conditions are light or marginal.

name: Sartfell NW
desc: NW

name: Port Erin beach
desc: Small take off area beteen promenade road and cliff

name: Andreas Airfield (Paramotor)
desc: Use runways/hard surfaces only. The fields surrounding are active crops and part of the agreement of flying here is that they are NOT to be used for take off or landings.

name: Tower Hill (Kamshet)
desc:
Skill level: Advanced pilots, P2 or P1 with instructor
Conditions: Dynamic, Thermic, Thermodynamic Nothing major. Its good to have a few local pilots for company.

name: Shelar Site
desc:
Launch Elevation: 720 mt MSL
Skill level: Advanced pilots, P2 or P1 with instructor
Winds: W-NW
Conditions: Dynamic, Thermic, Thermodynamic
Season: February to May Wind: www.windfinder.com/forecast/shelar_site

name: Billing - Bir
desc:
15.3 km from Bir Tibetan Colony (taxi stand). (INR 700 as of 2018.)

A trail frequented by trekkers starts above the Colony, only about 4 km:
www.youtube.com/watch?v=d3ADZ9fZFdE :/

name: Arambol
desc: Walk along the beach north from Arambol. You pass the lakeside beach which is one of the landing zones. Cross the beach and climb the hill one the other side. There are numerous paths to the plateau on the top. There are many areas to launch from depending on the conditions. The launches can be a little difficult as the top is flat and you launch over a vertical cliff. Best not to mess it up. You can also walk right round the headland to Querim/Keri Beach which is also accessible by car. There are tracks to the top from there as well. Take care when cliff launching in stronger winds as there can be rotor behind take off. Also watch out for turbulence over larger rocks and trees when low flying.

name: Harisson\'s Folly
desc: Harison's Folley. Motorable access. Nearly 1000 ft heigh. Lots of flat ground for top landing even for student pilots. Flyable with westerly winds.Great

name: Nandi Hills
desc:
There are five launch sites that takes winds from S-SE-SW-N-NE-NW.
South launch is a cliff launch & the surface is rocky.
SE launch site is a large grassy slope.
SW launch site is a tight launch.
NE launch site is grassy with rocky outcrops.
NW launch site is located on the adjoining hill called Nandi-2.It is a vast grassy,gentle slope.This site is toplandable.
More info on www.flynandi.com Flying season:Oct-May. Fly conservatively... fly safe. Please choose the conditions to match your skill level. Weather website links available on our website www.flynandi.com .

name: Pawna (Pavna)
desc:
Drivable Takeoff. 2 minute walk down from where you park your car. Ample space for two simultaneous takeoffs. 
wind direction for perfect takeoff is 270Â° but anywhere from 255Â° to 280Â° is acceptable.

name: Black Beauty
desc: Takeoff is at 450 feet facing NNW. None

name: Twin Rock
desc: Multiple takeoff spots between 200 to 700 feet

name: Rishikesh - Kunjapuri
desc: Take a taxi from Rishikesh +45 minutes up to a temple behind Rishikesh called Kunjapuri. The Take off is either on the last bend of the road before you reach the temple, or take a short 200m walk down to the left and take off on a small pimple like hill. Take off is tricky with some scrub to catch your lines. During Monsoon clouds can build up very quickly. be careful of this.

name: Yelagiri
desc:
Yelagiri launch site is 500m a.g.l & the ridge is 8kms long. Has launch sites for NW,SW & SE wind directions.
Visit www.yasa.co.in, for more info. SW(June,July,Aug) & NE(Dec,Jan) monsoon season to be avoided.

name: Munnar
desc:
This site is in Munnar, a Hill station in Kerala. Thermalling & Soaring is possible here
Favorable winds are south west, South & SSE

name: Pavagadh
desc:
Site elevation: 644m ASL
Facing: East
GPS Co-ordinates (UTM):
43 Q 347318 m E 2485715 m N

name: Vagamon - Summer Sands
desc:
Grass land East is also flyable but crossed and very 
turbulent.

name: Saputara
desc: Saputara is a plateau, takeoff is easily reachable by car. There are many takeoff locations to select from depending on the wind direction. It is at about 650M

name: Varkala Beach
desc: From the helipad sometimes it gets really bad

name: Yelagiri (Ramakrishna)
desc:
Source: http://www.yasa.co.in/YPC/About_Yela.html

Name: Ramakrishna
Orientation: WSW/WNW
Altitude AGL: 600m

name: Hallan
desc: Nice TO around noon when wind valley starts

name: Vagamon - Main Ridge
desc: The takeoff is located in a place known as 'Suicide Point'. Drive up to take-off. Ridge of about 10 km in length 3000 ft up.

name: Arnala Beach
desc: During high tide winds are a bit strong - good for power kiting but not for paragliding.

name: Aanganay Hill
desc: Chakung West Sikkim: 3 hours from Gangtok/ Siliguri and 45 minutes from Jorethang. Chakung is a serene hill top village with spectacular views of the mountains. From the Rangeet valley the road quickly climbs to alpine forests towards the take off point. The dawn and dusks from Aanganay hill (take off point) is splendid with Mt. Khangchendzonga in the backdrop, overlooking the town of Jorethang and the Rangeet valley.

name: Chaubattia
desc: Not good with wind from East to South East. Take care about storms.

name: Kodungallur PG Site
desc: This is a large and long beachfront facing 270 degree W. Ideal for PPG.  Season begins from October and ends by onset of SW monsoon towards the end of May. Wind usually start from east in the morning and turn to blow from SW at 11, then W by 12 noon and from NW after 2 pm. Wind speed varies from 5 kms/hr to 15 kms/hr.  Can fly about 30 kms along the wide beachfront with lot of emergency landing options.  Max ceiling will be 500 ft ASL due to helicopter service. Motorable road upto the takeoff. Except the SW monsoon from June to September, there are hardly any adverse weather conditions other than a few unpredictable exceptions.

name: Tungareshwar
desc: The takeoff is motorable about 7 kms of off road driving will take you 2000feet high. From the point of parking your car takeoff is about 10 minutes walking distance. The takeoff area is big but a rocky. The place is isolated and forested so not suitable for venturing out alone. No known weather hazards. Flyable only in morning. The area is forested, isolated and has wild cats. Not suitable to fly without local support.

name: Tokpada
desc:
This is a flatland hence flying is only possible by towing or with help of a paramotor. 
The area is huge and can take any wind direction As this is an abandoned salt-pan it is low lying area hence gets filled up during monsoon and not usable for couple of months after monsoon

name: Agashi Paddy fields
desc: This is a huge open field suitable for ground handling and winching Not usable during monsoon

name: Mount Abu
desc: Mt. Abu :-It is about 280 Km. from Jodhpur towards the South, 4500 feet AGL, there is a launch place facing the SW near the Honeymoon point near the â€œBaileyâ€™s trackâ€ there is a good clear rock with no vegetation it is ideal for a PG and hence very good for a HG. Thermals are very strong here I have flown my PG and HG here.For NE winds during winter (from October to Feb) the Launch place is near 'Guru shikhar' but this launch point is bit tricky and the one needs permission from the Radar authorities, the LZ is near Abu Road, I have not flown here during the winter season so I can not tell you much but My. Instructor has done an XC flight from there and he had a blast as he told me.A word of caution here:- Since the launch point is located near the 'Honeymoon point' on the Bailey's track which is located at a secluded place it is better one flies here with a group or has some people to assist him, there have been instances where people were robbed by the local tribesman...

name: Arna
desc: 150 Feet high, walk up..

name: Pushkar
desc: Pushkar :-Located about 240 KM from Jodhpur towards the NE, it is near Ajmer many pilots have flown here from the 'Savitri Hill' and some other hills there. Takeoff from the Savitri temple behind the lake at Pushkar and from the Nag ridge that runs between Pushkar & Ajmer. The hike to the Nag hill is near Sanjji Chat the highest Road tip on the Nag Hill where it crosses over to Pushkar. Few pilots have landed at a clearing near the Local bus stop at the base of the Nag hill while flying the East side. One needs to be careful of the powerlines there. It is Rocky cliff and hence a demanding take off...

name: Bavarli
desc:
Bavarli / Bambor is 35 Km far on the Jaiselmer highway and is flyable in SW and NE and has road going to the top, it is 250 feet high, I fly here all through the winter and summer. 
Also Towing is done using Hydraulic payout winch at several open fields and gives good potential for an XC. Contact Samarth to arrange for Towing.

name: Visapur
desc: You can drive to the takeoff but be carefull as it's right on top of a thermal trigger. However you will need a thermal to take you high enough for the jump to the ridge behind. Strong venturii at both ends of the ridge & strong sheer on top of the fort so stay away from the terrain. It is possible to go high enough in the house thermal & XC towards Tower Hill or Tungi fort.

name: Kone
desc: Multiple takeoff locations

name: Saputara Governor Hill
desc: Take off in the area designated for adventure sports complex.

name: Roopmati Pavilion
desc: Behind Roopmati Pavilion

name: Durtlanang
desc:
Near to Durtlang swimingpool.
Daytime is little bit strong conditions.
Only for Expert pilots
You can fly on the most big hill city in the World. Cliff site so very good soaring and thermic!!

name: Panchgani
desc: Coords not really correct...

name: Osiyan dune
desc:
Osiyan:-Located about 65 Km from Jodhpur towards the N, flyable in NE winds has a good restaurant at the top of the dune, it is an average dune flying site.
The dune is 50 feet high.

name: Hoskote Lake Bed
desc: Flat lake bed. Not for take-offs. Nil

name: Captain Hill Yadamadu
desc:
East side take off is bit rocky.
West side take off has good space and nice slope. Nil

name: Raghav Hill
desc: Small sized, tricky take off towards east. One can drive in an SUV till the point of take off.

name: panvel uran road
desc: good

name: Saptashrungi
desc: Takeoff facing east as well as west, possible to takeoff all directions.

name: Bandla
desc: Bandla is very good take off point: one is west facing and a second is north facing; for hangliders there is a west facing man made TO. very smooth weather is here ......

name: Jyotiba Dongar
desc: East and West facing, staggered elevation, so landing to takeoff is just over 100M high. If you can get the thermal cycle right long distances over the flats is possible. Takeoff is reachable by car, retrieve if you bomb out takes just a few minutes.

name: Trimbak Godavari Ridge
desc: Multiple take off locations depending on wind direction. Motorable Road goes up till the village on NW of ridge. Beware of venturi and rotor areas, electrical poles, wires, barbwire fencings, trenches, rocks. If do not have much height stay away from pinnacles as strong venturi near them. When Passing over table land make sure you have good vertical clearance to keep clear of rotors from cliff side. Afternoons will be quite thermic.

name: Zanzroli
desc: There are three takeoff spots. One has to be ready to trek up to reach the takeoff locations. The trek is through forest which does not have much visible trails so you will need a local guide for the first time. The takeoff spots are big and safe for anyone with over 50 flights experience. Flying in weak winds will be a bit of a challenge for inexperienced pilots - specially landing.

name: Anjuna
desc:
There are basically two take offs. The one on the map is the highest one.
There is a lower take off, just on the left or right (according of the wind) of the small white praying tower. The higher take off is easier and safer. Lower take off should be done very close to the ridge, to avoid rotors, but only if the wind is not too strong. Best flying conditions with 18-25 km/h wind from West or North-West.

name: Tateeja
desc: There is a temple on top of the hill. The takeoff is about 200m towards southwest of temple. Click on the "flights" tab to see the flights

name: Khoch, Mokhāda
desc: This is a hill flying site for paragliding. Enough space for takeoff with a friendly ridge Moderate climate throughout the year. Wind direction is suitable from February to May.

name: Juni Jawhār
desc: Paramotoring and winching site

name: Jawhār Palace
desc: For experienced pilots

name: Tala PG,Kuda
desc: Motorable takeoff through Tala properties, Suitable for W,NW, SW wind direction. Not suitable for training or beginner pilots. Should be flyable every day. Being a coastal site sea breeze should provide good soaring condition specially from February to May.

name: Gorakhnath
desc: North facing only... Except monsoon...

name: Mirawali
desc: Facing south,east and north... except monsoon...

name: Agadgaon
desc: Facing west only....

Naya busty

name: Khospuri
desc:
Excellent Place for takeoff.
Best for Tandem also. excellent except monsoon.

name: Deolai
desc: This site has multiple spots that are suitable for north launch. West lunch appears possible too but exercise your judgement. There are some thorny bushes and small rocks but nothing too challenging. As in this part of India October thru March is flyable.

name: Company Kadav Harbour
desc: 25 km long beach with ample space for landing anywhere on the beach. Fisherman are friendly and co operative.  4 kms from the nearest National Highway. Motorable good road upto the takeoff. Flyable from mid September till mid May. South West monsoon is strong from June to August. Usually wild will start from east in the morning turning clockwise  and flyable winds are from 11 am (SW) and from 2 pm NW. Usual wind speeds varies from 5 kmph to max 20 kmph. Mostly between 10 and 15 kmph laminar wind is  the main attraction for safe flying.

desc: null

on a hill, on top of west suburbs, near tehran.

the better idee is to speak with local pilots... FALL is best season for flight and spring is too periless

walk on the little hill, just near the salt lake.
alti: 1651m you can fly here when the wind is too strong on other sites.
Be carefull with south wind.

name: Seyedan

Near antenna, above the village.
Take the track in the valley witch go to the NW since Siadan.
alti: 2490m 10 months of year you can fly from this site but the best time for xc is between April and July

name: montain
desc:
from the road you can see it, on the top of a big sand slope.
alti: 1393m

name: Emam Zadeh Hashem (Mosha)
desc:
On the way to Amol at Haraz road after passing Ab-e-Ali ski resort continue to Emam Zadeh Hashem shrine.The flying site will be at right hand side just behind & above shops & inn. Fallow a short off road on right side after parking & shops to East  & turn back to West (about 500M). This road is not accessible in winter due to snow coverage hence you have to park car down on parking & hike about 200 meter up to take off site. See map photo
Coordinate is 35 46 40N - 52 02 28E Strong wind on spring & fall

name: Abb-E-Sard
desc:
Take off area is relatively small therefore launch will be one by one in to the south.
Hang glider take off site is on the wast side about 200m away. Strong wind
Strong 'Thermals' at middle of day in summer

name: Herdisarvik
desc:
The takeoff is just northeast of the corner of the lake, here:
http://ja.is/kort/#x=367964&y=378037&z=6

Park opposite the summerhouse, walk east along the foot of the slope, following a line of small yellow poles. After about 700m, you should be below a broad gulley (couloir) with a grassy patch at the top. Turn left, straight up the slope.

The launch is in a gap in the rock band and is a bumpy grass patch about 50m across. Southerly wind can bring low cloudbase and rain.

name: Skalafell
desc:
Anywhere on the top, but normally above the southeast-facing ridge. Cloudbase is often quite low, and Skalafell is at 800m, so quite exposed to upper winds.

As always in Iceland, the weather can change very very quickly. Contact the locals for a weather briefing.

name: Kambar
desc: Near the viewpoint. There is a large grassy area at the top of the cliff. As always in Iceland, the weather can change very, very quickly. Contact the locals for a weather briefing.

name: Seljalandvoss
desc: On the cliff, north of the waterfall. Iceland weather!

name: Hjallafjall
desc: Small ridge, 20m high, 3-4km long

name: Padova
desc: Very little TO, Takeoff only with good regular frontal wind Takeoff only with good regular frontal wind

name: Val della Torre
desc:
There are 3 takeoff sites very close to each other:
Lower takeoff: 880 m
Normal takeoff QNH: 980 m (550 m AGL)
High Takeoff: 1160M 

High takeoff is good in strong thermal days where the thermal wind at the main takeoff may become very strong (too strong for the beginners). Up there it is usually lighter.
Low takeoff is rarely used. Long grass there and prickly bushes. It can be used when on normal takeoff the conditions are too strong, or sometimes in winter in case normal takeoff is already in the cloudcover. Avoid flying with NW winds.

Beware of very fast developing thunderstorms over higher alps some 10..30km to the west. They can arrive literally in 30minutes and bring strong gusts with them. It is suggested to land as soon as possible if any thunder heard. 

In late spring/early summer strong and sometimes a turbulent thermal winds may ruin your takeoff, especially if you are without appropriate experience. Try to take off in late morning or in the afternoon, or take off from the high-takeoff site, its usually an ideal wind up there when at normal takeoff its already too strong. Local pilots often prefer Corio or Trucetti flying sites on those kind of days.

name: Praia a Mare
desc:
Take off is small but easy. Best hour to start is from 11:00 am to 5:00 pm in summer and from 12:00 am to 3:00 pm in winter. Praia a Mare is perfect for thermal flights and it is quite difficult to have strong wind. Cross-country flights here are quite nice. 
In the landing area pay attention to the wind from SSW that normally gives turbulence behind the Isle of Dino.

name: Monte Avena (Feltre)
desc:
Main TO: TO A: large; parking just behind.
TO B: about 400m up along the road, park at the 'Malga' and walk to TO (about 150m). ATTN: on the right side often modelplanes!

name: Pieve d Alpago - Dolada
desc: With grass steeply sloping, but normally with face wind

name: Sestola M. Calvanella (MO)
desc:
North: easy; grassy and ample. Ski track with gentle slope. With E winds the takeoff is in turbulence due to the tree line: a lot better with right direction in take off, near tree line

South: technical; rocky and steep. Requires good control. 

E winds perfect for 'passo serra' take off near (1 km) to Pian del Falco, under road for winter ski area.

S - W wind: remember others take off near Sestola Pian del Falco in plenty S - W direction. 'Pian Cavallaro 1800mt.' in ski area and 'Croce Arcana 1800mt' Fanano municipality. Spectacular spots! Do not fly with S - W winds; this is Appenine foehn and can be extremely rough. S - W wind strength can increase in few minutes.
Avoid flying with strong wind particulary warning with W and S: is normally substimate wind force with meridional winds from inexperienced or foregnier pilots

This site works better in post-frontal conditions. Pre-frontal conditions often bring S - W winds.

name: Celle
desc:
650 m AGL.
Takeoff QNH: 1030 m .
Pretty large grassy field, with some sharp hidden rocks, so be very careful and explore your takeoff path well.


A power line is present under the takeoff, but after the takeoff the clearance is very high and safe, but despite that be careful when soaring. Don't fly with winds from NW to NE.

Don't mess up when strong valley breeze is present. It will not just make your takeoff more difficult (crosswind launch) but may also ruin your flight as well (rotors may be present).

name: Chiamberlando
desc:
550 m AGL.
1005 m . Power lines on S and W side of the landing field. The W side has also barbed wire along. Don not fly with winds from NW to NE. Be careful about the wind valley which are often very strong. Typically it\'s a fall-winter flight.

name: Campitello-Canazei-Locomotiva
desc:
Alti: 2370m
from Canazei go to the Sella pass ('Passo Sella') and park your car on the pass. Walk 10 minuts to the take off, direction East; at the foot of the cliff, which looks like an engine when you are on the road froom Canazei.
In the winter greate soaring and groundhandling on the snow is porrible on the north face of the same site. Weather info: http://www.arpa.veneto.it/bollettini/htm/dolomiti_meteo.asp

North wind; If you wait too long, the valley wind could come in your back from 'Val Gardena' valley, this will jeopardize the possibility to start XC flights.

name: Campitello-Canazei-Col Rodella
desc:
There are two main take-offs, the first is located just 100 meters from the Col Rodella cable car station near the refuge Des Alpes. Going down the ridge from the hut we note the windsock; on the left side (towards the Gardena valley) is used when the wind comes from the North (the area under the two chair lifts with exposure to the North is customarily used for hang-gliders take off) . The right side (Fassa valley side) is used when the wind comes from South and Southeast and in the early hours of thermal activity, normally until 12.00am. After this time there is a gradual strengthening of the breeze of the Fassa valley, so use a take-off from the South to West facing. This take-off is reached by turning right out of the station and the cable car going down the path that passes under the cable car line in the direction of the road equipped with Rodella, at this point we can see the windsock.
It is also possible to take off right on top of Rodella (in North wind): 15' hike up from cable car station. Weather Info:
Rodella (with Webcam): https://www.icarusfassa.it/stazione-rodella/indexDesktop.php
http://www.arpa.veneto.it/bollettini/htm/dolomiti_meteo.asp
http://www.meteotrentino.it/
https://www.windfinder.com/forecast/col_rodella
Pay particular attention to moderate winds from the North and East in general, in these conditions, the area becomes very dangerous and turbulent. In any case, the flight in spring and summer in the central hours (11:00am to 5:00pm) is only recommended for experienced pilots. However, towards evening it is possible for less experienced pilots to make a beautiful soaring flights (South, Southeast Takeoff).

name: Laveno - Mte.Nudo - Mombello

name: Norma
desc:
Park your vehicle in the archeological area parking and walk up (easy) for 800 mt.
South-West esposure, very large and safe, very easy and large Top Landing Area.
All winds directions are good  or enough for taking off EXCEPT EAST & SOUTH-EAST WINDs THAT ARE DANGEROUS !
Possible strong breeze on day middle hours

Hangliders ramp available on Arestino Mount that is located between Norma and Cori, find exact data on the Club web site Live weather and live CAM http://www.sarracino.it/

desc: West / South-west esposure, large and safe within these wind direction. Trees on both sides. Local flying clubs run shuttles to takeoff year-round on good flying days. North-East to South-East winds, easy over-development during summer;

desc:
most often used TO in the valley.
La Guardia: 45:43.000N  011:10.629 E
alt.1130 m facing south. From Recoaro city center town road to Campogrosso then stop at restaurant La Guardia Norh wind can be dangerous and prevent flying when strong;  when light possibly good flying conditions.

name: Campogrosso  (Recoaro- Padova)
desc:
Campogrosso 45:43.758 N  011:10.766 E alt m1470 facing south-east.
From Recoaro 5-7 km to Campogrosso pass, then 200m before the mountain hut turn right, go for another 400m and park when the road turns left and you can see the valley; TO is 50m on the right.

Mostly in summer, or if you want to take off early or late, it's a wonderful place to relax also.

Unfortunately it's a little bit small and short. Norh wind can be dangerous and prevent flying if strong; if light can give good flying conditions. On this take off anyway you can notice well if the north wind is to strong

desc:
45Ã‚Â°39'50.86''N  11Ã‚Â°12'38.01''E; alt about 1600m.
From the end of the chairlift go down the skislope  keeping right for 3-400 meters: take off is facing the south west side (the opposite side of the chairlift). 

With certain wind conditions you can also take off from the skislope, on the north side.

name: Valdarno
desc:
There are two Take-off places; the first is 1060 mt. high, southwest exposed, easily reached by jeep (by car there is a ten mins walk), it's quite big and without obstacles.
The second, 200 mt higher (1250) is south exposed and used mostly by hang-gliders. It's quite narrow for paragliders.

name: Speikboden
desc: different places to lay out; about 10min walk from chair lift. North wind!

name: Monte Cairo (Monte Cassino)
desc:
(N41.5347, E13.8297)
A big large and smooth field, suitable also for beginners.
The takeoff field is reachable by a 3min walk through the forest from the parking place on the Terelle road (N41.547685, E13.810087).

As far as known, there is no permanent shuttle bus at the site, but as it is often used by schools, tandem pilots etc., finding a ride up should not be major issue. 
Unconfirmed information says there also regular buses going passing Caira and going up to Terelle, which would be perfect for going up.

name: Cornizzolo
desc:
Monte Cornizzolo, easy south facing launch directly at the road where the shuttle drops you off (Risparmio), or walk 10 minutes west to the summit to a much bigger launch (Centrale) used for competitions Careful with strong north winds, light north winds with strong sun can provide good flying conditions but you will fly in lee.
DO NOT FLY when the windsock on the top of the Centrale Takeoff (Visible from every take off) indicates NORTH WIND DIRECTION.
Wind indication: http://www.scurbatt.it/index.php?lang=en

name: Loggia di Pilato - Monopoli
desc: The takeoff site is quite short and steep; small stones make the run a bit slippery so it needs extra care while running. Bushes limit the lenght of the takeoff run, so even in case of mistakes the consequences are limited. Local club maintains wind sleeve and other wind indicators.

name: Monte Cucco
desc:
Grassy lane, moderately steep, easy. Check www.vololiberomontecucco.it for information on takeof zones (pg/hg). This site is - due to very often high wind speeds - more a HG than a PG site! Don't get intimidated if on a day with conditions fine for paragliding all you see are hanggliders.

Wind info: www.VoloLiberoMonteCucco.it
Mail : info@VoloLiberoMonteCucco.it

name: Castelluccio - Fontanile
desc:
Lots of space everywhere around the gravel road. Dust devils!!! Be very careful especially when at low altitude over the landing site.

Thundertorms may buid up very quickly in May and June. If you star getting a good lift everywhere on the plains, know that its the last moment to get down.

Sometimes strong wind is present at higher altitudes while not present at takeoff. This is especially important if soaring over Monte Vettore.

name: Santa Maria in Valle Vigezzo
desc:
HG: - at the gondola station (2 winsocks)
PG: 1) Cima 2: 15-20mins walk along the ridge to the west on the highest point. With binoculars, the windsock can be seen from the valley;
2) Pizzo Trubbio: access by foot (1hr) or by gondola (in winter or when arranged). Absolutely NOT with norderly winds ('Nordfoehn').
The thermals in the valley can be so strong as to cause problems when landing (especially for HG! > drag chute...).
Webcam Piana di Vigezzo: https://www.bergfex.it/craveggia-piana-vigezzo/webcams/c6087/

name: Boville Ernica
desc: South-West esposure,safe, top landing

name: Campitello-Canazei-Belvedere
desc:
There are two take-offs, the first is behind the cable car station of Belvedere on the ridge facing the Marmolada. This take-off (very technical, only for experienced pilots!) is used mainly with light winds from the south and southeast and in the early hours of thermal activity until 11.00am. After this time there is a gradual strengthening of the breeze in the valley of Fassa, so use a take-off facing West-Northwest. You can find this out from the south exit of the cable car and then turn right and follow the ridge to the windsock.
If you are coming from Pordoipass, park your car at the Pass and follow the path up to number 601 for 'col dei Rossi' for about an hour. 
In winter is not advisable to take off from here, it is better to takeoff from col Rodella. Weather Info:
http://www.arpa.veneto.it/bollettini/htm/dolomiti_meteo.asp
http://www.meteotrentino.it/
Pay particular attention to moderate winds from the North and East in general, in these conditions, the area becomes very dangerous and turbulent. In any case, the flight in spring and summer in the central hours (11:00am to 5:00pm) is only recommended for experienced pilots.

name: Monfestino
desc:
Easy E takeoff, grassy slope. Pass on the left of the oak with the windsock when launching.
Pay special attention to the wind cheching the windsock on the antenna on the N takeoff. If the wind is from N, NE this takeoff is in rotor.
With N, NE winds use the N takeoff. 
N takeoff (50 m northbound). Short, narrow and steep, a little intimidating, but looks worse than it actually is. Make sure your glider comes up cleanly before committing your launch. Unflyable with NW, W, SW, S winds.
Rough with strong E winds.
With N, NE winds the E takeoff can look good but is in rotor, beware! Can launch from here with very light N and NE. In this case steer left as soon as you clear the launch.

name: Ospedaletti Monte Nero Alto
desc:
Easy, Flight in Thermodynamics 
Vertical drop 530 meters. Winds: E - SE - S

name: Pianoro
desc:
Difficulty: Medium 
 SW - S Vertical drop 800 meters. Winds: SW - S

name: Massanera
desc: Easy Sint Wind Massanera +39 366 19 33 205

name: Serrone
desc: It's a 7.5km drive from landing to takeoff. If walking follow hiking signs to 'Monte Scalambra' - about 5km. Large easy grassy takeoff.

name: Pizzorne
desc: Meadow, easy enough; with southwind is necessary to contrast the paraglider, anyway conformation of the valley usually send the wind in front of the pilot.

name: Tivoli
desc:
Hughe field with some grass and some sharp rocks as well (on the left). Plenty of space for everybody.
The takeoff is right in front of the parking on the very top of the mountain. The sea breeze may get too strong in the afternoon. Never go without the accelerator system.

name: Trevignano
desc: Only good with winds from S or SW, other directions are dangerous.

name: Colonei
desc:
There are two take off 200 m apart at the side of the road (access description below). Wind direction NE-E-SE.
Generally take off in the morning, before the Ora wind from the South pick-up (generally in early afternoon). https://holfuy.com/it/weather/718

name: Santa Elisabetta
desc:
There are two takeoffs: high and low.

1) High takeoff. Nice and huge take off place at the feet of local  mountain chain 'Quinzeina' . Only one warning, be careful of the pylons of electric line near the take off.

2) 'Belice': lower takeoff - used when the high takeoff is unreachable (winter) or inside the clouds.
It is next to the small church Belice, not big but smooth and grassy field at 1000m altitude. Coordinates: 45.418305ºN, 7.641971ºE.
It can be easily reached by car via a paved road. Is the same that cavallaria place, both sites are in a ray of 30 Km so you can play a good cross if you like, so you can fly in all season

Don't fly with strong westerlies and northerlies. And better to stay out of valleys Orco and Soana - strong winds, rotors, lack of emergency landing sites etc.

name: Bagnara Calabra
desc: Near the highway exit for Bagnara Calabra.

Takeoff: 660 mt. exposed to the southwest, flying thermo thermo-dynamic, medium difficulty, ideal for those who want to begin to deal with the first heat, situated between sea and mountains

GPS:  40Â°42'45'  N
      14Â°50'70'  E No Fly wind

N - NW - NE - E

name: Capaccio
desc:
Capaccio is the symbol of free flight at least of the lower Campania and Lucania, a reality established for over 20 years. A site that offers the most varied possibilities: from the flight purely in dynamics, to the days for spring days of good thermal activity, from the flight for beginners, the starting point for important cross-country flights to the possibility of two-seaters with breathtaking views ranging from Capri, passing through the Amalfi Coast until you look at the mountains of Cilento, from the most inland to the coastal one. It guarantees at least 300 flying days in a year, a weather condition almost certain, with the entrance of sea breeze on time every day, and almost always gives flights back until late evening. The take-off of Capaccio is always attended, on weekends as well as during the week, well maintained and above all easily accessible by car, with a take-off landing distance of 4 km walkable in a few minutes.


Easy to find and well accessable by car. TO at the wind sock on the right side facing downwards. Strong uplift at the age. Turn left after TO.

name: Maso Tais
desc:
Not steep: sometimes, if the wind is not strong you have to run to take off. Wide grass field above a hotel, Maso Tais, facing south. The windsock is located on the left side on top of a tree.
The thermals start at 12:00 until 17:00. Weather Info:
http://www.meteotrentino.it
http://www.arpav.veneto.it
Pay particular attention to moderate winds from the North and East in general, in these conditions, the area becomes very dangerous and turbulent. In any case, the flight in spring and summer in the central hours (13:00 to 16:00) is only recommended for experienced pilots. However, towards evening it is possible for less experienced pilots to make a beautiful soaring flights (South, Southwest Takeoff).

name: Monte S. Giorgio - Piossasco
desc:
You must take off only from the area marked by wooden poles.
In order to avoid congestion and save the grass on the takeoff please prepare you glider behind the takeoff area and come to the takeoff zone only when you are ready. Do not fly with foen winds! Extremely turbulent and dangerous.
Keep eye on rapidly developing thunderstorms in the summer months.

name: Chamois

Watch the winds in the Valley D'Aosta.

There is a risk of over development in the region.

name: Punta Ces - San Martino di Castrozza
desc:
From San Martino di Castrozza, you need to follow the sign for 'Malga Ces'. After 3 km.  you will see the chair lift PUNTA CES - Time table on http://impiantices.it/skiarea-ces/orari/ (winter and summer seasons). If the chair lift will be closed, you need to follow the path for 'Punta Ces'. On top, at the arrive of the chair lift, you will see the refuge and below it, at the beginning of the slope 'Punta Ces', there is a TAKEOFF - Facing South. On your left side, you can see on top of the chair lift's pole, the anenometer. The teakeoff isn't really steep, so if the wind is not really strong, you need to run. Weather Info: 
http://www.meteotrentino.it 
http://www.arpav.veneto.it 

Pay particular attention to moderate winds from Northwest, North and Northeast in general, in these conditions, the area becomes very dangerous and turbulent in summer, it's better don't fly. In any case, the flight in spring and summer in the central hours (12:00 to 16:00) is only recommended for experienced pilots sometime its easy to get RainStorm during the central hours.) just check the weather before to plan to come here. Anyway towards Morning it is possible for less experienced pilots to make a beautiful soaring flights (South, Southeast Takeoff).

name: Alpe di Storo (Idro Lake)
desc:
also used by model airplanes.
PGs fly normally before 1100 or after 1600. WIND!!! often as early as 1100, the wind 'kicks' in and becomes too strong for flying -ideal for windsurfers/ kiters ;-)
Met Infos:
- wind at launch: https://www.trentinoadventures.it/en/129-weather-stations/148-weather-station-in-alpo-paragliding-take-off-point.html
- wind at LZ: https://www.trentinoadventures.it/stazioni-meteo/91-stazione-meteo-in-localita-idroland-punto-di-atterraggio-parapendio.html
- webcam at LZ: https://www.trentinoadventures.it/webcam/40-webcam-lago-d-idro.html

name: Campitello-Canazei-Brodol
desc:
The takeoff is normally used by pilots of the place during the closure of the cable cars or, because of his position, to make a beautiful soaring flights in the evening. During the first hours of the day pilots with less experience can make beautiful morning flights, and, not before the early afternoon because of the exposure, you can start to fly in thermals. This Takeoff is the easiest and safest of Fassa valley, it is located on that in winter is a ski slope, the slope is gentle and gradually tends to increase slightly and the exposure is perfect to go out on the valley. From Canazei follow the road to Pordoipass for about 9 km. When you reach the seventeenth hairpin, there is a road on the left showing 'OFFICINE MECCANICHE SITC'. Park your car and walk on the street in Southwest direction for about 5 minutes until the wind sock. Weather Info:
http://www.arpa.veneto.it/bollettini/htm/dolomiti_meteo.asp
http://www.meteotrentino.it/
Pay particular attention to moderate winds from the North and East in general, in these conditions, the area becomes very dangerous and turbulent. In any case, the flight in spring and summer in the central hours (11:00am to 5:00pm) is only recommended for experienced pilots.

- end of chair lift

name: Monterosso
desc:
On SP38 route after Soviore Sanctuary Fly Only with sudeast, sud and sudwest winds.
Pay attentention with strong east wind: takeoff is downwind.
With east and sudeast winds soaring is possible on Punta Mesco peak.
Sea breaze and good temperatures gradient can build thermals also in winter time with meteo downwind (max 20 Km/h). In Spring thermals are strongs and some XC are possible.
