name: Ambohitromby
desc: Take-off from the top, just bellow the antenna. better to go on the east side of the mountain. several places to take off from smooth slop to steep ones, everyone will enjoy it!

name: Amborokely 1
desc:
On the left side of the road while driving up north you can take a secondary road for 50 m and directly reach the landing area with your car. 
Then from there you can take-off above the road and do some soaring on the early morning and thermal once the conditions are establihed. Great spot to start cross.

name: Amborokely 2
desc: park in the village and walk up the top of the mountain, villager are very friendly and welcoming. The walk will be about 30 minutes to climb the 100m from the road

name: Ankazobe Soaring East
desc:
Take-off on grass surrounded by granitic rock, but with light slope, and many places to prepare and take-off. 
You will reach the take-off taking on the right while driving up-north on a secondary road, just after ridge, you can drive for the 50m to reach the take off and park next to it.

name: Ambohimanambola
desc: 30min walk to reach the submit, and then possible to take off from North to East wind. ideal with East. Mainly places to take off.

name: Alasora
desc: Take off only with East Wind, and windy condition to have decent fly on dynamic.

name: Inflating spot
desc:
Orientated East, so East wind are required which is the dominant every morning. 
Great spot to learn and inflate, possible to do some soaring if the wind is string enough.

name: Ambohimanambola West
desc: Great for beginners with West wind. Possible to inflate and do soring of there is enough wind.

name: Ambondrona
desc: Short take-off, better with enough wind to avoid running as the place is small and and steep.

name: Andilana
desc:
Take-off on the noth side with north wind, or on the east side with east wind. 
Dynamic fly mainly in the afternoon once the wind is enough

name: Rocher du Farihy
desc:
An official take off is accessible either by a small foot track just from the road below the mountain, or it is possible to go on the back of the mountain through secondary roads. 
It is possible to take of from the top of mountain (with east, south-east, northeast wind). Or from the official take-off, a bit above the cliff with East wind.

name: Route de Faratsio
desc: Take off is a few hundred meters from the road. Site flyable more in end of the day, with west wind

name: Topy
desc: East side and West side, both great Take off!

name: Pente ecole Analavory
desc:
Car park along the road toward tsiromandidy, and then the whole hill is free of trees, you take take off anywere you want and many landing option. 
Possible to fly dynamic! 
Mind the Cows...

name: Caméléon
desc: Beautifull Take-off orientated north-east, sooth grass and progressive slope.

name: Krusevo
desc: 4km from the town of Krusevo, 1470m asl, Large take off area right by the road-side. Easy acces, grassy, no problem! Strong North winds tend to make lots of tourbulent air, if winds too strong, go to the valley, there is a huge hill called Ribnik, perfect for soaring in ALL directions. Great Fun!

name: Ohrid
desc: Large, grassy take-off below the road. Moderately steep, easy. strong winds, carefull!

name: Vodno
desc: relatively small take off, on a top of 1050 asl mountain called 'Vodno', over the capital of Skopje. last 5km dirt road, any car, 4wd is preferable. Large mountain lodge, tee, coffie and a huge (guiness record) 74 meter hihg chross built on the top. a fucking monster, a poke in the eye to the albaninas! Flyable on N winds only!

name: Skopska Crna Gora
desc: LARGE grass take off on a top of 1600 m/asl mountain ridge on the north of the capital. 300 pg can launch at the same time, that big! Strong termals and S/W/SW winds could be too strong in the middle of the day for PG, but very good for HG.

name: Ajvatovci
desc: Large hill, grassy, this is a school hill, good soaring on strong E winds, walk up to the top or a serious 4WD. none

name: Sapka
desc:
summer: Large slope, grass, aprox 1700 asl, big, easy
winter: 2470m asl, cable car strong termals, dont exeed 2500m asl on W winds, near the mountain.

name: Ribnik
desc: This is a hill in the middle of the flatlands of Pelagonia, all directions! none

name: Sliva
desc: Large, grassy. none

name: Bogoslovec
desc: Take off is on the top of the hill, about 755 meters above the sea level, or about 400 meters height difference. Best wind for flying is N, but also is suitable for other directions. None

name: Struga
desc: Duży start, łatwy start on east with possible slight deviations.

name: Mt. Bogd Khan
desc: This Launch Site faces to NW and best for W, WNW and NW wind up to 10 knots at the base. From mid-July to late-September is the best time for early, light thermalling with average W, WNW, NW wind. From October to March, there is usually null wind with some S inputs. From April to June, there is really strong wind from N mostly. In any month during the afternoon wind becomes strongest.

name: Cheoc-Van Beach
desc: Lanuch site is a big stone

name: Morne Gommier
desc: Morne Gommier, 230m, between ' Sainte-Luce' and 'Le Marin. Good all along the year, but with windfinder under 10 knots

name: ghajn tuffieha bay
desc: a small clearing on top of the hill

name: qammieh
desc: a small clearing by the side of the road rotor behind cliff, top landing has to be done on left of takeoff

name: Dingli cliffs
desc: by the road on a small piece of clearing by the cliff edge rotor behind cliff

name: Top of the world
desc: From the parking walk south west along the ridge for around 100m, the take-off is situated on top of a rocky hill just before the farming terraces. There are some carpets set up to avoid line breakage. The take-off is otherwise rocky.

name: delli
desc: on the lower part of the slope

name: znuber
desc: on a clearing on the cliff edge

name: Mtahleb
desc: A patch of carpets over a rough rocky surface. Take care of your lines and inspect before take-off. Beautiful scenery

name: Montagne Longue
desc: Climb up the hill through the bush (20 minutes max), you'll find it.

name: Pyramid
desc: The takeoff site is relatively small, so you need a light glider or some wind or thermals to succeed. It is facing west, northwest with a beautiful view to the ocean from Le morne to Tamarin. You may fly with fruit bats every day here:) Only flyable when the backwind dies, so when Le Morne is not good for kitesurfing and the clouds seems to be at 1 place or drifting from the west. Basically the wind is good from southwest to northwest!

name: La Tinaja
desc: Despegue oficial Puerto Tinaja

name: Escalera
desc: S, SE

name: Valle de Bravo - La Torre
desc:
La Torre May be too windy to launch from 14:00 to 17:00 during March, April and May.
Thunderstorms during the rain season (from May to October)

name: Monterrey - El Mirador
desc: The take off is reachabale by car. It is very, very small and just useable with windspeeds up to 15 km/h. Beginners should avoid this take off or go there with another experienced person.

name: Chalchihuapan - Puebla
desc: South oriented saddle 350 meters over valley.

name: La Cumbre - Colima
desc: Take-off is oriented SSW. Ideal take-off varies between 10:00 and 14:00 hours, depending on local conditions and seasonal changes. Take-off itself is located at the top of La Cumbre at 750 m (above sea level) 350 mts from ground.Optimal flying conditions has a breeze that comes from the sea, which is located about 40 km (25 miles) away in a straight line in a SSE direction, and the valleys in front of take-off generate optimal thermal conditions. https://www.windy.com/19.181/-103.692?19.064,-103.930,11

name: Fortin de las Flores
desc:
Mountan named Cerro de san Juan de las Antenas
there is a road that take you to the launch directly by car. There are some antenas for radio &tv broadcast, microwave, cell phones etc. the take off is 1350 m. asl and we fly with E and SE wind. be carful with antenas. be carefull about pilots in top landing procedure.

name: La Salina
desc: Two Launch areas covered with astro-turf and carpet as of 2011. Windsocks, outhouse, switchback trails, LZ's all maintained by Team Fly La Salina and Bajabrent (since 1997) NONE

name: La Malinche
desc:
La Malinche Launch is unique in the region; the intersection of three valleys releases a consistent daily house thermal. It is the best local launch for both local and XC flights, providing options for 360 degrees and landing zones in all directions, as well as an extensive system of inexpensive taxis to take you where you wish. 
Pilots new to this site should get a briefing of the multiple landing and XC options. 
The large grass launch is maintained year around exclusively for paragliding by the paragliding owners and can easily accommodate 4 – 5 gliders.  
Winds are predictably Southwest, South, and Southeast.
Top landings are common for local Mexican tandem pilots and should present no problems for intermediate pilots. The flying season in this region is excellent in the winter and spring months, and we get rain in the summer afternoons but it is still flyable on dry days.  The launch site is situated directly in front of one of the most consistent house thermals in the whole region of several valleys.  

Late October - November - Gentle thermals, 2800 - 3100 m- 90% - good for beginner under instruction, XC, Ridge soaring, 90% flyable every day

December -January - Med-strong thermals 2800 - 3800 m - XC, Ridge soaring, Magic Air- 98% flyable everyday.

February - March - Med Strong thermals 5000+ m - XC, Ridge soaring, Magic Air- 98% flyable everyday.

name: Malinalco
desc: A part of beautiful grass covered sheep grazing pastures, a south-east facing launch with the wind usually crossing 45 degrees from the right.  There is a also a true south facing alternate further on down the trail from launch.  It is a rather steep launch.

name: Yelapa Tapita
desc: Carpeted launch with shade shelter, thorny brush surrounding carpeted area is unforgiving of aborted launches or errant launches. Dependent upon sea breeze for flying.  Thermals are generally light but can also be turbulent at moments.

name: Yelapa Tapa
desc: Cleared area near ridgetop where power lines leave ridge for Yelapa.  Two launch spots possible for slightly different wind directions (E & NNE).  Short runway with steep drop-off requires decent launch skills. Opposing winds above launch, variable upslope and over-the-back cycles on launch.

name: Valle de Bravo - El Peñon
desc:
One of the best flying sites in Mexico (and probably in the world). During the months of December to March the conditions allow for flights on the 100's km order, with cloud bases of 4,500 plus meters msl.
The launch was expanded on 2008 by the government of the Estado de Mexico as part of the improvements for the Mexico 2009 Paragliding World Championship. From February to the beginning of the rain season the conditions get stronger, with rough air and strong winds almost all day.
During the rain season conditions are mellow, but there is risk of fast overdeveloping, with strong thunderstorms.

name: El Salto
desc:
Not actualy a mountain, takeoff into a big hole ;)
240 m vertical, facing 060°. On the dividing line between two quite different geographic areas, sometimes blown out.

name: La Ceja Tapalpa
desc:
Intermediate or P3 or higher
Take off ramp for one paraglider at a time
SSE to E winds Very strong thermal conditions in hot days

name: Frailes
desc: Excelent place, big area

name: Zopilotes
desc: Excelent for beginner pilots

name: Cantamar
desc: South west end Dune if wind is northwest, south end or ridge to the north of dune if wind is west. Requires strong conditions due to low ridge and dune. Good ground handeling skills recomended.

name: Rusty Pelican
desc:
Coordenadas: 19 47 2.44 N 90 37 54.11 W Altura: 60 mts. Forecast meteorological : wind speed, wind direction, precipitation, temperature, cloudiness. Thanks to ' windfinder' 

http://www.windfinder.com/forecast/rusty_pelican

name: Zaachila
desc: Launch is oriented to the E and is flyable with NE, E & SE wind 2220m. asl just be aware of strong winds and don´t fly if wind comes from W.

name: Loma Maria
desc: 1833 m asl E SE oriented Don't take off if visibility is less than 100 meters

name: Vergel de la Sierra
desc:
Big in of to land, grass, oriented to the west 
Altitude 7800 ft. AVSL
Fly able from September to April all day Too much win some days

name: Purgatorio
desc: closed by landowner's request!!

name: Despegue Bistro
desc: Easy slope with 45 degree angle with south wind, very easy to take off, maximum two wings prepared but just one takes off. January to May, as in most site in Mexico at midday, from 11.30 am wind conditions can get very strong and is safe to fly after 3 or 4 pm

name: cantil de las aguilas
desc: Nice takeoff with green grass, one wind at the time. Enough room for toplanding. Orientation southwest. The best time of year is from november to march. But sometimes you can have a very nice flights during the raining season from june to september

name: Ixtapan de la sal
desc: Nice big takeoff with 450 m. in SSE direction, very safe launch with plenty of landing fields and road access for retrieval, it offers many routes for XC even connecting with other flying sites. Recommended for all pilots. Flyable all year. The best season is winter from October to March.

name: Teta Azul de la Misión
desc: The launch site is located ten minutes past Playa Santtispac and is accessed via a well marked and two wheel drive gravel road on your right. The best launch is 25 feet north of the gate to the antenna and just below the road. The prevailing winds are from the east which creates a slight side hill launch situation. If the winds clock to the north then you can lay your wing at the edge of the road and you will have a very clear and level launching path right toward the LZ.

name: Alto Lucero
desc:
Alto Lucero is the new place for flying close to the capital of Veracruz State. 
Great place for XC, the place is termic and soaring spot. The glass off or 'restituciÃ³n' is amazing in the evening but the XC potential in the morning and before 3.00pm is asome. Only Flyable with E and NE winds

name: Concha Chinas
desc: This is an afternoon site and needs a sea breeze with some South in it.  While the launch has been improved, it is small without a bail-out option.  You need a breeze to be able to launch with only a few steps.  Jungle surrounds the launch.  You will need solid launching skills, this is not a launch for beginners. You will need the right cycle/breeze to launch. Make sure you can penetrate the breeze to avoid landing in the jungle.

name: Tulancingo
desc:
Very nice takeoff where you can get up by walking or 4x4 car.

Wind direction NE to E. Has to blow constantly otherwise chance of dust devils.

name: Tulum
desc:
To fly the Mayan ruins of Tulum, you have to go by walk on the public beach which is situated 500 meters south of the ruins.
When you arrive at the end of the beach, there is some flat rocks before the small clifs and the lighthouse.
The best way to fly there is to inflate the glider on the beach and to walk in direction of the lighthouse. If the wind is in the good direction you will takeoff easily. BE CAREFULL, it's for expert pilot only!!! No landing place between the beach and the ruins and it's forbiden to land in the ruins or on the beach down the ruins... You need the perfect wind direction to fly there (east or south-east) and at least 20 km/h. The wind is often strong...

name: Boca Paila Dune
desc: Takeoff from the beach after the Boca Paila Hotel at the south of Tulum before the National Park entry. Need at least 20 km/h...

name: Lago Seco San Marcos
desc:
Concrete ramp oriented to the West
500 mts. above the landing zone
20.3516111 N and 103.5411944 W and 1885 mts. ASL

name: El Toro Bull Hill
desc:
Takeoff (despegue) is just to the east of the top T intersection at the top of the mountain below the antennas.

There is a north facing takeoff at the helipad higher up near the west antennas.

name: Tepoztlan
desc: Located in San Juan Tlacotenco. Launch is oriented south bound, approximately 700 meters above landing Strong winds and thermals during noon. It is important to launch knowing the wind direction to avoid lee side where you are likely to find rotors.

name: Antenas de Vizcaya
desc: null

name: Helipuerto
desc: Takeoff from an abandoned heliport at the top of the mountain.

name: El Piedrero SLP
desc: Rocky, hike up and find your spot.

name: Lombardía
desc: S, SW Semi desertic, mostly sunny, very hot

name: Bukit Jugra, Banting
desc:
Headwind facing south. Be careful if the wind is strong from S or SSE as there can be rotor coming off the small hill in front left side. In these conditions stay soaring over the launch and ridge area and don't fly out front left of the launch unless well above launch height. 
Be careful in strong East winds when landing as penetration can be difficult to make the landing. Can be bumpy on landing with strong thermals coming off. Avoid using to much break on landing approach

name: Bukit Naga
desc: N.E and S.W paragliders friendly

name: Bukit Dangdut, Seremban
desc: Small area only to fit one glider at a time.

name: Bukit Lohan Ulu, Ranau
desc: Wind started as early as 10am all day hot!!! rain unpredictable

name: Bukit Jeram
desc: The take off site is 1000 ft above sea level . It consist of 2   ridges running  in a line North to south 9 km and 4 km long. Take off is easy because wind direction will most of the time be headwind. towards east or west. and our country's dorminant wind is the Norh East Monsoon and South West monsoon. Most favourable for ridge soaring, Thermalling and x country.

name: Ruhiang Hill Tamparuli
desc:
Welcome to Ruhiang Hill Tamparuli
Elevation is 300m
360 degree Take Off
Many Koreans have test fly and they say
it is fantastic take off, will invite more koreans and counterpart to come to Ruhiang Hill Tamparuli. Weather forecast will be informed before take off by our instructor

name: Kokol Hill
desc: pls contact kota kinabalu paraglider for weather hazards

name: Bukit Simsim, Sandakan
desc: SLOPE TAKE OFF

name: Gunung Ledang
desc: Take off is at 1052 Meters ASL. landing 70 meters ASL. GPS coordinates:N2 21.962 E102 36.549 Launch is quite steep facing South East and Intermediate or over only. Caution when wind over 15klm hr from SE S SW. Ridge will be soarable if wind is S SE so its still flyable and can make landing ok if good height reached and heading SW along the ridge. If heading straight out from launch in this condition penetration over the jungle to reach landing maybe difficult. Beginners should not fly in these conditions and again, not recommended site for beginners. Landing is easy reached on no wind straight flight out on a sledie and usually have a good height of 200M to 300M or more by the time you reach it. Flyable if wind from the back N NW NE if light, but watch for strong sink is its stronger.

name: Cameron Highlands
desc: There is a small ridge top airstrip and can launch from the edge of this.

name: Bukit Ramli
desc: take off is very easy as this site has been develop by land owner. Never fly behind of the hill as there's pylon alongside of the hill but it is safe if you could gain height...

name: Kg. Lohan, Ranau
desc: All kind of vehicles can access untill Take-off. 5 minits from landing to TO..can lay out 4 glider in a time, with grass. very bald hill, easy for top landing. stones n rockc area at landing

name: Lambayan
desc: easy..facing the sea..sea breeze soaring no

name: Mount Kinabalu South Peak
desc: Sloap on rocky mountain Clouds and strong wind

name: Sedili
desc:
Just outside the south fence (to the right facing the sea) of the resort is a cleared hill. At the top is a grassy launch. This is suitable for ridge soaring the large ridge to the south or for low wind sled rides to the beach and ground handling. 

Alternatively, it is possible to do launches from the grounds of the resort in the right winds for experienced pilots. This is only for NE winds onto the ridge directly under the resort.

name: Bukit Batu Reput
desc: The TO is facing N for best condition although NE would still be possible.

name: Hijauan Heights, Pedas
desc: The TO is situated at 800ft ASL, with launch direction of S, SW and W. Best wind direction for soaring would be W. Plenty of space at TO area, could accommodate several pilots at once.

name: Kuala Kubu Bharu
desc:
The TO situated at 1,400ft ASL facing South, South-West. Accessible by 4x4 car from LZ and plenty of space for about 30 pilots to gather, about 3 gliders laid at the setup area. Plenty of lift upon launching and can easily climb to 2,000-3,000ft ASL before approaching LZ. Kuala Kubu Bharu is water collection area for the nearby dam and it is often raining in the evening. Clouds can build quite fast here so it's always good to study the local weather and observe the cloud formations before flying.

Please check weather forecast at Windfinder or Meteoblue to plan your trip.

name: Gunung Jerai
desc:
The TO is situated at 2,200ft MSL facing NW, however it is still possible to launch on N and W winds.

The access is via the only road up to the mountain and then a 10 minutes trek to the TO from the designated parking area. Rain and strong winds, as usual.

name: Bukit Bidong
desc: The TO is situated at about 195m ASL facing E and the hill is located about a few kilometers from the sea, therefore the prevailing wind will be quite laminar for an easy top-to-bottom slide down.

name: Canang Hill
desc:
N 05 27.315'
E 116 10.025'
altitude 702m ASL This site is flyable with East and northeast wind. Thermal are abundant and sometimes very strong. Not suitable for beginners

name: Tiogon Hill
desc:
N 5 26.239
E 116 8.987
ALTITUDE 768M ASL wind pattern over keningau valley is unpredictable. Different wind direction at take off and LZ is normal. Watch windsock carefully before do final approach. Ask local pilot before flying here. This site is different!

name: Bukit Genting
desc: Takeoff is situated at 300m ASL facing NW, left of a restaurant and with a clear view of LZ areas between paddy fields. Access to TO is via tarmac road to the restaurant. Rain and strong wind, the usual culprits of parawaiting in this part of the world. Frequent checks on windyty.com or windfinder would help to plan your flights here or contact local flying groups for further info.

name: Bukit Bubus
desc:
The TO is situated on small hill 100ft ASL facing NE and receiving a constant, all day long wind from the sea.

Launch area is spacious, easy to launch and easy to stay airborne using dynamic lift. When enough height, it is possible to hop to the adjacent hill for longer ridge soaring.

This site is very suitable for tandem flights for its spacious launch area, easy dynamic lifts for long airtime and spacious LZ. Rain, especially during monsoon season between November-February

name: Gunung Raya
desc:
The TO is situated at 900m MSL facing West, though due to the clearance of the area it is possible for NW and SW wind take-off.

From the car park, pilots need to walk about 200m to the launch area. Strong winds and rain.

name: Catembe
desc: About 40 mt hight, ENE orientation.

name: Morongulu beach dune
desc: Dune overlooking the sea Strong wind from the sea

name: Bazaruto Dune
desc: Walk to the top of the dune, look left and right, get your groove on and launch anywhere you want.  Like Dune Du Pyla but 10 times bigger!  No need for helmet or even shoes!  Land right where you take off. Low pressure systems come through about every 10 days.  Forecasted well in advance and easy to see coming.  Can blow hard for 2-3 days.  Bring your speed wing!

name: Spreets Hoogte
desc: Rocky take-off alongside the road Strong winds, particularly strong thermals (12m/s and more is common)

name: Vogelberg
desc: On the large space on top of the rock. It is a soaring site but be aware that the desert around can heat up and develop dangerous thermals!

name: Ouen Toro
desc:
On the Ouen Toro hill, 60m hight. See breezes strenghten the wind late in the morning and the site is no more flyable. Take care not to be trapped behind the ridges at this time, and ever.
The alarm signal comes from the sea as soon as the white caps appear, it's time to land.

name: Dzumac
desc:
At the top of Mt Ouamourai, 635m.
Take off covered with special weather resistant cloth. No trick on this site, but do not attempt to fly with easterly wind as you'll be leeward with really bad rotors on this side.
Windtalker Tel: 97.11.31

name: Kuendu Beach
desc: On the Fort Umbo hill, 120m. A little bumpy in the middle of the sunny days due to thermals comming from the landing field.

name: Mont Dore
desc: At the south end of the Mont Dore ridge, altitude 400m.

name: Gadji
desc:
The first one is at 100m on the ridge of the hill with a carpet.
The second one is on the top of the ridge at 200m (well oriented and very efficient with South-East wind conditions).
The last one is on the left side of the landing site, lower and East-oriented. Very efficient site with moderate South-East wind ; fly is possible from SSE to ESE but became dangerous with ENE wind.
When the white caps appear on the water, it's time to land.

name: Ga Kaleon

name: Barendeu
desc: 400 meters approx, on and old nickel mine. In the afternoon, the wind could be strong when landing in the coastal area.

name: Mont Tonta
desc:
There are 2 flat area at the summit of the Mt Tonta (old antenna place). The west one could be used for take off.
No difficulty if wind is > 5km from South, without any wind it could be harder because of the flat shape of the launch area...

name: Wijk aan Zee
desc:
The take-off is very crowded in the summer and there are many beach houses blocking access to the dunes, so you need to walk for a while before the houses stop. There is also a fence nowadays. Use the small space where the houses stop and the fence starts.
This WILL be crowded in nice summer days! Climbing over the fence at other areas is prohibited and may cause a fine. Strong wind and lower classed wings have only a small useable wind window. Too much and you get easily blown over the back. There are also sections in the dune who form nice venturis with low lift.

name: Zoutelande
desc: Takeoff is a small sandy patch on the edge of a fairly high (dutch standards) dune, next to the KNVvL information Board. (see picture) Watch for incomming winds on the ocean if the weather prediction indicates this. Pay attention to flying restrictions.

name: Plus4
desc: Details will be submitted soon Details will be submitted soon

name: Bruinehaar
desc:
On this flatland, Skyline Twente provides 2 winches that allow hanggliders and paragliders to takeoff up to a hight of more than 1 kilometer.
Two start-lanes, N-S and E-W, so flyable at all wind-directions. None

name: Giethoorn
desc: only take off by cable

name: Petten
desc: There are 25 kilometers of perfect soaring dunes in the north of holland.  Please respect these natural dunes witch they protect the lowlands.  Takeoff is prohibited only before the feet of the dunes, NOT ON TOP OF THE DUNES. Beware of turbulent wind behind the dunes.

name: Egmond aan Zee
desc:
From the beach entry you need to walk a while first till the omnipresent beach houses stop in summer. You will see the other paragliders and should try to only use these areas for launch.
Entering the dunes is prohibited otherwise and the paragliding activity is only tolerated.
Good summer days see quite some crowding, as this is the also quite well known 'sister' site of Wijk aan Zee. High winds - not flyable in 'normal' winds...

name: Eurofly Stegeren
desc:
Eurofly paragliding have their start and takeof for flatland paragliding (towing) on a field at the adress:
- Verlengde Elfde Wijk in the city of Stegeren
The field is orientated north/south, but because of the width of the field and the towing technics used starts can be made from most wind directions. 

1200 mtr winching posibilitys

Home base of Eurofly (www.eurofly.nl). 
Flying at Friday-afternoon, saturdays and sundays. Call for flight information: 
+31 6 54 66 38 93

name: Mander

East - West
Very nice winching site (1000 mtrs)in the flatlands. The thermals are sometimes very good, and xc is popular here. Home base of cloudtocloud.nl. Flying on saturdays and sundays.

Evening breeze can pick up quickly. Strong wind from SV-N not recommended. Listen to experienced towing instructors!

name: Lensamansstarten
desc:
This takeoff can be challenging and in general this is considered to be an IPP3 takeoff! This is because the wind-conditions.

The take off is on en edge of a cliff, and the wind can be turbulent at the take off. An alternative take off can be found to the right of the normal take off. This has limits on the wind direction, but it quite a bit easier.

If uncertain, please contact the local club for more information Turbulent take off in some wind directions. On wind from SE the wall towards right can have a huge downdraft.

Normally used for SIV and acro.
It is suitable for experienced pilots.

The site is flyable all year around with good souring- and termic conditions. 
Skilift and gondola to takeoff.
Takeoffs next to the lift.

Man skal vÃ¦re oppmerksom pÃ¥, at ved sydlige vinder mer enn 5-6 ms i 800hPa, dannes det bÃ¸lgeaktivitet. (lenticler)
Yr.no har satt opp en mÃ¥lestasjon pÃ¥ Storhornet (1550 moh, 15 km luftlinje vest for Hovden) Denne mÃ¥ler vindstyrke og retning hver hele time. SÃ¸k pÃ¥ Oppdal, sÃ¥ finner du mÃ¥lestasjon litt ned pÃ¥ siden for tredagers varslet.

name: Hoven
desc: Det er flere mulige starter på Hoven, den ene ligger øst og litt nedenfor toppstasjonen for gondolbanen, de andre på vestsiden av restaurantbygningen. Det er også mulig å starte lenger vest på oppsiden av veien hvor det finnes noen starter som er "snillere" på dager med sterk termikk foran Hoven. Alle er naturstarter som ikke er bearbeidet, velg startsted som passer til vindretningen og dine ferdigheter. Startbare retninger er fra SØ via S til SV. http://holfuy.com/de/data/586

name: Ramnan (Alomar observatory), Andøya
desc:
Welcome to Ramnan on Andøya. From Ramnan you can take off in almost every direction.
North east: Take off towards Andenes over the valley Bjørndalen and head out towards the main road. If you follow "Rambergsaksla", the ridge to NE, you can find some nice soaring and hang areas on the edge.
East/South east: Take off from behind of the observatory (the higher plateau) and fly out towards Møsje.
West/north west: Take off from the take off zone by the observatory and fly west towards Bleik. Watch out for turbulence and rotors by the edge of the mountain. Andøya is unfortunately known for its not so good weather. Visit https://www.yr.no for the latest weather report. There is also possible to check out the METAR or AIRMET for Andøya airport. Alomar observatory also has its own weather station where it's possible to see real time wind etc. Link to the weather station on Alomar: http://128.39.135.4/weatherstation.

name: Arnipa
desc: Welcome to Arnipa on Andøya. From Arnipa you can take off in almost every direction. It takes about 15-20 minutes to walk up from the main parking site in the north. North/North east: Take off towards the valley and head towards the road. You can land on the bog. East/South east: This area is best for soaring, and can be quite funny! Towards the south can it be quite steep so possibilities for some turbulence in the area. The whole mountain is covered in sharp rocks, so be aware! Andøya is unfortunately known for its not so good weather. Visit https://www.yr.no for the latest weather report. There is also possible to check out the METAR or AIRMET for Andøya airport. The best day for Arnipa is when the wind is coming from East/south east.

name: Sarangkot
desc:
There are several take-offs by the side of the road that climbs from Pokhara to Sarangkot, follow the paragliders and birds. Expect many tandems and solo pilots during tourist season. Constant weather with every day thermal system (rarely broken if strong inversion occurs).

Monsoon rain season is from may to October. There will be water on all the rice fields.

name: Diki Danda
desc: Small land near the school. Enough for one glider at at time, perhaps two. It can get windy so it can be a bit of a rough take off, but generally easy.

Easy.
It is north south facing hill with a  regular  wind. It is posssible to top land.

desc: Small take-off... little bit technical, not for beginners!!! 090-360-270 no flyable... No problem, because usually wind come from south and there will be flyable almost everyday during the season Sept/Oct---May....

name: Mandredhunga
desc: This site is not frequently flown. It was popular as a training site for altitude flights. No tandem company operates there.

name: Toripani
desc: Ample slope with room for a few gliders. As this used to be a training site for altitude flights, it can be considered an easy takeoff. Nowadays (2016) the place is used by some companies to do tandem flights.

name: Mardi Himal - High Camp
desc: Located at 3550m ASL in the high camp of the Mardi Himal (a 5555m high Nepali trekking peak), this is a hike and fly take off that requires previous planning and typically a 2-day hike. As such, it is not frequently flown, however a few flights are done from this site every year, as can be seen in online databases like Leonardo or XContest.org.

name: Rainaskot
desc: Very friendly village. 2 takeoffs. Easy top landing.

name: Dharan
desc:
There is one (or more?) flying site between Dharan and Bhedetar. Please update this map if you know the exact location.
Professional tandem company: Dharan Sky Adventure Paragliding

name: Elorrio-Udalatx
desc: Udalatx Mountain in Elorrio (Basque Country)

name: Treble Cone
desc: pub corner 500m before TC ski field. Possible to take off towards NE and SE. Strong W winds.

name: Dills Hill
desc:
Site Rating:
  PG: P.G.2
  HG: Novice

Takeoff height is 700ft ASL and 400ft above the landing paddock. Be careful of scratching low down amongst the spines if the wind is very cross.

There is a good top landing in the paddock to the left of takeoff however do not go behind the crest on the top landing as this can be expensive in aluminium and pride. Although there are a number of possible landing paddocks take care to thoroughly scrutinise these on foot beforehand as some have little streams and gullies running through them plus a few bulls! If the wind is off to the east - southeast landing can be turbulent.

name: Paeroa Range
desc: Awesome high site, that just seems to draw thermals to it.

name: Queenstown - Crown Terrace
desc:
West wind , need quite a bit for soaring

rather small but not much too difficult watch white caps on the lake give you good indication of wind coming. white caps: DON T FLY! too strong.

name: Allendale
desc:
Summit road  - 1 km south of the radar (big green ball at the summit)
Lower takeoff is best in light winds.
On the top takeoff keep the 'runway' clear for top landings.

name: Barnett Park
desc: summit road - watch for white caps on the Sea to check wind velocity.

name: Taylors Mistake
desc: 2km from Evans Pass on the road to Godley Head. Watch for white caps on the sea to check wind velocity.

name: Moirs Hill
desc:
Site Rating:
  PG: P.G.2
  HG: Intermediate

Takeoff is at 1,050ft ASL, 800ft above the landing paddock.

name: Maioro
desc:
Site Rating:
  PG: P.G.2
  HG: Novice/Intermediate

name: Castle Rock
desc: 1km West of the Mt Cavendish Gondola. Do not fly in NW winds. Landing area can become turbulent if the the sea breeze comes in.

name: Mt Cheeseman
desc: Drive up the Mt Cheeseman ski field road to the locked gate, then walk a few hundred meters to the ski field base station.

name: Glover Park (G-spot)
desc: Demanding Cliff launch suitable for experienced pilots. Difficult top landing behind tree line in compression zone and through rotor Takes N to ENE. Because of cliff launch can be difficult to takeoff when strong and if wind increases getting blown back is very hazardous.

name: Piha North
desc: Cliff site on private site Only takes S. SW will have rotor on the takeoff.

name: Puketutu
desc:
TEMPORARILY CLOSED FOR LAMBING.  Enter with permission, but animals not to be disturbed.

Access to the NW launch ( and a short walk around to the NE launch) can be gained by following the signs to Mt William walkway at the end of Puketutu Rd.

name: Karioitahi A
desc: The 'High Site' also known as 'The Main Cliff', 300 m north of the access road. (Used by PGs when wind is too light for the other launch sites).

name: Karioitahi E
desc: The top take-off located at the top of the cliff.(This is the main Karioitahi HG launch site.)

name: Port Waikato
desc:
On arrival at Sunset Beach there is a grassed area to the left of the toilet block and, on the southern side of this grassed area a private driveway access and little bridge across a small creek. Pass beyond the small bridge and you will find the obscure beginnings of the track which runs up through toitoi bushes and along the ridge heading south from the beach.

Hang gliders have previously used a launch located a short way along this track. This small launch area is on the edge of the cliff and is unsuitable for paragliders. The second top takeoff point is further up the same track where it exits the bush onto a large rounded hilltop.

On strong days it is also possible to launch from the sand dunes immediately in front of the cliffs to the left of the carpark and beach entrance area.

name: Coronet Peak
desc:
SUMMER time, carpark #4 or rocky gully, or hike to top of mt. wind mostly S.

WINTER time, top of mt either green gates or back saddle. wind mostly N, but sometimes S North W North E strong rotor.

name: Van Ash
desc: On the side of the road leading to Taylors Mistake take off. Do not fly NW or NE 10km+

name: Cass Bay
desc: 400 meters east of the Castle Rock car park on the Summit Road. Best flying is in light or dropping S to SW winds. Wind speed can increase rapidly here but this is easily seen on the water of Lyttleton harbour. If the wind is W of SW expect significant turbulence. Do not fly in NW winds.

name: Britten Reserve
desc: 500 meters East of the gondola on the Summit Road. Do not fly in NW winds. Ensure that wind is not SW by driving to Bridle path first.

name: Scarborough Cliffs
desc: Take the road to Taylors Mistake beach from Sumner, look for the track down to the left about 400 meters from the high point of the road. Take-off can be turbulent if wind is N. If E wind picks up pilot can get trapped at the N end.

name: Takaka Hill
desc:
Approx 960m
Faces SW
Be aware of 2 sets power lines. One crossing from saddle to valley the other a single wire from antennas on summit. Be aware of sea breeze coming over from eastern side and southerlies from over the back.
In summer the valley breeze can be strong.
Be aware of small planes crossing over and using saddle road as reference.

name: Mt Murchison
desc:
At summit of Mt Murchison.
approx 1450 metres

name: Barnicoat
desc:
Very sensitive site due to proximity of airport.  The control tower MUST be contacted by phone (035470799 ext 9)before take off.  Obtain briefing from loclal club ( http://www.thgpc.org.nz/ ) or from local pilot. Don't fly in winds east of north.
Be aware of strengthening sea breeze in summer.
Watch for signs of SW winds.

name: Ohope
desc:
This site is largely abandoned due to the actions of the hostile property manager.

There is also the matter of the large step in the front face causing all sorts of substantial rotor in the launch area.  

If you can get airborne from the public lookout or some other way, then go for it, but otherwise enter onto this property at your peril.

name: Kohe Point
desc:
Launch area is a little scruffy, steep, and restricted in size.  

No overrun, due trees immediately below launch - requires enough wind to lift you off your feet and a firm run or you will be treed right on the edge of the cliff!  Zero-wind launches are out of the question.  Minimum wind 10km/hr approx, or at pilots' discretion. The LZ next to the marae can be turbulent.

name: Bird's Clearing
desc: Requires permission for access from landowner.

name: Pukerua Bay escarpment
desc: Please contact a member of the Wellington Hang Gliding and Paragliding Club BEFORE flying at this site!  http://www.paraglidingearth.com/pgearth/index.php?club=1080

name: Maketu
desc: Flat area right on the edge of the ridge. Lots of rotor on lifting your wing, and a sharp lift/rotor spike 50 meters to your right after launch.

name: Mount Maunganui
desc:
Assorted flat area for takeoff and top-land.
See flight regulations below BEFORE takeoff.

name: Hamurana
desc:
Te Waerenga Road / Hoko Road Airstrip - Unknown and UNFLOWN Development Site.
Would a SO or PG3 please check this ridge out. There is no wind meter nearby that can be used for this site.  If you know of a nearby weather station, ask its' owner to broadcast to the MADIS or windfinder sites, and then that data will appear here automatically.
Alternatively, if you live locally, then consider donating a windmeter to someone near the LZ.

name: SnowPark
desc: On the right side of the car park

name: Raglan
desc: Easy takeoff from reserve adjacent carpark.

name: Bobs Hill
desc: Lots of space on the top of the ridge for takeoff.

name: Rogers Road
desc: Selection of low-level sand dunes to play on.  Varies 5-20 meters Alt.

name: Turangi Road
desc:
Unknown and unflown Development Site.

20-30M cliffs NE-facing in this area.

name: Urenui
desc:
This is not a site.  This is a reference to this whole sea-side area - NW to WNW facing 20-200M cliffs for many km to the North, MIGHT support some really epic soaring trips, possibly 50km the way up to Mokau or futher!

Unflown and unresearched.  SO or PG3 or higher to fly and document. Could be anything!

name: Ohiwa Hill (Onekawa Pa)
desc:
Take-off from the flat top of the Pa site or, if the wind is strong, a little lower on the hill facing NW. Take-off direction should always be towards Whale Island (the closest island you can see in NW direction) to avoid tall trees. Do not take off towards the fence and trees in a straight-north direction (big chance of sinking into the tall Pohutekawas after takeoff).

Best place to lay-out your glider is on the very back (S) ridge of the site, as far towards the west as possible. Airflow is cleanest there and take-off easiest.

To get your bearings on this site; White Island (Whakaari) is straight north. This is the puffing active volcano about 50 km off the coast. On some hazy days you can't see it, but it's pretty much straight out to the ocean (90 degrees on the beach). Anything left of White Island is more towards the west, anything right of White Island is more towards the east (and if the wind is coming from there the site is not flyable, see "Weather" below).

Whale Island (Moutohora) is directly NW. Anything to the right of Whale Island is more towards the North, anything left of Whale Island is more towards the West. The end of Kohe Point ridge is WNW (and if the wind is coming from there it gets very turbulent, see "Weather" below). The site is good in a NNW-N. North gets very difficult to take-off, but once in front if will be super buoyant.

In NW it is recommended to not fly past the little spur towards the east (and into the bowl facing north). In a NW It gets very turbulent on the western side of the bowl, and if you get low you'll have to fight into wind to get on the windward side of the hill again.

When it gets more W (WNW or W), the hill still looks like it is flyable, but in fact isn't. You'll notice very quickly if you take-off anyway; turbulent in front of the hill with very little lift.

As soon as there is a bit of E component, it gets almost impossible to take-off. There is no take-off possibility towards the NE at all. Even if you are able to take-off towards the NW in these conditions, you will fly straight into a big turbulent, rotory sink hole. You'd have to fly through all that around the corner towards the east to find marginal lift. Not worth it.

The prevailing wind in summer is NW-NNW due to the seabreezes. The seabreeze usually starts every sunny day between 10 and 11 AM, and stops about 30 minutes to an hour before sunset. BEWARE of a sudden wind direction change when the seabreeze stops: It is not uncommon to have a nice 12 knot NNW seabreeze turn into a nasty 22 kts southerly within minutes! You will feel it coming (starts to get turbulent, less lift, wind-lines on the ocean disappear or change direction suddenly), but it's safer to just be on the ground well before sunset.

It is very important to know how to read wind-lines on the ocean so you can determine the true wind direction. Because this is a steep hill with a flat top, the hill will "feel" flyable in most wind directions. Make sure you know the true wind-direction before you takeoff.

When in doubt; stop by the local pilots that live in the two story house at nr 240 on the road towards the campground (you'll see the windsock on the harbour side). They will be able to tell you if the conditions are good or not.

name: Waiotahi
desc: Unknown, unflown development site.

name: Matata
desc: Actual takeoff site is not particularly apparent even when you walk right across it, nor is the walkway particularly well defined.  You will need a proper site briefing to visit here.

name: Newdicks
desc: A little tight takeoff near trees.  PG3 or SO to comment.

name: Puheke
desc: Gorse weeds cover much of the mound and the fields below but there is a large grassy section on the south slope which can be accessed from the top.  The top has tall grass and is gorse free.

name: Shipwreck Bay
desc: Unflown development site

name: Opotiki Airport
desc: Unknown development site

name: Little Waihi
desc: Unknown, unflown development site.

name: Braemar Road
desc: Tight takeoff.  Unflown development site.  PG3 to develop and advise. Really big step in hill.  Rotor everywhere.

name: Tarawera
desc: No one had flown this before. Wind can and will change really rapidly in here.

name: Putauaki
desc: Don't know.  No pilots have been here.

name: Kaupok
desc: Possible launch point for substantial southbound ridge-soar. Lots of rotor from pointy headland bits scattered all along this coastline.

name: Mokau
desc: Large takeoff area available at the summit. Full weather http://tinyurl.com/d34gjy2

name: Mokau Cemetery
desc: Two-minute drive off the state highway.  Easy takeoff from flat grassy area, and knee-high fence you can step over. Full weather details http://tinyurl.com/d34gjy2

name: Alex Knob
desc:
Flat grass area looking East North and west . Kea flying...
Very easy and clean.
might be a bit wet in the morning. beware of the catabatic wind (down the glacier).

name: Tapawera
desc:
On slope beside forestry road. Sea breeze in summer.
Go to top and check wind direction.

name: Taupo Urban
desc:
Downtown Urban site.  Needs plenty of on-shore breeze to be flyable, which means experts only.

Assorted takeoffs scattered along the foreshore.  Please don't screw up your groundhandling and end on the road in front of cars! Only flyable in strong wind - caveat emptor.

name: Whakaipo Bay
desc: Large grassy park area?  To be explored.

name: Cliff Rd-Glover park
desc:
Takeoff is from a small grass area behind a low post and cable
fence.  The Launch is a bit tricky as it's a table-top and you must pull up through the rotor.  There is a road directly behind launch so you must check for cars before launching. Gusts activity is visible on the water so keep a good lookout.

name: White Horse
desc: Take off either above the white horse or by the tower

name: Ocean Beach
desc: No access without prior authorisation - contact a local.

name: Bridges
desc: Please always call at the farm house before proceeding, site owners Mark and Poppy Keskic are very friendly. The takeoff at the top of the hill is 900 foot A.S.L. Vehicles can be driven up only in very dry conditions, but it is extremely rough and you require a 4 Wheel Drive with a good muffler clearance (or just an attitude). Please note that access is via the cattle race. Do not attempt to drive vehicles in or out during milking time - around 4pm.

name: The Gondola (Christchurch)
desc: About 100m to the North East of the gondola restaurant. There is a grassy spot on the dirt road that is cleared. Do not fly in strong winds. Watch the rotor to the west of the knob over the gondola lines in an NE wind. Do not fly if winds are NW

name: Musick Point
desc:
A bit dodgy, but it works if the tide is out and the wind is in the correct direction (NE to E).  On a good day, can fly from the tip all the way back to the beginning of the golf course. You could probably go further, but I've never done it personally.

Highly unofficial launch: Please be careful not to conflict with the golf club, as the land belongs to them.

name: Shakespear Regional South
desc: Wide grassy area

name: Duders Peninsular
desc:
Take-off height at the northerly site is 280 foot A.S.L, normally in front of the trig, although the bowl immediately to right can be used also.
HG vehicles to be kept to a minimum. Drive slowly up the track towards the Trig. Park before the trig. DO NOT DRIVE PAST THE TRIG because the road there is subsiding and there are serious OSH issues involved. In other words, there is vehicle access to the northerly site, but you have to park before you come to the trig.   
When the wind is square in (northerly) the whole Peninsula can be flown, if it is off to the north west or north east it will be marginal going around to and back from the eastern end. Take-off heights at the south easterly site is 180 foot A.S.L, adjacent to the top dressing fertiliser bins. The best top landing is also in this area so vehicles should be parked as close as practical to the bins. Glider Types: 
Hang Glider
Paraglider
Site Rating: 
HG Intermediate
PG2
PG2 + 30 hours
Site Type: 
Coastal
Wind Directions: 
N
SE

name: Centennial Park
desc: Right from the roadside

name: Rees Valley Slopes Above Shelter Rock
Fazayah Bay
desc: 1 km above the arabian sea Because of strong thermals flying in Oman is only recommended for XC Pilots!!!

name: Eftalquot Beach
desc: 100, above the sea

name: Cerro Vigia
desc:
S,SE,SO,E,NE,N,NO Strong wings from the north east. Carefull for over developing clouds and thunder storms.

There is towers with cables lines and AC power lines. get in contact with the locals.

name: Jangas
desc: Smooth slope to launch from.  Just perfect.  You will see it, there is no development, but the launch is clean and easy. Beware of really strong (N) winds in the main valley.  Serious high altitude landing no matter where you land.  The valley floor is close to 10,000 ft.

name: Miraflores
desc: The take-off is a relatively small circle of grass specially for paragliding. The take-off is easy but it does get busy with tandem pilots. About 85m. Ask the local pilots.

name: Pachacamac
desc: The Take off area is in the middle of the mountain 'Punta Blanca'. Its a little spot, but easy to lunch. In summer time it is very dusty, but in winter time there are a lot of veggetation, so the glider doesnt get dirty. None

name: Chupuro
desc: Altitude: 3900 amsl. Taking off is really easy. It is a great valley. The season runs between May and September, when is sunny and clear, with stable thermals of +4 and even +6 m/s.

name: Ayacucho
desc: The take off is situated at 40 minutes from the town of Ayacucho.  On a hilltop at 3500 m that's named after the town that lays behind.  'Campanallo'.  The Takeoff has a triangle shaped area and lays just above the road that's takes you there. It's facing north from where the wind usely comes all year around. in flying season almost none. possibility of big rainclouds in the late afternoon coming from the south.  Ayacucho lays in a kind of valley and you can see clouds forming on all horizons.  In wintertime that's when its best for flying you have open skies most of the time with an average cloudcoverage of 20%

name: Cerro Sacro
desc: A not-so-grassy slope with room for 2 to 4 gliders. Nice inclination. Lines can get caught with roots and outcropping rocks, but not too bad. There are a few telecom towers just besides the slope. EXTREMELY DANGEROUS: There is a virtually invisible abandoned zip line that runs from somewhere below the take off to the valley floor (beyond the landing). Such line cuts through the main landing field (as marked in this website). If you are not 100% certain of where the line is, use an alternative field. Also keep it in mind if you happen to be scratching near the slope. See a diagram showing this in the pictures section.

name: Wamantanga
desc: easy, near a big cross at Wamantanga

name: Punaruu 600
desc: Punaruu 600

name: Punaruu 350
desc: le 350

name: Tautira
desc: 180 m facing north

name: Mt Marau
desc: ENGLISH please!

name: Le belvedere
desc: DZ hÃ©lico

name: Vaiare
desc: au dessus de la baie de l'arrivÃ©e des ferry

name: autemanu
desc: pointe Matira

name: taiohae
desc: derriere chez GENDRON

name: Tubuai
desc: deco TAMATOA

name: Tefarerii 60
desc: deco EST

name: 350 SAGE
desc: 350 au dessus du lotissement SAGE

name: 900 To'a Rotu Rahi
desc: More than 830m, a wonderful and unforgettable view.

name: Kasay beach flight park
desc: Launch is at +300meters. Area is covered by very low grass. Flyable wind direction is northeast and eastnorthest. Skill level required is novice and up. This site is good between October and May during the northeasterly wind season.

name: Dingalan
desc: Launch is +250 meters asl covered by low grass. Very wide area to set up and do ground handling. Flyable for eastnortheast and northeast wind direction. Fly only between October to May.

name: Montalban
desc: Launch is +400 meters, usually a 4X4 drive up. Flyable for west and southwest wind direction. Another take of more to the north also exists for more northerly winds. Fly this site between June and October. This is the rainy season and over-development is frequent: be there early enough.

name: Nabas
desc: Take off is at +250 meters. Flayable for east,eastnorteast and northeast winds. Small area on take off. For novice and above pilots only. Fly this area between November to may only.

name: Carmona
desc:
Ridge faces East, E or SE winds are good. Ridge soaring is common, cooler towards late afternoon, less thermic.
Some huge Thermals mid afternoon if you like. Mainly flyable from November to about June, depends on the monsoons.

name: Punod
desc: The take off area is fairly small due to the shape of the mountain, but if the wind is good, it should be safe. (See photos) This site is at around 2,300 ft above sea level, and can often suffer from showers if low cloud is coming over. Otherwise it is as one would expect from a tropical area: One must always keep an eye out for changing conditions.

name: Nataban Peak
desc:
Launch can be made from anywhere on the top of the ridge around the centre section of the bowl where the ground is covered by grass. The best location will depend on the actual wind direction on the day. The easiest time to launch tends to be the first part of the morning before the cloud development takes place and thermals start. Once the thermals start to 'kick in', watch out for sudden changes in wind direction, as if the wind swings round to the West (or even NW), then the wind in the bowl below ridge level can become quite turbulent and rough.
The terrain to the East of the site drops away sharply, and you must be careful not to enter this area unless the wind direction is East of South.
All commerical aircraft are flying at high altitude in this location, but do keep an eye out as I have seen military helicopters operating close by on a previous occasion.

name: safi ranch
desc: About 970feet ASL with multiple take-off site facing South-East facing Sarangani bay.  a combination of sea breeze and thermal wind condition. Maybe thermic and bumpy during the peak of Sun normally 9AM to 3PM'ish.

name: Marcillia
desc:
Nice take of at only 10mn walk from the road.
altitude 178m fly there when the Wind is Est to Est-NordEst.
The Wind is in the same direction of the breezes so don't go when the alize is too strong (max 20kms)

name: St Nicholas valley
desc:
Watch the pic for dÃ©tails ;)

Attention! Go to the highest dome (180m), the 3rd. Before that , the direction of the air does not reflect the reality.

Just after the summit, a dome with a gentler slope will help you to take off with all the security need for all levels, aroud the others slopes are very steep.

If the wind is really West it flies well in thermal but it's better to go to another takeoff further, on the next hill. There are plenty of possible landings aroud...

For a Est Wind,go to the 3rd take off, good for soaring. Take off is accessible by road from the airport (km 18) turl right on the dirt road. at the bottom near river, the hill will be on your left. The east wind is less strong in this valley.It allows to fly when it's too much strong evrywhere else!

name: Puro island, Tablas,
desc: possible to takeoff at the top but very small ridge so easier to takeoff down the slope where there is a area that is not so steep.

name: NOAH flysite
desc: 1,050feet ASL Shifting winds through out the days progression.

name: Omaya mountain
desc: Find a place with not to many stones and not to high grass.

name: Labney Grassy mountain
desc:
Walk up a grassy ridge. Start on the top. Watch out for sharp stones under the grass.

Easy walk along a small trail. Gets smaller and smaller. One small river to pass.

name: Labney jungle start
desc: the start is cut out of the jungle.

name: Mambajao
desc: Drive up from Mambajao to the volcano observatory. Park just 50m past this on the RHS.  Walk across and up the slope to a gentle rounded take-off area Strong thermal activity during the day

name: Mike V FlySite
desc:
Take Off lunch 18Meters AGL

Easy for takeoff just walk up stairs 30-40steps. Takeoff technique. upon takeoff crab to the right then you when you get the lift Crab to the right towards the jungle then there is a lot of lift. Veny nice wind no turbulent even in thermic day.30ft above the ground there is a lift!! Dont fly in not flyable condition. and When you fly, if the wind getting strong land emediatly before you're blowing back to the mountain.

name: Pitogo Point, Tabugon, Tablas Island.
desc: Takeoff on the ridge Possible to fly comfortable from 10-14 kts, when wind is from NE-ENE it becomes little gusty from the island in front. Best and most stable wind direction is E-SE

name: Oslob, Cebu
desc: Facing NE, E, S. Sunrise take off, 7 am thermaling through 1 pm. After noon, extended sleddies; High Season starts Oct through May.

name: Mount Caniaw
desc: Takeoff from old basketball court. If not to strong east wind it's going to be a sea breeze(w).

name: Tubalina Pass
desc: Close to the road. right to small cottage. If not to strong east wind. The sea breeze(w) gives you a nice wind to start.

name: Rajdhani
desc: Amazing take off facing West. Best for midday and afternoon flying. This site is just above the Khanpur Lake. Acrobatic flying can be done very easily and best for cross country flying. Easy launch. Great Thermal activity in Summer season and in winters good soaring. Pilots have a very good time on this site. Good weather: 15 C to 34 C (winter and summer).

name: Birmoghlasht (Summer Palace)
desc: 2500 meters. Many areas on top of the ridge are suitable. Takeoff to North in morning and South for soaring in Evening. Big mountains, strong conditions.

name: Eagle's Nest
desc: Amazing Take off, just after taking one step after inflation, lift will take you up 100 meters just in seconds. This site requires high skill. Very strong conditions, and strong thermals. Take off is at the altitude of 2900 meters above sea level, and the ridge is more than 6000 meters above sea level. Good flying skills can help you in breaking altitude gaining record. World's altitude gain record is made on this site by Leroy Westercamp (Nederlands) in June 2006. Stong Conditions. Rocky mountains are all around. Thermal and ridge soaring is available.

name: Uttul
desc: Undeveloped but big and easy. Nearest town is Booni. Jeep from Booni costs around 1500 rupees and take 1hr 45min. Road is in good condition and leads to 2nd highest canal project in the world, was blocked by snow at 3600m in late May 2007. Open in June leads to top of ridge at 3850 meters. Facing South/SE. Morning site. Top landing possible all along ridge. Yes, very large mountains create strong conditions.

name: Kohala
desc: Easy east facing take off, 2300 feet above sea level. Good for early morning take offs. Not suitable after 11 AM.

name: Mung
desc: 3 Different slopes: 60 feet, 200 feet and 350 feet.

name: Express Way Site
desc: Very easy, grassy take off.

name: Shigar
desc:
Take off is approx 1.5 to 2 hours walk.  

Start at the quarry area 1km N of Shigar on the Askole road.

Start climbing the steep loose slopes above the quarry and immediately turn S to contour the slope and follow a path leadng S and up.

You can also go up the steep path directly (the way through the cliffs is easier than it looks) and then walk S on easier ground on the plateau above but this takes longer (maybe 2.5 hours)

A good take off facing S with some cleared ground (removed small herb plants) can be reached after about 1.5 to 2 hours.    Take off there or on the talus slope above.

The valley breeze was found to be from the NW on one occaission which was not expected but worked ok for this take off. 

Even though it faces S it didn't start working until 12pm.

It might be possible to find another take off site round on the SE face which works earlier Yes, lots. Plenty of safe landing options.   Very wide valley.

Skardu valley seems to get quite windy (40kph+) after 4pm and a strong and regular S wind blows down from the Deosai plains meets the W valley wind of the main Skardu valley.

Wind characteristics near to Shigar are not known sufficiently to comment.

name: Chunda
desc:
Take the main road W from Skardu for about 10km to village called Skardo on some maps (not sure if correct name)

Turn S on the tarmac road leading 1km up to the Army base.

Skirt the base on the right hand (W) side and follow a rough track for 500m.  At the fork take the track on the right leading up the hill and follow for 5km approx.    Perhaps 1hr by jeep from Skardu.

When you start to reach the irrigated zone of the Chunda valley stop and walk W up a gentle U shaped valley passing a cricket pitch to reach the lip overlooking the Skardu valley. Watch out for strong valley winds after 4pm

name: Choa Saidan Shah
desc:
3 different take off points (at different heights) are made for beginner and intermediate pilots.

name: Skrzyczne
desc:
There are 3 takeoffs.
1) N-NE about 50m down the black ski piste from the chairlift top station. Grassy lane with a lot of space, relatively flat. Start is very easy.
2) NE-SE a small spot East of the above launch. Quite steep. The launch is small (space for 2-3 wings) so on crowded days please do all prelaunch preparations on the North lane. Start is easy with E wind.
3) N-NW about 50m down the red ski piste from the chairlift top station. A lane with some grass and rocks, relatively flat. Start is easy with N-NNW directions, but may be challenging with more west wind (hazard of rotor from nearby trees).
Launching from ski pistes during the skiing season is prohibited.

name: Gdynia Orłowo - lower
desc:
You can take off from two grassy fields:
- first located on the left (two meters above promenade), after launch be aware of barriers, stick close to the trees, gain height and jump over big oak to the big cliff on the right
- second located on the right close to the monument, use a lot of power to forward launch (you will need it because there is rotor close to the ground) go through promenade between the trees. Its better choice when it is hard to start from the TO on the left (lower wind speeds)

Watch out for people crossing by! http://www.iopan.gda.pl/MarPoLab/wykresy/wykresy.php

name: Azinha
desc:
Flight conditions: Due to the South exposure, with the Sun heating the slope, and the orographic characteristics of the spot, it is possible to fly with any wind direction, if the meteorological wind speed does not exceed 15km/h. If the meteorological wind is also south then it should be limited to 20km/h, with the thermal activity adding up to it, it normally works all day. East wind works until 18h and North and West wind until 15h. Ideal forecast is a light south or westerly wind.
(©clubevertical.org)

name: Achadas da Cruz Cable Car
desc:
Near the cable cart. !!! REGARDING FLYING ON THE NORTH COAST !!!

Please take in consideration the following before attempting to fly on the north coast:
 
- Safe landing zones are very scarce, they are often very short, narrow and rocky.
- High tide levels can make them even shorter or completely disappear.
-The cloud base tends to form at low altitude, if youâ€™re flying and it happens below your flight level it can be disorientating
- The sea state ranges from moderate, 1.25 to 2.5 meters wave height, to very rought, 4 to 6 meters wave height. In the event of landing in the water it will be extremely difficult to reach the shore.
- Especially with lower pressure, wind speed and direction can change and consequently its effects on the sharp edges and abrupt orography of the coast can originate dangerous rotors and whirls.
 
We strongly advice all pilots, regardless of their level of experience, to contact AVLM before attempting to fly on the north coast to double check the weather conditions.

name: colimacon 800
desc:
alti: 770m
very good takeoff, big work for the most frequently site on this island. Aerology : Please, beware of strong North wind, you would be to leeward of a trees hedge during the first minutes\'flight.
Indeed watch the sea before taking off to check that there is no wind in St-Leu\'s bay. Frequently, and it is the danger of this site, everything is quiet at the takeoff and there is a 40 kph wind on the landing ground. In that case, please, land on parapente-Reunion hillside-school. (watch the thorny bushes all around !)

name: Saint Leu 1400
desc:
alti: 1370m
Situation : West coast - St LEU bay

GPS : WGS84 S -21.15094 - E 55.34269 

Altitude : 1 400 m ASL

Access : This site is situated above La Chaloupe village. Take the road to ColimaÃ§ons and keep going towards La Chaloupe. Once at the village, take Vaudeville road on the left. The site is about 4 km, on the right just by the road, look for a small wind sock. If you reach a concrete road, it means you went past the 1400, but you are now heading towards for the 1500... Aerology : The cloud cover may be very fast with ceiling between 900m and 1200m : Take off early, before any clouds form to avoid any surprise.
The risks are the same as for ColimaÃ§on site : everything is quiet on the takeoff, but there can be a lot wind on the beach. Please, always watch carefully the sea before taking off to make sure there is no strong wind at touch down. A look at the weather report, internet or other, is an additional safety measure...

name: dos d\'ane
desc:
alti: 900m
Access : Go to RiviÃ¨re des Galets village, then rise up to Dos d\'Ã¢ne church (40 minutes on foot).
Don\'t forget to stop at the bakery with a parapente decoration to taste the local speciality : Macatia.
Go down the concrete road, then go up the dirt track on the right-hand side for about 10 minutes. Possibility of bus, near the bakery of the RiviÃ¨re des Galets, it will take you up to the village of Dos d\'Ã¢ne. Aerology : You must be careful when the wind is coming from the North, it makes you pass to leeward of the crest to go up to the RiviÃ¨re des Galets. As to St-Leu, make sure that there is no strong wind on the sea which would risk to income during the flight. Avoid flying in this site by heavy thermal conditions because important venturi effect and turbulences in the heart of the river.

name: piton textor
desc:
Altitude : 2 169 m ASL
Situation : On the road to Piton de la Fournaise volcano
Access : Take the road to the volcano from Murat village, go past the RiviÃ¨re des Remparts point of view over RiviÃ¨re des Rempart. The Piton is on the left, about 3 km farther. It is locatable by pylones of Hertzian relays. Leave vehicles on road side and keep walking. Takeoff is made towards the back, in front of the Plaine des Palmistes. Aerology : As for all the sites over 1 500 meters ASL, it is necessary to arrive early because cloud formation can be very fast. If the wind comes from your right-hand side, you are to leewar of the peak, one contents so with admiring and one can attempt Piton Rond. Take off in breeze regime, it is sometimes necessary to wait for a moment before that is reversed, patience...

name: matouta
desc:
Situation : Takeoff at Matouta (Saint-Joseph). Landing at Basse-VallÃ©e (Saint-Philippe). 

GPS : WGS84 S -21.34662 - E 55.70227

Altitude : 461 m ASL


Access : Takeoff is on a mall round peak situated under Aerology : Toakeoff orientation : East-Southeast. Privileged meteorological conditions : dominant Wind coming from the North or from the South-Southeast. Sometimes a West-Southwest wind can bring a return of South-Southeast. Possibility of soaring by steady wind, over the take-off and behind Piton Bernard can gain height. It is also possible in the first two thirds of the course between takeoff and landing on the cliff situated in border of the R.N. 2. By sunny weather, thermical currents are generous above Matouta hamlet and Basse-VallÃ©e village. They are stronger when sugar cane fields are cut.

name: maido
desc:
Altitude : 2 200 metres ASL
Situation : West region (St-Paul)
Access : Accesses to Maido peak are particularly well indicated from St Paul or St Gilles by the Route du ThÃ©Ã¢tre, thanks to the orange-coloured road signs which will guide you up to the summit. The site is 1 km downstream to the summit. Park your vehicle just before the exit of the forest and take the road on your left, you will arrive on the site after 10 minutes of walking on foot. Aerology : Plan to arrive early at the takeoff, the aerology strengthening quickly in the morning. A meteorological beacon (143.9875) (regrettably being repaired for the moment), gives you force and direction of the wind every quarter of an hour. By West wind, northwest (coming from your left-handler in the takeoff) you will be in front of wind to leave RiviÃ¨re des Galets, strong turbulences are guaranteed before every crest. Reserved for the experimented pilots. Please, rather go and admire the magnificent point of view over Mafate\'s cirque and come down again by car to bathe in the lagoon. You will enjoy flying tomorrow !
Before flying from MAIDO, please, contact local paragliders, they will give you tips and may even come to fly with you, if you provide the shuttle for them...

name: plaine des gregues
desc:
Altitude : 948 m
Situation: Site of Bel-Air holiday resort 
Access: Coming from Petite ÃŽle : Take CD 31. After the church take Chemin Dauphin on the right. After about 800 m, turn to the left in Chemin Denis Leveneur (not very easy to spot, about 300 m after second hairpin curve on a straight line). The CD 3 will be perpendicular to you, turn to the right, then, after 50 metres, take the Relay lane on the left. From there, you will cross the picnic area of the Relay, then a Aerology : 1- Dominant meteorological wind come from the North, Southeast, South and sometimes Southwest in the West which can create a Southeast return. The presence of foam on the sea does not apparently prevent the exploitation of the site, on the condition of not going down on the coast. On a cloudy day, easy takeoff for a pure soaring in the air laminaire which allows to enjoy for a long time effortlessly. On a sunny day, caution in the takeoff because of squalls due to the thermal currents. In this type of flight it is important not to fly to leward relief, because nasty cuttings watch for the parapentiste which manages to rise higher than the crest side sea ! 
2- A zone of weak wind allows the exploitation of considerable thermical currents. However, the takeoffs are more unpredictable because of the possible inversion of the direction of the breeze. There are remedies to this phenomenon : Eithet you take off before the cirque warms up too much, either you take off when there is no breeze. This kind of condition allows you to acquire height and pass in transit towards the coast 8 km from there, or join the mountainous relief and see other skies.

name: piton entonnoir
desc:
Situation : BÃ©zaves village (above Saint Joseph) This site is fitted out, covered and maintained by the the nearness of a water tank, situated between two peaks. From Saint-Pierre, the dÃ©co is on the right peak. Take the RD3, just before the bridge over RiviÃ¨re des Ramparts and follow the road indications Aerology : Takeoff orientation : Southeast in the South.
The most favorable period is from September till December, from 10 o\'clock when sugar cane fields are cut. During other seasons, especially when everything is green, is is better to wait until noon except when the wind allows soaring. 
Privileged meteorological situations : dominant meteorological Wind from the North in Northeast creating a protected zone under the wind, light wind from Southeast in the South or baromÃ©trique swamp.
In some ways, by strong conditions, this site has a certain resemblance with that from BellemÃ¨ne to Saint-Paul. Same typical takeoff which allows to reach the downstream cliffs with difficulty if one risks taking off when there is no thermic and where the breeze or the wind fall again in rollers on the top of the cliff, putting back down the poor hangglider. If the crenel is judicious, ascent is made immediately or between the dÃ©co and the cliff. The ascent is favored by the presence of Piton de l\'Entonoir, situated on the West by the dÃ©co and higer, on which you can lean.

name: bellemene
desc:
Altitude : 730 metres ASL
Situation : In the heights of Saint-Paul.
Private hillside-school, property of AZURTECH hang-gliding school. Access free for all qualified and insured pilots.
Official takeoff for local and international competitions from the top of the school-slope.

Flight schedule : 
You can stay playing over the school-slope or make soaring on the cliff before landing at Savannah or Tour des Roches landing ground. Beware, without any thermal current, reaching the cliff from the top of the school slope is impossible for some wigs. What is more, a medium tension Ã©lectric line is on the way... Reserved for good pilots. For the others it is recommended to take off from the 920 (click to see), it is quite safer.
Otherwise, it is a superb Aerology : This site is situated in the North-West of the island, so we fly to leeward when meteorological incoming wind comes from South-East or East.
When the wind comes from South-SouthEast, (during trade wind period, from June to September) beautiful confluence could happen on the left. Then, you will fly in a North return, more adapted situation on this site, particularly because of the cliff orientation.
When the wind is East-NorthEast, confluence zone can be clearly seen on the right, then you will fly in a South return.
Otherwise you will be in a pure breeze regime.

Flight schedule : 
You can stay playing over the school-slope or make soaring on the cliff before landing at Savannah or Tour des Roches landing ground. Beware, without any thermal current, reaching the cliff from the top of the school slope is impossible for some wigs. What is more, a medium tension Ã©lectric line is on the way... Reserved for good pilots. For the others it is recommended to take off from the 920 (click to see), it is quite safer.
Otherwise, it is a superb

name: colimacons 1500
desc:
Situation : West coast, St Leu Bay. This site belong to Parapente Reunion school, (Ask for authorization. Phone : 02 62 24 87 84).
GPS :
Altitude : 1 500 m ASL (of course !)
Access : This site take place above La Chaloupe village. Take the same road as to reach ColimaÃ§ons site and keep going towards La Chaloupe. Once at the village, take Vaudeville road on the left, continue still 6 km up to a concrete road and follow it. On the right-hand side of the road a panel indicates the site. After 5 minutes walk in the meadows, you are there. Aerology : The ennuagement may be very fast, with cloud cover between 900m and 1 200m. Take off early, before clouds form to avoid any surprise. Be careful, the risks are the same that for ColimaÃ§ons site : everything is quiet at the takeoff, but it can have a lot of wind on the landing ground near the sea. Please, always watch the sea before taking off to be sure that there is no strong wind on the beach.

name: MAKES
desc:
LES MAKES

Situation : Saint-Louis region (West coast). Cirque des Makes

Point GPS :

Altitude : 1 400 et 2 000 metres ASL
Conditions are often mild, but quickly cloudy. Crossings are possible Northwards as Southwards, it is rather easy to join St-Leu west coast by following crests.

Access : Take FenÃªtre des Makes road up to the Make Observatory, then turn left on the forest road up to 1 400 or 2 000 take off as you want. (according to the cloud cover)

name: Postavaru Mountain
desc:
4 options for take off: 

1. The best one (XC-wise) is facing South. It's next to the top stations of Capra cable-car. Quite steep takeoff. Only for SE-S-SW wind. (45.568035, 25.566038)

2 On North side, from the very top, in between the two cable-car, next to the big circle of antennas . (45.567435, 25.564011)

3.On North side, an easier take off is just from the ski slope, next to the Gondola Postavaru Express - Top station. (45.571155, 25.560474)

4. If there is a NW wind, you can take off from Lupului ski slope (45.570035, 25.558886)
