name: Priseaca
desc:
The best way to reach the take off place is arriving in Stoenesti village and ask about Mr. Nidu. He's a known person in the village. He has a special 4x4, hand made and in about 40 minutes after a spectacular adventure trip by car you'll get the best fly site from Leaota!

Mr. Nidu phone call: +40721.579.432
He's not a english speaker.

name: Rimetea - Piatra Secuiului
desc:
There are two takeoff places, one below the rocks and the other on the top.
Both takeoff places are accessible only by hiking, 20 min walk to the lower and 1 hour to the top.
The lower takeoff is not advised for inexperienced pilots. The top takeoff is big, with grass, easy to takeoff. In Spring and Summer time storm cloud can form.

name: Rimetea platou
desc: it's a plateau 150m x 200m slowly inclined to south-west, suitable for SW winds or no wind conditions, 1 to 1.30 hours to walk up, quite rough steep footpath, take off altitude ~1080m, when plateau finish, the keep going there on south component winds, north winds not suitable

name: Rimetea below the forest
desc: just below the forest, 830m absolute altitude

name: Rimetea 'La Brad'
desc:
take off from the ridge of Ardascheia, you have to walk up about one hour and a half, about 600m altitude difference, it's a good and nice walk, we use it when the wind is too weak to climb from below the forest and, yes, when we like to make some fitness :-) 
Site oriented to south-east, small take off area (you risk the trees just below) quite steep meadow just on the ridge, forest below, left and right, good luck :-)

name: Rimetea below the rocks
desc: below the rocks is a place to be used when enough SW wind (yeah, not too strong) or in the afternoon when the site is in full sunshine and thermals are present. Not suitable for any north component wind !

name: Iara pe nord
desc: This is take off place up on the mountain south from Iara village. Suitable for north winds. Alternative for Rimetea  when the winds blow north. You have to walk up about 30 - 60 mins or drive up with a suitable 4x4 car

name: NW on Petresti hill
desc: Suitable for W to NW winds, quite small hill, but good enough to soar a little, but also to get altitude and make a flatland XC flight (done already! :-D )

name: Cheile Turzii
desc:
a quite flat - slowly inclined to SE slope, but followed by a steep wall of Turzii canyon.

two possibilities to go at takeoff: hiking, follow a path (marked with red points) for aprox. 40min or by car follow a natural road for 3km (aprox 20min)

name: Dezmir
desc: The classic place Dezmir, nearby of Cluj Napoca. About a 100m high hill, suitable for afternoon soaring, or small flights, also for beginners. There is a school, ASPAR, where everybody can try a flight, tandem or single.

name: Liteni
desc: there is a small hill nearby of Liteni village, you can walk or drive up with a good car. Take off is very short, followed up by a vertical wall - just some meters and below is the forest. Suitable for E or SE winds

name: Salicea

name: Åre
desc:
Are (or Åre in Swedish) is mainly the biggest ski area in Sweden. But it is also a great place for both hang- and paragliding. There are 3 maintained launch zones all year-round for beginners from NE to NW. The biggest is called 'the 1000-meter' and is located at 1280 m ASL. There are also possibilities for XC flying, mainly from April until September.
The mountain is easy accessed by a tram from January until August. In the other months, you can just walk up the mountain, or in summer time catch the local club shuttle/buss or by Skysports shuttle/buss. Åre is a mountain and must be dealt with carefully. Lenticularis in the sky is a bad sign. 
The landing might be difficult in NW winds as the landing itself acts as a thermal trigger (because of the location by the lake).

name: Hammars backar
desc: Beautiful grassy slope facing towards SW. You can drive up to the launch site by car (unless the military is practicing target shooting - then the gate is closed) Dont fly in too strong winds! Hammar works best when its SW but also when its SSW or WSW. If it doesn't work, land on the soft beach. But beware of landing in the ocean. There are currents which may drag you out.

name: Asa Stenvik
desc:
Small hill in the center of Asa, 15 km south of Kungsbacka. TO is on the top of the small mountain close to the beach at the camping. Just park at the camping and walk down to the beach and you will see the hill on the right side. 

Just walk to the top and you will find a big flat spot to start from. Easy TO and toplanding. This site works best with wind from SE but it's possible to fly in S too. It's small so pretty strong wind is needed to get some height.

name: Tandådalen
desc: Take the ski lift to the top. Turn right back to the slightly more narrow ski slope. When the wind is right W to SW take off is nice and easy at the crest. If the winds turn to northerly watch out for the Venturi created by the valley to the south.

name: Balberget SW (Harahemberget)
desc: This is a cliff launch with hang glider ramp at the cliffs edge.  The ramp needs some maintenance (rotting at the top).  The ramp is held to large bolts in the rocks by rope that could be also degraded.  I think it hasn't been maintained in at least 10 years.  Paragliders should make their walls further up the clearing away from the cliff.  there it is mostly free of large obstacles, but careful layout is required to avoid snagging lines.  Winter snow would make this site much easier to launch. Cliff launch means sharp wind gradient on launch with potential for stall and/or collapse.  Beware of cross-winds. Landing area may be in the lee of low rolling hills in stronger south winds but not likely.  Wave is also likely given rolling hills in front of launch, so beware of unusual gusts in the laminar of non-thermic days.

name: Margareteberg
desc: It needed some experience because you need to ground handle and balance up a slope a few meters for the takeoff. On the other hand, it is completely harmless, so it is good for practicing. No weather hazards, except to strong wind. More than 28 -30  km / h is not recommended.

name: Kleven
desc: Take off near the sea end of the take off. A rotor at the start.

name: Åre - Morvikshummeln

name: St Paul's

name: Kovk
desc: This takeoff place is one of the first and most popular takeoffs for free flyers in Slovenia. It is known very well in Europe. Hanggliders like it, because you can drive up very close to this place. The gliding on Kovk is possible through all the year. The good winds are W,SW,S,SSE.

name: Sorica
desc:
Usually it is a 20-30 minute walk up but sometimes the ski lift can be organised the day before. The launch is small, space for one glider only. Launching usually occurs between 10am and 11am. Later than this and it is too strong.

Once launched, head east to the shoulder and climb. The west wind. The valley wind (prevailing) is usually from the west but for this site it must have an easterly component for the morning. On those days it will switch back to a west wind in the afternoon allowing you to fly downwind in the morning flying out and downwind in the afternoon coming back. Beware if you are against the wind either way as it will then be turbulent.

name: Kobariski Stol (Kobarid)
desc:
Altitude 1400 m (ASL)
From Kobarid use the road on the North side; the road on the South side is 4WD only -or rental car ;-)
Best is the local 'Parabus' Valley wind can be quite strong!

Meteo stations in Soka Valley (Wind speed and directon in Slovenian and English language)

Stol: +386 (0)41 646324
Kuk: +386 (0)31 704901
Kobala: +386 (0)41 646319

name: Lijak - Lijac
desc:
PG/HG - ASL: 565m  (HG can use take-off ramp at ASL of 850m)

Lijak is one of the most favorite take-off places in Slovenia.
Its special location offers an extraordinary number of flying days throughout the year. There are very good weather conditions for flight also during winter time; even when in the nearby Vipava valley blows strong bora, Lijak is quite well protected.  Also, in the winter time the cloud base can be higher than in summer. This geat take-off place is situated above a karstic spring of the brook Lijak, on a sharp edge of the Trnovo landscape rising over the characteristic, funnel-shaped steep slope â€“ hence the name; Lijak is a Slovenian word for funnel. Check at local bar (pizzeria Lijak at LZ) about flying conditions !!!

name: Ratitovec
desc: Just find your place near the refuge. For takeoff with East wind, go 300m East of the refuge. With East wind, condition are often rough

name: Kobala (Tolmin)
desc:
Above the city of Tolmin, take off place called Kobala, small road 15 km from Tolmin.
In July and August shutlles are organised every day starting at 10 am from landing.
Take off at 1pm with thermic breeze west side or in the morning if wind is blowing from east. Check http://skytech.si/

Valley wind can be quite strong

Weather info lines:
Kobala  +386-41 646319
Stol    +386-41 646324
Kuk     +386-31 704901

name: Ambroz
desc:
Takeoff is located on the hill above city Cerklje, on about 1300m asl. After about 25minutes of driving with your car you get almost to the takeoff. Usually there are couple of cars parked, and you can easily leave your car there.
The takeoff is not that hard. If there is a W or S wind blowing you choose upper start, and if there's E wind you have to go to the lower start which is located about 200m lower. To both starts you can easily come with your car. Choose correct side for your takeoff - if W or S, choose upper takeoff, and if E, use lower takeoff. Try not to fly in hazard conditions. 
You can call this number for weather conditions: +38631704123

desc: Takeoff is in a village called Gozd, at the foot of Kriska gora. It's located on the southern side of the hill, so you have to go round the hill to get to the takeoff.

name: Stary Haj
desc: Not a very large grassy and rocky area for 1-2 gliders. At least 2-3 m/s upwind is desirable for a safe take-off. Access to the take-off: Park on meadows under the hill and take a traverse path to the top. The take-off is also accessible from the E8 path, which passes through a meadow about 300m behind the take-off. You need to take the direction of a hunting hide, cross the ridge a bit and you find the take-off.

name: Balsamar
desc:
This takeoff is managed by â€œLos Zopilotosâ€, your local flying club.  All Zopilotos can fly without restrictions.

Very easy take-off ideal for both paragliders and hangliders with the possibility of being  180Âº  if improved.  Good access road that drives right to the launch.  It is ideal field for top landings.  Excellent for ridge soaring.  With light wind excellent spot for top to bottom beginner flights.  With 12 km + winds, excellent for rigde soaring.  There is a house thermal to the left of the launch.  Ideal for tandem flights as well.
Spectacular views of the pacific ocean.

Dry Season Nov-May with the incidence of strong north winds in 2-4 day periods specially through Nov-Feb, but because it sits right on the coast, sometimes south winds are able to creep in anyways.  Flyable year round as the rainy season tends to rain at night in general.

*GPS coordinates *:  take off : 13Â°30'1.06'N; 89Â°32' 7.02' W - Elevation : 170 m. Tropical conditions - no flight suits

name: k 51
desc:
13Â°40'0.60'N; 88Â°50'23.51'W -Elevation:754m  
Orientation:  East/South East
This takeoff is managed by â€œLos Zopilotosâ€, your local flying club.  All â€œZopilotosâ€ can fly without restrictions.
Very easy take-off , wide and grassy, ideal for both paragliders and hangliders.   Good access road that drives right to the launch.  Both dynamic and thermic, this valley is among the areas most exposed to the  sunlight in the whole country.  Expect strong thermals in noon  hours.  With light wind excellent spot for top to bottom student  flights.    Ideal for tandem flights as well.  Spectacular views of the valley and â€œVolcan de San Vicenteâ€.
Dry Season Nov-May with the incidence of strong north winds in 2-4 day periods specially through Nov-Feb, but SE winds are predominant during the rainy season(june-november), making it flyable year round. Tropical conditions-no flight suits.
Strong thermals around noon hours

name: Coatepeque
desc:
GPS: 13Â°52'40.56'N; 89Â°31'3.48'W
Elevation : 1004 m
Orientation: Southwest 
This takeoff is managed by â€œLos Zopilotosâ€, your local flying club. All â€œZopilotosâ€ can fly without restrictions. 
Technical and small take off.   Excellent rigde soaring site, spectacular views of the crater lake Coatepeque, an ancient volcano the erupted thousands of years ago. Expect to get a lot of flying time and be carefull when the wind is too strong, it makes it tough to come down.  The vehicle drives to the takeoff and pilot recovery is easy as well.  
Season Nov - Aug Tropical conditions-no flight suits
Tough to come down when windy (> 20kms/hr)

name: Koh Larn
desc: Take off faces NNW and is from a flat paved area in front of the large statue of a monk.  The site works well in mos wind directions between NE and NW.  The local geography seems to funnel the wind up the hill and and it surprisingly easy to stay up in light winds.  When the wind is strong then you will be lifted off the ground.  If you are not used to flying in strong dynamic lift then wait until the wind eases off.  Please be aware that there is a tandem operation here between October and February.  Give way to tandems when it is safe to do so.

name: Phu Thap Boek
desc:
Warning:  As of 2015, the launch has been mostly taken over by a major expansion of a small tourist resort.  Launch is becoming too small and unsafe due to many obstacles, buildings of various sizes and various post and fences completely in the way.  They ruined it.  There is still a small field which can be used adjacent to the diminishing launch (now a dusty parking lot) but may require a full on forward launch for proper take off.  I heard they plan to build on the field too (bummer!).  This is a very nice site which is disappearing due to poor communication and lack of judgement between the landowners, local pilots, local governments and especially the Thai paragliding officials.  (RASAT)
A very sad turn of event for paragliding in Thailand!
Launch can be tricky.  Many serious accidents so far so not a beginner site!  This launch is not forgiving so you better be prepared, talk to the local pilots first.
2020 Update:
BUMMER.  More structures, parked cars, and a launch in a cultivated field that is facing perpendicular to the hill.  Very tough to launch in the best conditions.  Only reason I can use this launch is because the field is not cultivated at the moment...  One of the best sites in Thailand doomed to extinction... Potential storm cells forming over the launch at times so be careful and watch for these budding electric storms! Can be tricky down in the valley when the dust devils gets going but this does not seem to happen very often.

name: Nai Han Beach
desc: at the windmill, jut under on the grass area. Very large and easy. when wind come too much from north, beware of turbulences.

name: Phu Sing
desc: Sheer cliff.  Recommend for advanced pilots only.  Public access road to launch.  Within the boundaries of a protected area. You can be in serious trouble at some of the areas along the ridge if the wind drops and you need to do an emergency landing.

desc: The takeoff is inside some gates, beside a Buddha stature, at 500 meters. Best wind direction for this site is 100, east south east. Below the take off are some large boulders, which will be dangerous if you do not get your take off correct.

name: Alakjin
desc: Go to Rudaki and Omar Khayam Street intersection at north end of town in Dushanbe. On west side of this intersection you can find taxi to Alakjin (30 somani). From where the taxi drops you off in Alakjin village, walk north along a small road (that changes into a path) following the stream. After 10 mins, where the stream forks, take the right (easterly) fork. Follow that along a well worn donkey trail for 5 more minutes then take a sharp right along the back side of a cherry orchard (where the farmer gave me a huge bag of cherries!) From here work your way up a fairly steep hill side following numerous small donkey trails. The takeoff is due east of the cherry orchard and up about 200m. You can't miss it when you arrive - it's a large flat grassy area with takeoffs possible in any direction except north. Hike takes 0:45 to 1:15hrs and there is an altitude gain of about 350m. None

name: Catlakkaya
desc: Takeoff height is about 1650m. There is no slope on takeoff site but only 15 m long runway, and its just a crag at the end of the runway. You have only one chance to takeoff. And needs N wind. It may be risky at turbulent weather and there is no emergency landing point. There is only crag and forest under you. wind speed between 10- 20 km/h is good to take off. Electric cables may be a risk near the landing sites in the city.

name: Goveclik
desc:
The take-off is facing NE, but the main wind course is W in the afternoon. So late take-offs may be difficult and turbulent. There is another take-off facing NW, easier to take off there, just walking down a little.
Strong inversion prevents higher climbind rates, but usual inversion stop is 2400 mt over take-off and once you drift back to the main mountain shoulder, you may easily get over the inversion. 100+ km XC flights possible, over mountains and flatlands.
The scenery is beatiful, as the forest trees are grown naturaly at steep mountain. A place where we planned to do tasks during the PWCA and so will definitely with the Super Finals in 2010. 
Take off is a restricted area, contact locals prior to trip plan for permissions and briefing is important for airspace and military areas. West wind may pick up in later afternoon, but it is very predictable. Follow up weather forecasts, weather does not develope dramatically unless forecasted.

name: Deregündüzlü
desc: Shallow slope ideal for slope ground handling but small hill flights are also possible. There is absolutely zero rock on the ground but weed may overgrow after spring. Be prepared.

name: Zeytin Barajı
desc: Yes

name: Saijia
desc:
Flat ground with nice grass. Allow open 3 canopys at the same time. Front edge is cliff. 330m high and 1.5km to landing. Good season October to March.
Summer have typhoon and storm. Cloud suck.

The landing zone sets off sudden thermals. Watch out on landing! 

Watch the thermal cycles. 15 - 20 minuutes. When you're on, you're really on. When  you're off, you're on the ground.

name: Hu To San, Tigerhead Mtn
desc:
There are 3 take-off areas all right next to each other. They are operated by two different companies. 

Two of the take-off are free to use for any solo pilot. And even tandem is possible to do here if coordinated with the site manager. The site manager is friendly and speaks English fluently! 

The other site is better developed with bathrooms, tables and even a place to stay over night with a running water and showers.
You do need to pay to fly from this site.

All take-off's are west wards and flying starts around noon. This is not a beginners site with low altitude start means that there is a lot of bumpy thermals. 

Later afternoon is great evening flying with sunset, this place is know around the island for it sunsets. Summer time often overdevelops with great cloud suck and thunder showers. Be aware of the weather changes.

name: Lu Yeh, Gao Tai
desc:
30 m X 30 m take off area, bordered by massive parking lot crowded with tourists on  weekends and everything that comes with it, But it is heaven M - F. 

368 meters, msl, 150  agl

Ask for house thermals and sink holes as  the wind direction shifts and when to cross the valley to the 900 take off zone.

cliff launch, with occasional bursts of rotor and thermal.
When they  trim the  trees on the SE face,  that  launch is  safe  and easy. When they  don't there is a  constant back-wind and rotor. 
The south west launch is largly useless. GW  has wrought  havoc on the Taiwan  weather system, hard to predict. Typhoons are  forming  further north. summer is  best  season ,  favorable winds develop often 7 am to 7 pm, 2000 m msl soaring 

WATCH TYPHOON SEASON -August Sept, usually  coincides with the Int'l PG competition. ( kinda makes you wonder...) A typhoon from the south will set up a tail wind that will last for 3 days of Xcellent XC, good night flights

name: Taiping San
desc:
900 meters msl, it's faster to fly up to this site, from Kaotai, than it is to drive up. It is seldom used. Fly up from Kaotai, stop for lunch and fly out again.

Watch that east wind take off. FLy down to  cloudbase. typhoon season and overdeveloped often.

name: Wan Li
desc: 184 msl, beach site, large enough, but  crowded on the weekends. seasonal. watch frontal activity, local squall, and typhoons season.

name: Puli old
desc: 15 m  front to back, 40 meters wide, convergence turbulence on a cliff launch. not for beginners. many spectators. crowded. nice  grass see other Puli  site

name: Wai Ao, To Cheung
desc:
160 msl, beach  site; small-ish take off, 60 X 50 mts,  pro-top landing. 
This is one of the few  sites in Taiwan where a large enough LZ is in full view of a suitable TOZ. rainy winters, nice summers. transitions are thermic. But otherwise, prolonged sled rides. Watch those cross winds.

name: ming li
desc:
long drive up  to  a long glide out,  good  thermal, XC. no amenities, well manicured  grassy field, slope 

pictures  and  description here : http://www.szicby.com/page01b.htm typhoons  season and windy  winters,  This site is at the mouth of the Hwa Dong  valley. So, it is influenced by the sea  system and the valley system.

name: Ji Chi
desc:
grassy  slope, long curve, hard drive up, no amenities like  everywhere in Taiwan,  TYPHOON  season 
spring and  summer  are  good,. Winter is cold,  cloudy and  strong winds.  XC  potential here for 50 km

name: Big Bird N
desc: 300  agl, N - NE take off... so  far winter, off shore  and  strong

name: Xr To San
desc:
contrary to GE, actual elev is 165 msl/agl, In the winter, blows off shore when a front is passing. About 2 days every 10. Check XCskies.com. 
XCskies' algo's don't reflect the on shore breeze here.
So, if XCskies shows the cloud cover is less than 50% and the off shore wind indicates less than 20 kph,  from any direction, then the ACTUAL conditions are good for flight.

name: FS  station
desc: experimental; I'm flying sim so I can  decide whether or not to clear the site. When the cold fronts come in the winds blow offshore. DON'T fly here. This will last 1 - 3 days.

name: Big Bird  East

name: ping pu tso san
desc: experimenting with  several -  haven't quite selected one yet.

name: jindzen, dong huh
desc: 65 msl, beach site, coastal ridge soaring; If the site is not available, it is possible to take off at the parking lot of the cafe, pending traffic.

name: dulan 1, the finger
desc: 250 msl beach landing at the resort. This mtn is also called Sleeping Beauty because it looks like a woman reclining with her arm stretched out pointing to Green Island. This TOZ is on her finger. Dulan 2 is on her elbow. watch for  Q me's developing

name: Dulan 2 N elbow
desc: 420 msl, grassy slope, a little bumpy on the glide out, good top landing, ridge soaring mostly, thermal XC if you plan your routes. same as  Dulan 1

name: Jin Loon 1000
desc: a looong drive up to this one; but well worth it for loooong XC along the coast clouds and OD.

name: jindzen san S point
desc: not for beginners. Can be brisk. OD. ballast up for strong winds

name: Li Jya
desc:
at 730 ml, with 360 degree  view, this is one of the best site in Taiwan. take off in  any  direction. even night flights  are a breeze. 
BE AWARE: The site is no longer used! The Take Off area is over grown by vegetation (September 14th 2011). Look for Luye instead (just few Km more north). AWSOME! OD clouds

name: Stop and drop
desc: 100 msl  over the beach. This is a  Stop-and-Drop off pilots who take off from the  side of the road. Driver keeps going to the pick up area. If it is  windy, you go up. If it is light, you glide down wind to the pick up. typhoons. When there is no wind, it's not easy to inflate.

name: Xr Dze X
desc: experimental so  far

name: wu jin
desc:
still testing, 700 msl/agl. This is the 41st site in Taiwan that I am test flying in the  never quest for the best X-C-lent site and  for the best training site. 
Thanks Raf for an excellent resource. The PGESIM allows me to sim-fly several times  before I have to break out the weed whacker.

name: 60 egg mtn
desc: the mountains are covered with short flowering grass. Ask the farmers permission before take off, or take off from the road. summer thunder showers.   Winds on the take off are  often not as strong as  in the  deep  valley.

name: jr bun
desc: a little  rough , hard to find, watch the valley  winds, enjoy the  view of Jr Ben Hot Springs

desc: long  drive  up , choppy  hills  below and a  long  glide to  landing. SO, fly  only  when conditions are better.

desc: medium sized, grass covered slope, no amentities. Many XC options, top landing is probably not an option as thermal is 'out there', not near the take off. Short  walk form bus route to take off zone and LZ. watch the typhoon season.  Watch for fast  cloud  development

desc: This is experimental. I am setting up the site so that the 'right people' can test fly it. It is a very large grassy slope, with lots of room for ground skimming in smooooth ocean air at 200 meters above a beach. It is sufficiently remote that there will be few pilots there at any one time. There are amenities; B n B, driver, restaurant, etc. watch weather reports and satellite images before leaving home so you can avoid typhoons  and off shore winds.

name: Usambara ridge
desc: Exactly -4.839, 38.2833 The slopes and grass are well cut now in all E-S-W directions. Thanks to big trees behind it, it's also well possible to TO with a slight tailwind. Flyable all year, except the rainy season. Mostly complicated during the peak day heat. Also, some dangerous winds (usually, short gusts) before or at the sunset.

name: World's en View
desc:
S 08.83103/ E 033.54181 elevation - 2429m

Take off is behind the Antenna facing east at the highest point of the Chunya road. There is enough space for parking the car. The weather changes quickly. In the rainy season thunderclouds can already be developed at around 1 pm.

name: Ol'molog
desc: Volcanic cone remnant.  Grassy hill with some trees on lower parts of the hill.  There are two antennas on top of the hill with a road to the top to access them. A 4x4 is required.  Lots of space to camp just below launch, but permission is required from the local township to use the site. There can be strong catabatic winds at this site, coming from Kilimanjaro in the evening.

Flights. The place is suitable for training flights in thermo-dynamics, as well as for cross-country flights. background with weak winds, westerly breeze pushes

name: Bukhta Koktebel’ Pograntsy
desc: The ridge is about 1000 m long and faces south wind that usually starts here as a sea breeze at noon and may last almost till sunset. Ridge soaring is great with spectacular views at one of the most attractive places of Crimea. Launching needs some experience since there is not much space. The spot is very popular and sometime may look like a swarm of bees with paragliders zooming along the coast. It is wise to take advice from locals where to launch and land best and expect rotors and rollers since they are not rare here, just lock on terrain and think where to expect them.  Sometime the airspace may be closed for gliders by officials because of some undeclared reasons, so take patients and don’t be frustrated. Usually nice with rare  precipitations

name: Vinogradovo Chorna Gora
desc: Takeoff is not for beginners. Vertical wall )) See photo

name: Isingero; Felix and Robert's place
desc:
Multiple decently sized takeoffs with low-ish grass, there are many rocky patches so make sure to have your runway planned it is always windy (usually the right direction for dynamic lift)

The plane in front of the site is very wet and often over develops in the afternoons with monstrous clouds.

name: Torrey Pines (San Diego)
desc:
Large grassy slope. Launching between orange cones are the safest and recommended areas. There are rotors in other areas outside the cones that are effected with cross winds conditions. Ask a local pilot if you are not sure. The water and cloud in the ocean tells the story of what is coming.calm spots.. wind is not strong.  Dark spots could be wind. Whitecaps it is starting to get stronger. 

Watch for the winds to switch and fly ridges and fingers according to rotor spots.

name: Marshall (San Bernardino)
desc:
Marshall Peak is a forgiving gentle slope launch that drops off steeper. There is room to set up several gliders at once when the winds are southerly, which they usually are. Grasses around launch are trimmed from time to time but sticks in the lines are possible. The top of the peak is dusty dirt but it doesn't seem to stick to gliders much. The normal way up is to drive around the back in a truck, which takes about 1/2 an hour. Most of the distance is paved, with the last couple of miles being a dirt road in variable condition. Four wheel drive is not usually necessary, but some amount of clearance is helpful. Drive slowly on this road, as it is two way traffic with blind corners. Collisions do occur. It is also possible to hike up to launch, and elevation gain of about 2300 feet (700m). Be aware that rattlesnakes are common in the summer, and mountain lions and bears are sometimes seen. No mountain lion or bear attacks on people have been recorded, but hiking alone at sunset might not be the best idea. 

There is another launch 1200 feet (365m) higher in the town of Crestline. This launch is flat grass becoming steep quickly. It is often windier at Crestline; there are many days when Marshall is good for paragliding and Crestline is too windy. Hang gliders launch there more often than paragliders. On days with good lapse rates and light base winds it can be great for paragliding too. Driving to Crestline is all paved roads. Hiking is not an option unless you are an ironman or plan to camp half way. Summer conditions mid-day are usually very strong and can be dangerous. Dust devils blow through the LZ. Pilots are encouraged to launch after 5 pm on their first flight and work earlier as they see how they like it. 

Sometimes sea-breeze fronts blow through, you can see them coming. And occasionally gust fronts from thunderstorms, though most thunderstorms form far enough back in the mountains as not to affect flying.

wx info: http://www.crestlinesoaring.org/weather

name: Woodrat Mountain
desc: Large and perfect grade with gravel. West launch capable of simultaneous launches. Also a north launch. Large and well maintained. Main LZ can be dangerous mid-day, mid-season. Convergent air from 3 valleys creates difficult landing conditions.

name: Cedar Mountain (the 'C')
desc:
You have a window of opportunity for launching. Too early you sink out. Too late and the wind get too strong.
Alternative TO (especially in Winter) at the 'C': 37 38 32.9 W113 02 05.3 (2513m) Southwset Utah wx: http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/slc/current/meso.swut.php

name: Mollies Nipple (Hurricane- St.George)
desc: You have a window of opportunity for launching. Too early you sink out. Too late and the wind get too strong. They don't call it Hurricane for nothing. Southwest Utah wx: http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/slc/current/meso.swut.php

name: Chelan Butte
desc: beware of dust devils!! - https://www.windy.com/47.805/-120.039?46.957,-120.039,7

name: Tiger Mountain
desc:
Two take-off areas, N and S. South take-off is lower than N (NW) by about 200'. Some HG activity from N launch. NO POWERED CRAFT.
Google Maps
http://maps.google.com/?q=Issaquah,+WA&ie=UTF8&t=h&om=1&z=16&ll=47.497546,-122.009525&spn=0.007495,0.021501&iwloc=addr Tiger becomes a weather washing machine when the wind is out of the east. Mechanical turbulence makes any flying experience difficult and dangerous. Avoid flying this site in east winds.
Also trees to the east of the south launch can mask an east wind (make it appear like a nice south day). Its easiest to detect this situation by watching the tree tops to the north and east of the site clearing.

name: Potato Hill
desc:
Takeoff is small, allowing just one person to launch at a time.  There is plenty of standing room, and enough room to set up a few hang gliders.

There are bushes and short trees in front.

The launch faces east, and the valley creates its own east wind on most summer days, regardless of the prevailing direction. Westerly winds are blocked by local conditions on most days.  However the wind can switch later in the day, creating lee-side and/or convergence conditions in the Fout Springs valley.

name: Elk Mountain
desc:
1) South Launch - grassy; steep; can launch 2; preferred by paragliders; 4,000\' MSL; 2,600\' vertical. 

(2) North Launch - good, but can be tricky; brushy. 

(3) West Launch - sometimes used by paragliders; rarely used by hang gliders.

name: Ellenville
desc: The main launch faces WNW - NW. It is wide and grassy, with level set up space for twenty hang gliders or dozens of paragliders. There is a separate, narrower launch that faces west. See weather tab.

name: Mt. Zion aka Lookout aka LO (Golden)
desc: Please see rmhpa.org for site requirements. This is a sensitive P3 site and requires paperwork and walk through before launching here. Please see rmhpa.org for site requirements. This is a sensitive P3 site and requires paperwork and walk through before launching here.

name: Inspiration Point -aka Inspo (Orem- Provo)
desc: space for several gliders; just a few steps off parking.

name: The B
desc: This is an advanced site due to the lack of landing zones!  Take off is a 20 minute hike up a steep but nice hill with a 3000 foot mountain behind it.  Most hike about 100 yards above the \'B\', really  the top of the open area, to launch, any higher is very hard to find open areas to launch, though I have found one another 45 minutes higher. Standard Mountain flying!

name: Horse Canyon
desc:
Do NOT park vehicles in upper set-up area, keep clear for top landings.

Do NOT attempt top landings if Hang Gliders are setting up. Do NOT fly during high pressure Santa Ana wind conditions.

Be cautious of rotor during takeoffs when wind is cross from the north.

The local club, SDHGPA, maintains a weather station on launch: https://www.sdhgpa.com/weather-stations.html

name: Day Dreams
desc: Two separate launches on the ridge directly NE of Kings Beach State Park. Launch can be tricky due to the small, rocky set-up area and punchy thermals that roll through the launch. Be ready to be lifted up and practice your reverse flying skills just in case. You're looking for SW at a steady 10-15 mph.

name: Howard
desc:
Please contact the Eagle Cap Paragliding Club (ECPC) for the latest information and updates on flying from Mt. Howard.  

Mt. Howard is a foot launch paragliding & hang gliding site located 7 miles south of Joseph, Oregon. The launch site faces north and is most commonly flown from July through the end of September. The Wallowa Lake Tramway (WLT) offers transportation to the public to the top of the mountain. Then, a ½ mile hiking trail leads to the launch site, located on National Forest land. This is a high profile and sensitive flying site so please respect this site guide information and only fly within your limits. 

All pilots are required to be “CURRENT” members of the United States Hang Gliding & Paragliding Association (USHPA).  A minimum Paragliding *Intermediate (P-3) with special skill TUR (Turbulence) or Hang Gliding Advanced (H-4) certification is required.  All licenses will be checked, indemnity waiver signed, site guide review completed, and ECPC membership collected before visiting pilots are signed off to fly.  Please contact the Eagle Cap Paragliding Club before you arrive to organize paperwork, a site briefing, and a time when club members are available.

Paragliding Intermediate (P-3) pilots are required to have the turbulence (TUR) special skill, and it is highly recommended to also have the High Altitude (HA), Restricted Landing Field (RLF), and Cross Country (X-C) special skills. Joseph Weather: https://www.josephoregonweather.com/
Current Howard Conditions: https://www.josephoregonweather.com/howardwx/howardwx.php
Howard forecast: https://www.josephoregonweather.com/howardwx/howardforecast.php

name: Otay Mesa
desc: Best for strong, post/pre-frontal South to Southwest winter conditions.

name: Cuesta Grade
desc: This site is a drive-up with a fairly nice launch area.  Please get a site checkout from a local SLOSA pilot prior to flying this site.

name: Blossom Valley
desc:
Hike up (10 to 15 minutes) or High Clearance 4X4 drive up 

Note:  The Blossom LZ is CLOSED until further notice. Effective 5-7-14, the Blossom LZ Landowner will press trespassing charges to all accessing his land.

Helix Water Property & Old Riverbed LZs Remain Closed Blossom Valley has the Highest Accident Rate of all San Diego County sites.

Thumper out front and to the North is a knob that tends to throw off thermals that can be pretty bouncy.

Also watch out for high winds, venturi effect, across the top and across Amen Ridge, off the the right (north) of launch.  Lower speed-gliders can be blown back on windy days.

Lots of Power Lines in Valley

name: Mission Ridge (Fremont- San Jose)
desc: Huge and grassy.

name: Soboba
desc: Many takeoff options. Weeds are mowed down. Some are steep.

name: Elsinore
desc:
E launch: Short sloped launch area

Edwards launch: Rocky knob

name: Blackhawk
desc: Flat road turn-off.

name: Kagel (Sylmar)
desc:
Grass area.
large enough for a few wings.

name: Hidden Valley
desc: Cleared area. catus on edges and embedded lavara rocks protruding can catch lines.

name: Winchester Bowl
desc:
Aside from the one shown on the map (primary launch) there are also launches facing West, East and even North.

** Update ** I saw two launches one up top which is a small SW facing launch and one about 30-40 meters down which is more South facing and a bit bigger.  

It's about a 20 minute walk from the base to the top I would guess. Very strong cycles in the middle of the afternoon, but typical SoCal conditions regardless.

name: Big Black
desc:
Although Big Black is in the Cleveland National Forest, it is a highly sensitive site. After years of working with the Palomar Ranger District we feel very fortunate to have regained access and to fly there via a Special Use Permit. 

Small cutout between trees: Being nested in pines, launch can be tricky for paraglliders, but ok for hang gliders.

name: Little Black
desc:
Many, depending on your desire to hike.


USHPA and SDHGPA Membership is Required to Fly Little Black.  
Site Guide: http://www.sdhgpa.com/sites-guide.html

name: Laguna
desc:
Laguna is primarily known as a Big East Facing XC Site. . .  for Thermal and Convergence flying. It can also be good in Pre and post Monsoonal conditions.

Although Laguna can be tempting and fun for summer evening katabatic flying when horse is blowing down as well as being fun mild Santa Ana days, be advised that the nearest LZ to Launch is a 45 min  drive down to the dessert floor and having a dedicated driver is required.

The San Diego club has a special use permit to access the upper launch, which is generally preferred for paragliders.

name: Calabasas
desc: Santa ana winds during winter months.

name: Santa Monica- Malibu - Corral Canyon
desc: Large Beware of West wind (from the right) as the peak to the right will create turbulence.

name: Ojai - Chief
desc: Easy

name: Comanche
desc: Large

name: Pine

name: Skyport (Santa Barbara)
desc: Steep slope

name: Mentone
desc: Off a dirt road.

name: Slide
desc:
Large flat parking lot. Asphalt 

Best to inflate far behind and run through the rotor zone at the lip of launch. 7600ft take off, conditions can change rapidly. Moderate level difficult regarding weather. Monitor local WX, including anemometer at the Slide Mountain Peak.

name: Kingsbury grade
desc: Nice setup area. Steep dirt slope with small sized rocks. Tree obstacle to clear immediately after launch. Highly active site. Unstable days following frontal passage area ideal.

name: Hat Creek rim
desc: > see website below

name: Big Sur - Wild cattle
desc: Please Note:  The roads to launch are periodically closed, due to forest fires and landslides.  Before traveling to Big Sur for flying, please check with the Los Padres National Forest (805.968.6640) to make sure that the roads to launch are open.  They are serious about the road closures, with fines of $5,000-$10,000 and up to six months in jail, and the local residents are on the lookout for violators. The conditions are most reliable from fall through spring.  It is usually too foggy to fly at Big Sur during the summer.  Conditions for soaring are best between Christmas and Martin Luther King's birthday.  You can typically count on having a beautiful, smooth sled ride, but soaring flights can be had on pre- and post-frontal days.

name: Dunlap
desc: There is a large flat set up area behind launch.  There are two launch areas on each side of the cabin, with a larger one on the south side.  There is only room for one to lay out at a time however. None really, Dunlap is very consistent spring through early fall.  Early in the spring there may be low cloud bases and overdevelopment.

name: Goodsprings (Las Vegas)
desc: Good weatherlinks on the webpage of the local club: www.desertskywalkers.com

name: Paiute (Bishop- Owens Valley)
desc:
Big area with dirt and small rocks.  Also lots of tiny bushes to snag lines.
Launch is at 8000ft/msl, 4000ft above the LZ.  The air is thin.  Occasional dusties through launch, especially late in the day. The Owens Valley is quite exposed, so wind direction and strength changes can be rapid and dangerous.  A landing in the mountains will likely keep you there overnight, so carry sufficient water and supplies.

Weather conditions in the summer are suitable for HGs and sailplanes only.  Overdevelopment, gust fronts, powerful winds and violent conditions are common in the summer.  The best PG conditions begin mid-september and become very weak by early november.  Spring conditions are variable and unpredictable.

Many met-links: http: //karicastle.com/owens-valley-wx/

name: Ed Levin
desc: Four launch areas: 1750' (top), 600', 300', 50' (training hill)

desc: CLOSED  > Alternative: Marina State Beach/ Lake Court Dune ...

- upper launch: N43 46 05.9 W113 17 24.0, 2430m
- Coyote: N43 44 31.3 W113 17 55.6, 2240m High desert!
Strong winds, high cloud base, dust devils, rapidly changing weather, TS, ...
