desc: Large grassy area

name: Walshes launch (Aspen morning)
desc: Grassy and large East launch: normally only a small window, before the wind starts blowing over the back.

name: Deertrail
desc: Steep slope down from a road

name: Bear Back
desc: Sloped hillside

name: McClellan (Reno)
desc: There is a West launch (main one) and a South one.

name: Rendezvous Peak/ JHMR (Jackson Hole Mountain Resort)
desc: CLOSED High-alpine site in American West means weather can (and often does) change rapidly. Talk with the locals throughout the morning. Read the local forecast discussion.

name: Snow King (Jackson)
desc: large and grassy

name: Phillips Ridge
desc: Narrow and steep

name: Black Cap
desc: From a dirt road

name: Del Cerro
desc:
At the edge of the Del Cerro Park look left.
You need to launch left of the park 200' to avoid being arrested. Look out for Great white shark in water and Sea Bass in bikini down below.

name: Hogback
desc:
It is possible to soar both the south and north sides of the hogback depending on the wind. South is rarely flown by local pilots & is Not recommended for visiting pilots,

South side launches are unimproved in rough terrain. Checkout our Holfuy station for current wind conditions. https://holfuy.com/en/weather/416

name: Cape Lookout
desc: Heading South, the takeoff is a small gravel spot along side of the road shortly after the entrance of Cape Lookout State Park.  There is a small clearing looking out over the ocean.

name: Peterson Butte
desc: Grass slope overlooking farm fields, or hike up to the summit in light conditions. Winds may increase rapidly and significant gradient may be present aloft. Clouds and fog may form below and in front. Stay well clear of terrain and be prepared to descend if conditions strengthen. HG pilots have been caught in strong winds aloft, unable to penetrate and escape. Spring weather may be particularly unstable and change rapidly.

name: Blanchard
desc: TO is at 'Samish Overlook'

name: Rampart Ridge
desc: Because this site sits at the top of a mountain pass the winds can become very strong, very quickly. Rule of thumb is to compare the barometric pressure of Seattle and Wenatchee. If it is less than 5 millibars (metric) difference (west to east), then the winds may be light enough to allow safe flying.

name: Point Mugu
desc:
From paved road at Laguna Peak.
GPS coordinate supplied for launch is approximate, John Thee or Claude Fiset (see contacts) to confirm.
Appropriate wind directions need to be revised by John Thee or Claude Fiset (see contacts).
UPDATE 2006/7/28: The take off has disappeared.

name: Ord
desc: There are streamers and one can launch anywhere from NW to NE, depending which side of the cone you pick. Typical building afternoon West wind accelerated around the shoulder of this ridge.

name: Santiago Peak
desc: Flat and typically in wind shadow so you need good forward launching skills. A freind broke lines on 2 wings trying to launch and gave up.

name: Diablo
desc: Large grassy area Mid-day summer conditions can be robust.

name: Tollhouse
desc: Rock face; (10/2018: nicely cleared of all sticky things); beware of 'poisonous oak' if going to pee... None

name: Springville - Slick Rock
desc:
It is a VERY long glide to the main LZ - you must gain altitude, or you won't make it over some hills out in front. It is extremely difficult to get back to the road from there. So land on the big open BAIL OUT LZ below and in front of launch.  

Watch how and where locals lay their wings out, and choose which spot seems to suite you best to launch. Launch there can be very dangerous, it is a sheer rock face similar to Tollhouse.

name: Don Pedro Lake
desc: From a small island.

name: Wolcott
desc: Above the landfill, on a private acess road. you must contact the local club 970-376-0495, Greg Kelly for the details wind 230-290 SW

name: Bristol
desc:
1450 MSL
N42 44'47.9 W77 24'08.2
West Facing Launch
Setup allows approximately 4 hang gliders to be set up at any one time
Located on Stid Hill across from Bristol Mountain Ski Area
Car pool to launch to avoid congestion
http://terraserver.microsoft.com/image.aspx?T=2&S=12&Z=18&X=379&Y=5918&W=3
http://terraserver.microsoft.com/image.aspx?T=1&S=11&Z=18&X=758&Y=11837&W=3

name: Italy Valley
desc:
2000 MSL
N42 36'47.5
W77 18.43.0
Round slope launch: S/SE
Setup allows >30 gliders to be set up at any time

name: Dansville
desc:
1560 MSL
Shallow slope launch W/SW
Setup allows 5-7 gliders

name: Harriet Hollister Spencer State Park (Closed)
desc:
(Closed)
2100 MSL
Shallow Slope Launch N/Ne
Up to 7 gliders at any time

name: Mossy Banks Memorial Park
desc:
Closed due to nesting birds wildlife preservation
1550 MSL
Cliff Launch North
Up to 3 gliders

name: Hammondsport
desc:
1750 MSL
Truncated Slope NW
>20 gliders setup at any time

name: Palomar
desc:
Palomar is one of San Diego's best mountain sites due to the micro climate which exists in the valley.

SDHGPA membership required for Launch and LZ Gate access

All Palomar launches and LZs are on private property. SDHGPA has only recently been given permission by the Pala Tribal Council to access the primary launch and landing areas after a lengthy site closure. 

Because of this and other Landowner agreements, site protocol is critical to the continued use of the site.
http://www.sdhgpa.com/palomar.html Weather conditions:
SDHGPA maintains a weather station on launch: https://www.sdhgpa.com/weather-stations.html

name: Cayucos
desc: This site is generally a Hike-up site but a 4X4 can make it up if dry.  Please do not attempt to drive up if the road is wet.  The area is private land & has cattle on it. Close all gates. Thermal block can cause an otherwise nice looking day to be turbulent and tricky.  Get a local pilot to give you a site checkout.

name: Laguna Lake
desc: From the top of the hill. Hike up.

name: Montana de Oro
desc: Contact the local club. Thermal Block can cause very turbulent conditions while looking fairly benign.  If locals aren't flying, it's a good idea to avoid MDO.

name: Baldy Butte (Ellensburg)
desc: Grassy hill with a few rocks Strong winds

name: Packsaddle Mountain
desc:
2,015 feet MSL (mean sea level)
387 feet AGL (above ground level)

South launch... ESE winds (P2/H2), foot launch and ramp

North launch... NW winds (P3/H3), ramp CLOSED DURING DEER HUNTING SEASON -- Late October thru Mid January.

name: GrayBird AirSports
desc: Towing site for PG & HG

name: Avenue S
desc:
There are a number of potential take-offs though the main one is marked on the map.  Other possibilities include a small flat hill out front and the side of the road to the East of launch.

The best launch is up top though as there is lots of room to layout and hook in.  It is a bit rocky but generally clear of plants and debris.  Since it is a bit behind another lower hill the best flight plan is to fly straight out and climb up out front. Gets windy and thermic here during the day but a few hours before sunset nice glass-offs can set up.

name: Brace
desc:
Launch is open and grassy with some rocks surrounded by bushes and low trees that are forgiving of launch failures - in terms of injury if not so much in terms of time to untangle. In case of parawaiting the Brace launch is a beautiful place to be. It is top-landable with the usual risks.

When the wind is cross this is a P4 launch. Fly straight out and get clearance as quickly as possible. Variable. Often stable, but even stable blue days sometimes allow good XC flying. Occasionally conditions are spectacular with working cumulus clouds that don't overdevelop. On these days flights of 100k+ are possible.

name: Kirkridge
desc: Narrow, almost slot launch.

name: Rocky Point
desc: 40.965439, -72.956130 North to Northwest winds required

name: Saddle
desc: The launch is a rocky but but gentle slope that drops away to reveal the and LZ. It is quite large and makes a great place to learn top landing. Avoid Saddle on strong west and SW days, although thermal flying in the summer is possible on light west days. Out and back 20 mile ridge soaring flights are possible.

name: Table Bluff (Eureka)
desc:
HG: cliff launch: no room for running!
PG: good high wind reverse launching skills required.
Same launch for HG & PG.

name: Mattole
desc: Launches at 200', 800' and 1200'.  Grass slope.

name: Richmond Dale
desc: Tight sloped take off surrounded by trees.

name: Pulpit
desc: Site is owned by the CHGPA. Well maintained gravel covered slope. Rocks below launch, elevated HG ramps on either side. Site is NOT flown in a North cross due to rotor. Site easily gets too windy and blown out. PG pilots do not fly if surface wind is over 7mph because it's typically over 15mph at launch. Excessive turbulence when crossed.

name: Mingus
desc: seperate launche sfor HG and PG Eric Chan, 2007/4/7: To safly fly there, the wind must be within 15 degree of being straight in. Otherwise you will get much turbulence.

name: Crestline (San Bernardino)
desc:
A moderate size area where 2-3 PG can setup at the same time.
You park you vehicule in the parking behind launch which is accessible with any vehicle (asphalt road).
There is another launch (Marshall Peak) which is about 300m (1000') lower in case the wind is too strong here. Paragliders use Crestline instead of Marshall to lengthen a sledder when conditions are too weak for staying up. Summer conditions mid-day are usually very strong and can be dangerous. Dust devils blow through the LZ. Pilots are encouraged to launch after 5 pm on their first flight and work earlier as they see how they like it.
Wx info: http://www.crestlinesoaring.org/weather
Webcams: http://www.crestlinesoaring.org/ptzcam

name: Gunter (Bishop - Owens Valley)
desc: As usual in the valley: rocky, some weeds, but a small area is clear enough to lay out 1 PG... Your flying in a desert area: so take at least 1/2 gal of water along in case you sink out and have to walk!

name: Flynns (Bishop - Owens Valley)
desc: large, space for several gliders; toplanding possible; windsocks (visible from LZ). Many met links: http://karicastle.com/owens-valley-wx/

name: Walt s Point - Horseshoe (Owens Valley- Lone Pine- Bishop)
desc:
Launch is either known as Walt's Point or Horseshoe.
This is more a HG site than a place for PG - as the launch requires a special technique: lay out your glider across the TO with the right wing tip right at the edge of launch; the bring up the right side first...
After TO turn right towards the small saddle (but don NOT fly across) - normally the thermals are right there. Thermals can be VERY strong: PG's normally don't fly here June - early September;
Many met links: http://karicastle.com/owens-valley-wx/

name: Daniels
desc:
1700 MSL, 880' vertical
Gentle slop, slot.
Glide slope to LZ: 4.3:1
Careful with rotor in bowl to right of launch.
Soarable along 1.5 mile ridge.

name: North Sheba Crater (Flagstaff)
desc: South face has two bench launches that favor south winds. Launch can be made in almost any direction from the top. Utilize the locals or regulars for knowledge on conditions and how rapidly they can change. Certain wind directions can cause mechanical turbulence in certain areas. Late morning and mid day in the warmer months can be quite strong.

name: Dry Canyon
desc:
Getting there: 105Â°53'10.00'W x 32Â°55'38.50'N. Accessible by 4x4 only on a badly eroded US Forest Service Rd. Turnoff from main road is here: 105Â°53'6.71'W x  32Â°56'54.82'N. You will have to go to Google Earth to see the road.  

Ratings: This site is P3 because you have a very short space (< 10 m) to launch because of rotor behind the ridge.  

HG launch: This is where the F.S. road takes you. This is not the recommended launch for PGs. It is more difficult to inflate the wing there because of the steep hill and rotor. Make sure you have good kiting skills as PG pilot. NO TOP LANDING!  

PG launch: From the HG launch, hike east to a rock band. There is an opening that allows to walk down to a col where the launch is located. It is clear of bushes and features a perfect 30-40 degrees rolling slope, no rotors, and slightly lower winds. HG to PG launch is a 5-7 min hike. 105Â°53'3.58'W x 32Â°55'35.33'N

You can soar the ridge for hours, go XC, or do a sledride of about 15 minutes. This is a fun site but there is substantial turbulence, especially in the spring and summer. Paragliders should launch before 10AM or after 4PM during the summer as it often gets blown out in between those times -- hang gliders only. In the fall and winter, PG is often good the whole day.  For the longest PG flights, get to launch around noon or 1PM and wait until conditions are appropriate.  This is not a crowded site. DANGERS: If you see or hear thunderstorms to the east or see the white sand being kicked up 15 miles west of the site, GET DOWN! 

Beware of the typical very rough southwest desert air in the spring/summer.

name: Squaw
desc:
West and Southeast launches, launch se in a.m., west afternoon.
West:  44° 0' 18.32''N, 116° 24' 45.05''W
Southeast:  44° 0' 17.95''N 116 °24' 33.16''W
watch your lines with the sharp basalt rocks

name: Swan Falls
desc: Cliff Launch, watch the rotor, gravel with some sharp basalt rocks and some sage brush.

name: 8th street
desc: grassy knob

name: Bogus Basin
desc: Tight gunsight between some small pine trees.

name: Melba Ridge
desc: Cliffy launch, take care with lines and basalt rock. Not a weather hazard, but maybe a health hazard is the feed lot at the south end of the ridge, your nose will tell you when a big fat juicy, er.. uhh.., thermal has released.

name: Herd Peak
desc:
South-West/West

High desert

Epic Vistas Don't fly on North days!

Don't fly mid-day in the summer!

Conditions can be very big.

name: Sea Grapes
desc:
Takeoff is from the base of a 25 foot ridge, winds from 12-16 mph are required to fly here and its illegal to touch the dunes or protected vegitation so flawless high wind ground handling skills are a must. P-3 or better skills required to manage the launch...weve never seen a p-2 fly here yet on their first try. 
 A .5 mile hike with gear is required to get from the legal parking to the best launch. gust lines from the water, or winds over 16mph can be treacherous, also blowbacks are a distinct possibility on cross days.

name: Garrapata
desc: Walk 'down' to the beach and turn left and you will see a 100yards or so of brocken cliff faces from 20-30ft with a bowl on the end....Launching is a little tricky, but if it's 16+, pick a face you like and back up into it and try a running step up launch from the beach into the lift ban, it's a little strange but works quite well in the right conditions(need a low gradient). If you can't get that you will need fairly good kiting skills to find a rock line to kite up..... Watch for gusts if your parked...it can pick up pretty good here...

name: Whaleback Mtn.
desc:
Recently expanded launch area along forest road at top of clearcut/burn area. Requires flat slope launch skills. See http://rvhpa.org/site-guide/whaleback/ Over development, cloud suck, strong desert conditions, dust devils, thermic LZ, high winds.
https://www.windy.com/41.534/-122.153?40.590,-122.153,7

name: Little Sur (Monterey)
desc: It's basiclly the gap between the road and fence line at North end of the straight away section of the highway 1. Check google earth pic.... ((You're launching off a road embankment so traffic is quite an issue if you drop your wing or get pulled over the highway))... Getting pushed over the back and landing on the road embankment is a real issue when it's strong. Stick to light days...The water is sheltered a bit from the open ocean swells so it looks calmer than it actually is. Oh yea, and the point to the north is called Hurricane point for some odd reason.

name: Fort Funston (no PG)
desc: On the sea. High = 80 m

name: Thomas Mt
desc:
Mike Harper writes:
If you are looking for places to fly near Idylewild you might check out Thomas Mt.
Justin and I flew there a couple years ago. We cleared a TO area at 33.599911  -116.653854.  There is an area just below launch to land on forest land than needs to cleared of some vegetation. 33.585042  -116.663961. Justin squeaked it in there and I landed next to the Anza High School. The best place to land if you get up would be Garner Valley 33.629535   -116.634438. It's a 100+ acre of forest land clear of trees with a dry steam to land in, much like Soboba without the trees.  Check the wind at  http://cdec.water.ca.gov/cgi-progs/queryFx?s=anz. Best wind direction is SW which occurs in the early afternoon. By late afternoon the wind has usually clocked around to west making it cross. The RASP always looks inviting for the area. There could also be places along the road to launch to the east towards Garner Valley.

name: Heavener SW Launch
desc: Located in Heavener, Oklahoma, near the Heavener State Park. Access the Two Launch Sites from the State Park.  Southwest Launch and Southeast Launch, provide 800 Vertical.

name: Mount Nebo
desc: Located in the Mount Nebo State Park there are three launches: a South facing, East facing. and a North/East facing.  NE launch is a Roll-off.

name: Panorama
desc:
Beautiful Bermuda sod roll-off
ENE Launch

name: Buffalo
desc: Nice grassy roll-off

name: Mt. Magazine
desc: Cliff

name: Greenpoint Frankfort
desc: Paragliders launch from a sandy, wide launch atop the dune ridge. 370' above the lake/beach.

name: Hatcher's Pass
desc:
Many launch opportunities, but the best is from summit lake in the afternoon.  There are potential takeoffs from numerous mountains in the area with 30 minutes hike.  The takeoff at Summit Lake is accessible by car.  It's a lovely place for a picnic and a hike if the flying isn't on. Uh...  It's Alaska.
http://www.cnfaic.org/wx/wx_marmot.php

name: Little Yancey
desc: Overgrown - abbandoned

name: Short Mountain
desc:
P2
Cliff Launch

name: McGee (Owens Valley)
desc: Takeoff for Paragliders is on steep hillside clearing just below a east facing switchback in the road which overlooks Crowley Lake. The best takeoff for hangliders would be from the road itself. many met links: http://karicastle.com/owens-valley-wx/

name: Mt.Sentinel (Missoula)
desc: West winds and NW winds

name: Keel Mountain (Huntsville)
desc: About 900 feet above the LZ and it plenty big enough to set up a few gliders.  It is a slot launch in the trees.

name: Cherry Tree
desc: 4 wheel drive or high stance vehicle required to reach launch.  Wide open on top with top landing easy.

name: Jenkins (Birmingham)
desc: Wide open field on top open for top landing

name: Boulder
desc:
35-45 Minutes hike from end of Locust St. in Boulder.  Three launch sites, with a maximum of 600 ft. vertical. As always in Colorado on the Front Range, be careful of westerly winds and over development.
You can get local weather links on this website: https://redtailparagliding.com/weather/.

name: Geertson Cr. Mail Road
desc:
Rolling sage brush.
43,13'29.97' N
113,43'04.19' W

name: Edgewater
desc: Weather suitable for soaring is very limited.  Even the weather forecasts don't accurately predict flying weather.  Many touring PG'ers come to the site but leave shortly after arriving.  The local guys who drive to the site are right about 60% of the time.  Best to have business in Cleveland and likely to stick around a week.

name: Mt Herman
desc: Steep grassy meadow ending to point of no return cliff. Room for 2 gliders.

name: Box Canyon (Tucson)
desc:
Dehydration and heat exhaustion are a real hazard during hot weather. Bring plenty of water for the hike up. 
Desert flying is hazardous in hot weather. Inexperienced pilots should limit flights to evenings under the guidance of a local pilot. DO NOT attempt to fly this site for the first time without a local guide! 
Rain or virga in the desert produces gust fronts and microbursts. Watch for overdevelopment or lines of moving dust. 
Desert vegetation has teeth and eats the wings of the unwary or careless.

name: Mustang
desc:
Southwest winds. Typically flown in evening glass-offs. This site can be unpredicatble and is easily blown out.
West-facing walk-up on BLM land, about 5900 feet MSL. Takes winds ssw (200) through wnw (290) up to about 15 mph, depending on pilot's experience level. Rarely flyable if winds aloft are forecast over 10 knots at 6k, 15 knots at 9k. Don't launch in winds over 16 knots (18 mph)! In strong southwest conditions (common summer afternoons) getting blown over the back is very bad. Rotor lives there and will hurt you. Winds aloft can be considerably different than those on launch or in the LZ, particularly in high pressure weather. 
If winds are northwest aloft the \'biscuit\' (the nearby butte - you'll know it when you see it) produces turbulence. 
Don't land in fields north and west of launch due to hostile landowners. 
Dehydration and heat exhaustion are a real hazard during hot weather. Bring plenty of water for the hike up. 
Rain or virga in the desert sometimes produce gust fronts and microbursts. Watch for overdevelopment or lines of moving dust. 
Desert vegetation has teeth and eats the wings of the unwary or careless.

name: Miller Canyon
desc:
Prevailing wind pattern is light SE in morning and 10-15 NW in afternoon. Perfect launch conditions are light SE winds. However, the launches are east of Miller Peak (~9500â€™) and Carr Peak (~9000â€™), leaving it in the lee of the mountains in prevailing afternoon winds. Often, thermals block the winds that have west in their names, and allow for safe launching. These OTB winds then allow for a great tailwind for XC routes to the E and NE. However, winds are often very shifty on launch due to this rotor and thermal activity. Generally, in the summer launches must occur early (10 to noon), as with any SE facing site, with afternoon winds that blow down. Major XC April through July. Late summer often capped off by over-development. Typically high to very high top of lift.
Launch 1: SE cliff, 7600 MSL, 2900 above LZ. It has a clear 20+ foot long area to run- which then drops off into a cliff. Low or No-wind launches are fairly safe due to the running room and the cliff. Wind will blow vertically up the cliff face, so appropriate precautions are suggested. AWCL skills will likely be required for winds over 10-15 mph and it gets dangerous over 20mph. If it is soarable, do not expect to launch yourself. The SE launch is generally dangerous for paragliders. A pretty nasty rotor often sets up +15 feet above the ramp, twisting canopies just as you are leaving the ground.
Launch 2: E slope, 7600' MSL, 1/4 mile hike out. A bit shallow and is subject to crosswinds at end of launch, caution is required in southeast conditions. HG/PG.
Launch 3: NE slope, 7600' MSL, 1/4 mile hike out. HG/PG.
Launch owner: USFS. SAHGA has a special use permit, key access. Insured through SAHGA. In strong conditions the SE (cliff) launch requires good AWCL skills. 
Controlled airspace two mile radius around aerostat (tethered balloon) to the north. Do not fly north of Carr Canyon road east of Route 92. 
Controlled airspace to the north around Ft. Huachuca army base. Check Phoenix sectional chart for details, or consult a local. 
Unpredictable, often powerful desert weather. Dust devils will flip gliders on occasion. Zeus will toss lightning at unsuspecting pilots holding bags of aluminum tubing. Occasional Hail. 
Some local pilots bite.
Barbed wire fence on the south east corner, and along road on NE side. Stay clear of the cows (and associated material) if present. The sign post at the â€˜Yâ€™ in the road in the LZ is hard to see on some approaches. The Y is a tempting spot to land so pay attention. There are powerlines on three sides of the LZ but are pretty far away- arrive at LZ high to ensure avoiding. Expect turbulance over LZ if winds are from the SW.

name: Bell Mountain
desc: Mostly rocks and sand and about two and a half gliders wide.  Located at 34.57'33.57N and 83.43'45.96W at 3350'MSL. Glide ratio is 4.59:1 with a 1421' vertical to LZ.

name: Pigeon Hill
desc: E facing cliff launch, 1150' AGL, 3-1 glide, 3 mile ridge

name: Chilhowee Mountain
desc:
Launch is on Park Service property in the Cherokee National Forest. Almost due West facing.
Launch is sloped and grassy.

name: Little Gap
desc: About 1km from the parking lot along the Appalachian Trail, where the trees open up on the right. Just before the power line. Need  NW -N- NE winds.

name: Eagle Rock
desc:
The site is on Crawford Mountain and actually has two launches: one NW and one SE.
Added information: Eagle Rock gets its name from a town in the valley. 

NW launch does not work the greatest with a West cross, more favorable with North winds.

name: red wing
desc: take off is a nice grassy area with the tinyest slope. This may look like it is only a ridge soaring site, and it is in the winter, but in the summer, there are some thermals too.

name: Hayden Ridge
desc:
West/Southwest

Big and open but steep and a little rocky.

name: Morningside
desc:
Full service flight park with large west facing training hill,  150 ft 250 ft & 450 ft launches via ATV access to ridge soaring and thermals. Tow operation for Hang Gliders.
>> check out this video about Morningside: http://www.viddyou.com/viddstream?videoid=43807 Northeast! Weather changes frequently. Call the flight park for info.

name: Telluride Gold Hill
desc:
Morning launch is East into Bear Creek, it is best with very light wind forcast, you launch into nice cycles coming straight in. Evening launch is West into prevailing West winds.

GPS coordinates of launch are 
N 37.89416 W 107.82339 This is a very high altitude mountain site. Conditions can be very strong.

name: Channing hill - Benicia
desc:
Channing hill Park. Go through the park, up hill, follow the track up up up and to the left  at the top until you find a bench at the top of the hill, walk down a few yards and enjoy the flight on this site. For flying Benicia/Vallejo, check the winds at http://www.wunderground.com/weatherstation/WXDailyHistory.asp?ID=KCABENIC2.  Joel McMinn runs the weather station from his house, which is about 300 yards SW of the west-side LZ.  Check out the photos on the paraglide Benicia/Vallejo link on the weather site.

The east side works best with E to ESE winds from 7-20 mph.  Less than 7 mph will provide only extended sled rides.  The west side will work in SW to NW winds, but W is best. Look for 10-15 mph, gusting to under 20.

name: Yaquina Head
desc: A rocky promontory with a lighthouse forms the outer part of the headland. Launches are possible to the north and south along the ridge to the east of the lighthouse, or to the south after a short hike to the top of the headland. Beware of strong shear layers which can produce light winds on the surface with blow-back conditions only a few dozen feet above. If the weather station wind sensors are spinning madly, don't assume the light winds you feel are real! Coastal winds may change abruptly, and laminar shear layers can produce surprisingly high backwards-flying-velocities. Low clouds and fog may obscure visibility, and a nearby non-towered airport with ILS approach makes operation unwise with ceiling below 1000 feet. Check current NOTAMS before flying, and contact local club for information.

name: Cove (Richfield- Monroe)
Mt.Edna (Marysvale- Richfield)
desc:
Utah's highest drive-up site! (Early) morning thermal site. 
TO in almost every direction possible.
North: stony Due to Altitude, weather conditions/ winds can change very rapidly!

name: Monroe Peak (Richfield)
desc:
Easy West facing launch. Utah's 3rd highest drive-up launch with 6500ft vertical.
TOP-landing possible. Central Utah wx: http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/slc/current/meso.cenut.php

name: Lake Mountain (Saratoga Springs)
desc: Rather technical: flat surface near radio towers

name: Parker (Koosherem)
desc:
GPS 38 24'57' N (38.4158) 111 52'02'W (111.8672) elevation 8440ft/2573m;
Very nice west facing launch. 30 mile (48Km) soarable ridge. Central Utah wx: http://www.wrh.noaa.gov/slc/current/meso.cenut.php

name: Mount Parapoo
desc: North and West slopes, preferably from the Western peak. 4WD may be required to access portions of the Northern slope. Eastern peak is an active landfill. There are 2 weather stations located on site. One is at the base of the Northern slope (Tower) and the second is on the West peak (Site2). They are updated periodically and can be viewed at this site: http://www.chestercountyswa.org/index.aspx?nid=191

name: Bria Dog Ridge (Mammoth Lake)
desc: A small patch is clear of bush/ stones, just enough to lay out 1 PG; HG can set up on the 'turning pad' behind launch.

name: Francis Peak
desc: A nice west facing grassy  meadow at 9200 feet/2804meters. 2wheel drive access on a fairly good dirt road. Plan for 45 minutes of driveing time. Sometimes soarable, sometimes good thermals but you can't use them past the 9500ft ceiling, which is a major bummer. Absolutely gorgeous view of the Great Salt Lake especially at sunset. Launch turns catabatic at sunset! Lake effect storm development can happen very fast. Don't fly if it is even slightly unstable. Strong winds can push you over the back side into very remote country. Follow the spines to ensure best lift.

name: St.George -the 'Usual' (the 'U')
desc:
Quite large cleared place on top of the ridge with some wind indicators.
Cliff like launch, but with a some headwind easily doable... ...

name: Hancock
desc: Works best with south west winds. Nice afternoon thermal cycles come up from the south west making a nice launch. In light winds there are sage brush and uneven terrain  making it at least a P-3 launch Winds Parallel to the ridge can cause some nasty rotors. and as always with a mountain thermal site (especially in high pressure) a dusty can drag you when you least expect it. (As my broken nose will attest)

name: Kahana
desc:
This site is insured by USHPA. The Hawaii Paragliding Association maintains a permit from the State of Hawaii for members of the association. Before flying here pilots must be current members of USHPA and the local club. There is no cost for visitors to join the local club.

There are multiple spots to launch from along two ridges, from 250 to 350 feet ASL. Hiking up from the landing zone to any launch takes about 15 minutes. Winds are best from NE to ENE. If the winds are too east the landing zone doesn't get clean air and pilots may find themselves landing in sink or rotor. Also, rain squalls periodically blow in from the ocean, bringing gust fronts and rain and sometimes changing the direction of airflow in a dramatic fashion.

name: Mt Graylock
desc: The top Greylock is the highest point in Massachusetts. The mountain is a state park opening in the middle of May and closing late October. Greylock has a paved road to the top with a parking lot. There is a $2.00 fee for parking in this parking lot. There is also a lodge open to the public which has bathrooms, serves food and sells souvenirs. Please keep in mind that there could be a lot of non flying visitors to the park and respect should be given to them at all times. The park is also patrolled by a park ranger. Greylock rating is H4/P4 site. H3/P3 are allowed to fly there with a USHPA advanced observer, examiner or advancer instructor. The pilot observing must be present every time the H3/P3 launches. If you need an observer, please make arrangements with them prior to showing up. The pilot must sign in and show their current USHPA rating card at the front desk of the lodge. Pilot must sign a waiver the first time they fly Greylock every year. Pilot must also sign in every time that they fly there. Don’t forget your USHPA card. No card, no flying, no exceptions. Launch is located on the peak of the mountain facing southeast. The mountain can be flown in south to northeast conditions much of the time. Hang gliding set up area in the mowed grass area near the monument. The hang gliding launch is a short flat slope located just off the mowed grass area on the southeast side of the mountain. The paragliding launch is a large flat area above and behind the hang gliding launch on the mowed grass. Caution is needed when launching due the close proximity of the other winged pilot and the non flying public. After launching, be respectful of other pilots trying to launch and the viewing public. PLEASE NOTE: No top landing. Since top landing will put the site at risk for everyone, anyone caught top landing will permanently lose their right to fly Greylock.

name: New Jack City - East Ridge
desc:
From the back South corner of the New Jack City area, there is a small elevated parking area, just around the corner of the big rock formation is an old road or path at least heading SW up to the ridge.  Follow this up (10 minute hike tops), and you'll find yourself at the South end of the ridge looking West.  I had to kick out and cut down a few plants/cacti to make it suitable for launch but last time I was up there it still looked good, although it's still a very small launch.  Rosette launch skills are desirable to avoid tangled lines on rocks or debris.

The launch is somewhat wind sheltered by a smaller ridge in front, so after launch be careful of turbulence until you get above the ridge and further North with better airflow.  Also because of the wind shelter you may only get about 9-10 mph of gusty wind at launch but 20' over the ridge it could be blowing 20mph (max trim speed for my glider), so just because it seems light at take-off it may still be viable and by the same token don't wait for stronger conditions because up higher they may be badly blown out! Watch for high winds aloft.  Just 20 feet up and the wind had double on me and I was parked and trying to get aerodynamic to maintain my position.  I would recommend flying in the late afternoon as things are calming down so you don't get stuck in anything.  The wind is a little bit gusty as well which is to be expected from the desert.

name: New Jack City - West Ridge
desc:
From the center of New Jack City, by the outhouse and main camping area, look West and you will see an old decommissioned road heading West over the ridge.  Hike up there, it's about 120m of vertical gain, so about 10 - 20 minute hike depending on how fast you are.  At the top is a post and a relatively flat area.  Last time I was here I tried to kick out any small plants and cacti and get rid of any rocks that looked like line snaggers.

The West launch *MAY* be suitable for hang gliders, but good luck getting it up there.  I don't hang glide so I don't know what details you are looking for, but I would guess that it goes nicely when it's on.

You can launch either East or West. East is not so good, very turbulent and I would recommend checking out the East Ridge if winds are from the East.

Launching West is where the best flying is to be had but I've yet to soar it, just one short sled ride.  I found the winds died down drastically about 20m down even though it felt perfect at take-off. From New Jack City - East Ridge:
Watch for high winds aloft. Just 20 feet up and the wind had double on me and I was parked and trying to get aerodynamic to maintain my position. I would recommend flying in the late afternoon as things are calming down so you don't get stuck in anything. The wind is a little bit gusty as well which is to be expected from the desert.

name: Lake Isabella
desc:
Launch from anywhere near the top of the radio tower, the road may work but could be a bit windy.  I launched a bit further down and found better conditions.  Launch is South facing is into the predominant wind direction.  Apparently the wind is like clock work here.  I would avoid middle of the day flying until you have more experience because it can get very blown out.  Stick to morning and late afternoon.  It's about a 30 minute hike up to the top if you just park out front and hike straight up.  There is a fenced off road further along the road that you can drive up but not sure about private property issues.  The walk up along the road may be easier for those that prefer an easy stroll.

I'm not a hang glider but I'm pretty sure that they could fly here, nice steep cliff to launch from and plenty of wind. If you fly in the morning watch out for wind strength increasing as the day goes on.  It can get very windy here.

name: Kernville Slabs
desc:
From the campground underneath the Kernville slabs start hiking up for about 20 or 30 minutes until you find away around all the bluffs.  This may require some minor scrambling, watch out for critters like snakes and skunks, I saw both up there.  Once you get above the slabs you'll come to easier grassier terrain.  Launch is quite wind sheltered and very misgiving as to actual conditions.  

One launch is to head WNW, you will probably have to run for quite a bit and then dodge a few trees on your way out.  I had to get rid of a smaller bush the first time I was there as it was right in the way.  There is lots of sticks and debris around so do your best to keep your lines clear.

It took me a few tries to launch here due to high wind shadowing from trees in front.  Also the conditions felt almost lee side or catabatic as cycles seemed to be getting weaker and less frequent and even flipping my leading edge over once as I waited.  Regardless, conditions in the air were quite the opposite. High winds during the middle of the day.  Even during the evening it was quite gusty with some moderate amounts of turbulence.  This ain't your local coastal ridge soaring site!

name: Bingen
desc:
Description of Site: Overlooking the Columbia River Gorge, Bingen is Gorgeous. A deluxe manicured grass LZ at the Bingen Marina from a 2100' sled ride with soaring potential with a reasonable drive around makes this one of the gorge's premier sites. With south and west launches it works best sunny & calm, but also works in very light east or west winds (under 10 mph). On good thermal days, gains of 2500' are common with XC potential to the east. if there is a wind, westerlies are best from the Intermediate west launch, east winds tend to be rough and unpredictable making for crosswind launches and tumbling air at the south launch. Unfortunately, Bingen bisects the high wind windsurfing capitol of North America and private property. If there are whitecaps on the river at Bingen Marina or a wind line is moving from the west, it is blown out. Like all other Gorge sites, pilots must keep a sharp eye on the river for the streaks of dull looking water and whitecapswarning signs of the Gorge locomotive, The Wind.

Park across the road from the log cabin.  The trail starts walking downhill and turns back uphill as it goes around the property owned by the log cabin.  Please do not cut across their property as it only takes 1 minute longer to go around (if that)

As you approach the gate at the cattle fence, please remember to close it and latch the chain behind you.  The hike up to the South launch is 5 -10 minutes from the car.  You'll see a large flat launch area west of a large lone oak tree.  This launch is suitable only in East or South winds.  (most likely East)  Make sure you have visited the LZ prior to going to the launch as the Columbia River Gorge is famous for higher winds in the LZ.  If it's windy and you can't kite the LZ, don't launch off the top.  

If the wind is out of the west, continue along the trail for another 15 minutes and you'll end up at the west launch. 
This is a great launch for spring thermal and ridge soaring.  Keep in mind from this launch, you cannot see the LZ.
Make sure you keep an eye on the water as wind moves in from the west like a freight train.  If you can see white caps 4 miles away near the hatchery, then you need to top land or get down fast.  Keeping an eye on the river is critical. Wind comes up like a freight train.  If in doubt, better to be on the ground wishing you were in the air than the opposite.

Winds are often very different above 1500 feet. Watch landing area closely when coming down.

name: Heavener SSE Launch
desc: Located in Heavener, Oklahoma, near the Heavener State Park. Access the Two Launch Sites from the State Park. Southwest Launch & Southeast Launch provide 800 Vertical

name: Bellyache Ridge
desc:
Both landing and launch are paved drive to locations.  Bellyache is a P2 rated site and registered by the local Vail Soaring Club.  Visiting pilots and tandem passengers are urged to contact David Champaign at:
www.VailValleyParagliding.com or Greg Kelley at www.aircrossusa.com Primarily flown in the mornings before the winds shift and come 'over the back'.  Watch out for the wind shift.

name: Grandeur
desc: Hike up towards Grandeur Peak. There are several places to launch. Good launch at central spine (grassy area approx. 5900 ft); more technically difficult launch on southern spine (6200 ft). Good launch where both spines converge (6500 ft).

name: Bee Canyon LFB
desc: Launch is a little hill (Little F*****g Bump) at 3,500' elevation facing generally West. Hike up dirt road from parking area on back (East) side of hill. Bench up using the larger hill to the East of the LFB and jump to any of the other hills to the North and Southeast if enough lift. The backstop for this area is Mount San Jacinto, which develops thunderstorms in the summer.

name: Pine Ridge
desc:
Pine Ridge is a Central Oregon ridge soaring site with mild thermals mixed in spring and fall, more radical thermals during the summer. It is a one mile long ridge facing the prevailing northwest winds and located entirely within the Crooked River National Grasslands. Launches for this site are all walk-up. North to northwest winds are the best flying, shorter duration flights can be had when winds are from the northeast or 
west. Regular controlled burning has removed much of the juniper, which once dominated this site leaving a multitude of open grass launches and landing areas. Because all launches are below ridge top, it is advisable to check wind speed and direction at the top of the ridge prior to any launch.

name: Pine Mt. (training hill)
desc: From the rock 'L' look to the east and you'll see a faint trail leading up to a well-cleared launch area.

name: Agave Hill
desc:
There is some turbulence at the launch face and in front but it is benign. There is no cliff or major obstacles either in front or behind launch which means it's easy to bail in case you need or want to.  The area in front of launch generally has good lift if the winds are coming in over 12 mph. Soaring is possible with as little 5-6 mph if you launch at just the right part of the cycle (at the beginning).  To get to the top of the mountains, see 'Soaring the Triangle' below.  Do not fly north and enter the the canyon from Agave because you may encounter much stronger winds near the Mundy's Gap vortex.  However, the house thermal is at the north end of the hill just north of Agave Hill (see image below).  Do NOT fly behind launch unless you are certain the winds aloft are less than 15 (PG only).  Top landing at Agave is possible but difficult because of the danger of being sucked into Mundy's Gap.  In general, you want to stay out in front of Agave and to the south of the canyon.  These areas are safe from the effects of the vortex at the Gap.  Skilled pilots can attempt top landings if they check the winds behind launch.

Be certain to check winds aloft.   If it's over 20 mph at 9K', do not fly (PG) as you can get blown over the top which would be an adventure.  Remember:  This is the desert and air during mid day can be challenging.  Less experienced pilots should stick to the early AM or late PM.  Laminar air is almost always present late in the day and dreamboat soaring in the Franklins occurs at that time.  Thermals are gigantic here, as in the Owens Valley, so always check the weather or with us before flying. It is important to note that the jet stream affects our flying in the Franklins by causing turbulence and gusting in the lower atmosphere.  Our experience is:  Enjoy the Franklin Mountains when the jet stream is not overhead nor within 100 miles of us.  With steady winds aloft and no jet stream, the Franklins can be a pilot's ultimate delight.

name: Kiting Park (Las Vegas)
desc:
None!!! WARNING:  WARNING:  WARNING:  WARNING:  WARNING:
WARNING:  WARNING:  WARNING:  WARNING:  WARNING:

DO NOT ATTEMPT TO UTILIZE DURING OR AFTER RAIN, THE BASIN IS IN MORTAL DANGER OF FLOODING.

name: Garlock
desc: 35.418N 117.85W Elevation 4760 ft. (1450 m) Could be too windy for PG during summer.

name: Sollie Smith
desc: Requires a drive up, 2WD all the way. Open grassy slope in west-facing bowl. Soaring potential along south-facing ridge, west-facing Sugar Hill to southeast. Marine air can condense rapidly in front of launch creating white-out conditions. Strong thermals possible during summer, prevailing northerly summer winds may be thermal blocked up launch slope but create rotor turbulence aloft.

name: Skinny Ridge
desc: if the wind is cross do not launch!!!

name: Roan (Rifle)
desc:
not really 'meadows', but different large grassy spaces with little sage or stones;
many TO options available overdevellopment, N wind

name: Villa Grove
desc: Located near Villa Grove, CO in the San Luis Valley. Site faces SW, launch at approximately 9,300ft MSL, The primary LZ is at 7500ft MSL and is miles and miles of grass and short sage fields starting at the base of the Sangre De Cristo range. The Sangre De Cristos range from 12,000ft MSL to over 14,000ft MSL and run unbroken for over 60 miles to the south of launch, then a 15 mile gap and continuing into New Mexico. Both ridge soaring and thermal opportunities. Flying often possible year round. Great XC potential. Often called the little Owens Valley. This tends to be a strong wind site, suitable mostly for hang gliders rather than PG's.  July thru Aug. tends to have a monsoon weather pattern which produces huge cumulonimbus clouds.  Flying in the presence of these clouds can be VERY hazardous.  For PG's to fly safely, the forecast winds should be 10 mph or less.  The winds on launch/ top can be 2X the landing zone.

name: Atlanta Paragliding Enterprises (APE)
desc: Tow at any direction

name: Henninger Flats - No Safe Local LZ
desc:
Open for now but there is no safe LZ available at the moment.  Anywhere that looks good is off-limits due to private property and would jeopardize the site.  XC flying is the best bet to find a safe LZ.  Please message a local before flying this site to get the low down (https://www.socalxcleague.com/ Aaron Price)

Take-off can be found on the trail up to Henninger flats out of the Eaton Canyon Wash.  As you are nearing the campground, you will be on a last leg of the trail heading West-ish.  As you enter this leg there will be a small power line going up the ridge that you will cross underneath, about 40 yards past this you will see a steep dirt path that leads up about 10' to a grassier slope, this is your launch.  There is one tree which divides the launch between a South launch and a West launch so choose carefully which was you want to launch, depending on the cycle it can blow both ways. Standard SoCal flying rules apply, expect punchy stuff in midsummer

name: Section 16
desc: Take off is from St. Patrick's lookout at the top of the Section 16 trail. Park at the trailhead on Lower Gold Camp Road and hike the trail to the top of the saddle. A spur trail goes east along the ridge to the lookout. The Take off can be challenging due to the steepness of the launch slope. The hike takes about 1 hour and about 2 miles with a 1500' alt climb. Wind coming over the backside. Usually there are nice easterly thermal breezes for flying, however on high climb outs there can be a shear layer because the prevailing winds are generally west at altitude (12,000')

name: Otto's Ridge
desc: this site is only flown early in the morning in catabatic winds; flying normally stops as soon as thermal activity sets in.

name: Blue Rock (Vallejo)
desc: https://www.wunderground.com/dashboard/pws/KCAVALLE53

name: Bidwell Park North Rim
desc:
Must Have Permit and Sticker to Fly this Site

Contact Bidwell park Fliers- site 
administrators:
Jon Stallman
Shad Preston
Martin Roland
Wil Brown

Take Off and Landing Zone map:
http://www.flyzephyr.com/Bidwell%20Map.htm.pdf

Park Map:
http://www.chico.ca.us/general_services_department/park_division/documents/Bidwell_Park_Bike_Map.pdf Wind Conditions for Flying 
Call the Chico Municipal Airport's automated weather service (530.879.3850).  The ideal wind conditions are, on average, are from 130° - 170° at around 10 mph, with no gusts.  The site will often work with 180° - 190° winds, but the turbulence on the ridge in these conditions is dangerous.

Monkey Launch:  No more than 15 mph.  At 18 mph, the lift band flattens.  At less than 12 mph, it will be difficult to make it to the primary LZ. 

Julian's Launch:  This is a cliff launch and is about 300' lower than the Rattle Snake launch, so you will need to bench up to get high.  It has an open area, with no rocks, and a house thermal right at launch.  Look for 170° at 10 mph, on the airport phone, and 160° at 15 mph on top. 

Rattle Snake Launch:  Look for 130° - 170°, from 9 -16 mph.  12 mph is perfect.  16 mph is pushing the limits, with the steep gradient. 

Weather.com is the most accurate basic weather site for this area.  If the weather forecast predicts that the wind will be south from 5-12 mph, then the winds will actually be southeast from 5-18 mph.  Below 200', strong winds blow through the canyon from the west. When parking at Bear Hole, the wind may appear that it's coming from the west, but upon cresting thermal hill, and higher, the wind will be southeast.  Avoid the south-wind rotors on the opposite rim wall.

In the summer, there is usually an inversion between 3,000' - 5000'.  Mid-day thermals can be like bullets shooting out of the LZ, especially on low inversion days.

Always be aware of the wind speed and direction and don't push the envelope.  There can be a strong rotor if the wind is too far from the east.

For ridge lift:  Look for 130° - 170° at 9 mph (reported from the airport phone). 

For ridge lift with thermals:  Look for a good skew T lapse rate, with south winds from 130° - 170° from 4-9 mph. 

For convergence with ridge lift:  Later in the evenings, the sun shines on the west slopes of north rim, while the prevailing wind is from the south.  If you get up with ridge lift and then then manage to drift back on the rim, you can enter the convergence zone between the heated lee of the rim and the prevailing ridge lift.  In these conditions, you can gain from 1,000' - 3,000' of altitude. 

For a glass-off:  In the summer, the daytime heating transitions to glass-off conditions at around 6:00 pm.  Even if the winds are 20-30 mph on launch, the delta breezes and central valley winds decrease and the latent heat lifts off until dark, making for magical, smooth flights.

name: Hopewell Junction
desc: Hill over the Sylvan Lake

name: West Rutland
desc:
Covered metal ramp facing SW.  Most hang gliding pilots find the launch very comfortable.  Paragliding pilots need to layout and pull up behind the ramp and carefully launch without running off the side of the ramp.  Large setup area in a grove of shade trees accommodates up to 30 hang gliders. Launch works best in calm to moderate SW winds, but is soarable with light S through W winds. The launch is near a natural gap along a long ridge line.  Air flows through the valley in front of launch and speeds up as it flows through the more narrow gap.  Pilots have measured wind speed above the ridge at 10mph, while in the gap, the wind speed was measured at 30mph.  Don't get caught in the gap with a glider that can not penetrate stronger winds.  Avoiding the gap is easy to do.

Light south wind days are fine, however, as the wind speed increases turbulence increases as air flows over a point (Birds Eye) on the other side of the valley.  There are exciting stories that start with pilots launching on strong south days.

name: Sandia Peak
desc:
Takeoff is located atop Sandia Peak and accessable via the Sandia Peak Tramway.
Launch is very narrow and steep with little room for error. 2018: greatly improved. Summer brings strong thermal activity and potential for thunderstorms and associated turbulence and gust fronts.

name: Wellfleet
desc: 100' Sand Dune

name: South mountain
desc: South launch suitable for SE to SW winds. SSE preferred . actual wind: https://azhpa.org/south-mountain/

name: Whale Hill
desc: very large, open 'meadow'; almost anywhere on the 'hill'. Early morning site; best launched before 1100am

name: Abernathy Creek
desc:
At least two launch sites.
Bench at 3464 MSL and Summit launch at 4100 MSL above bench.
Many other possibilities depending on winds.

name: Tumwater Mountain
desc: Mountain launch. Small, room to layout one glider. Steep, narrow corridor launch. 2900ft vertical. Town and LZ is almost directly below launch. winds over the back.

name: Nappanee
desc: gravel road north/south and east/west 2 miles long

name: Cullom
desc: Take off is suitable at any direction. Road are N/S  and E/W 2 miles in every direction

name: Hearne Municipal Airport
desc: Takeoff is typically performed with truck tow. Scooter tow is sometimes performed as well. Hearne can also use aerotow, but it is not typically perormed.

name: Mt. Umunhum
desc: This is an old military site with lots of toxic material being cleaned up, but will soon be opened up for recreational use including free flight.  Now is our chance to simulate some flights on it, and figure out the ideal LZ's and XC routes for various wind conditions.

name: Shaw Butte
desc: Very small rocky launch. Not for beginners. You must have confidence and skill kiting your glider. Expect to be lofted while still in reverse position when the winds are above 8 mph. Snagging and breaking of upper lines is a real possibility. EXTREME heat in summer months. Not a pleasant hike at all. Great flights can be had during the later part of the Monsoon Season, but obviously you need to be familiar with the typical weather pattern. Dangerous storms can arise quickly.

name: Grizzly Mountain
desc: near antennas

name: West Mountain (Payson)
desc: Given coordinates are for East TO - just past the antennas. WIth a bit of experience launch options for allmost all direction can be found.

name: Eagle Summit
desc:
There are multiple launches in this area and multiple LZ's
there are lots of places to fly from
area is above tree line for the most part so there is only low lying vegetation everywhere.
CAUTION: there can be many Sharp rocks on some launches that like to eat wings. Big Trucks on hwy.
strong winds Possible.
contact local pilots for more info.

name: Indian Creek Air Park
desc:
This is a scooter tow site. Suitable winds are se to sw and ne to nw. Light winds any direction. Only open to flying when the Pro is here. Call 972-390-9090 to find out if it is open. heavy rains temporarily make the fields unusable.


Strong wings > 10 mph won't work for paragliders.

Very strong wings > 15 mph won't work for hang gliding.

name: Masonville
desc: private property!

name: Marmot Hatcher Pass  AK
desc: http://www.cnfaic.org/wx/wx_marmot.php

name: Curtis Canyon
desc: alternative to Beaver/ Snow King, if wind (W / NW) there is too strong

name: Plymouth -Peaked Cliff
desc: nil

name: Arkoma Sod Farms
desc: This is the training site for www.RvPPG.com

name: Cannon Mountain Ski Area
desc: coordinates to be verified!  > please update

name: Crawford
desc: There are two main launches, one at the reflector towers, and one 200 yards north on the ridge. Top landings in strong cross-winds not advised

name: Enjoy Field
desc:
For paragliding we have nearby roads that are very suitable - no power lines.  
All this is located next to Enjoy Field airfield, which is midwest hanggliding mecca. Roads that we are towing from are up to 3 miles away - it is very exciting when your first xc is from road to airfield! You have to be USHPA certified to fly paraglider or powered paraglider from field.

name: Hull Mountain
desc: Launch Best in SW wind, works W to SSW.

name: Goat Rock
desc: Take off is typically north corner of parking lot.  It's possible to launch and fly the south side as well.

name: Buddha (Closed)
desc: Buda is a Private Closed site that requires specific â€œby invitation onlyâ€ permission by the land owner to fly.

name: Lee Vining
desc: Many met links: http://karicastle.com/owens-valley-wx/

name: Fort Flagler-Harmon
desc: Cliff launch with deep rotor boundary. Wind is too strong when white caps start to appear on water.  Spring and late fall are best. Tends to get thermal blocked in summer.

name: Mt. Tom
desc: Difficult - very narrow, uneven, cliff launch.

name: Wes-Mar Airfield
desc: Privately owned grass runway used for scooter and aero towing.

name: Whitwell - Tennessee Tree Toppers
desc:
2100ft
Ideal 130-180 winds favored
OK 120-180 winds Ideal 130-180 winds.
OK 120-180 winds 
8-10mph for soaring conditions.
Thermal site primarily.

name: Apache Maid (Flagstaff)
desc: Launch is quite tight with a steep drop-off.  Tree hazard right behind launch.

name: Sand Turn, WY
desc:
Take off is at a turn-out on the last big switchback on highway 14 going over the Bighorns. Turbulance or shears can occur when thermals going up on the east slope of the Bighorns hits the prevailing westerly winds.

Be sure to check forecast for what the Meteo winds are doing at 12,000.  Anything greater than 15mph Westerly should lead to extreme caution!

name: Zapata
desc: site of the 'WRE' (World Record Encampment)

name: Snowbird
desc:
High Altitude Launch!!
Just off the gondola, small ridge, which makes for tricky wind conditions.

name: Iron Mountain
desc:
Infrequently Flown and Launch not maintained and can not be maintained in this Open Space Preserve.

Mostly Hike & Fly and XC turn point from Little Black.

There are just so many better sites that are close.

Altitude above Launch is limited by airspace approach path into Miramar MCAS Airport (NKX).

name: Fuzz (Closed)
desc:
(Closed) Sub Site of Horse: Fuzz Launch East Facing launch is extremely dangerous and should be considered closed.
​Fuzz was a rarely used historical launch on the southwest side of the valley (across from the primary Horse Canyon launch site). 

initially imported from International Leonardo

Rating: Local H4 / P4; Visitors H4/ P4 only with Local Guide
East facing unimproved slope to cliff that “ Requires Extreme Caution" - and use is discouraged. 
Flight in Santa Ana Conditions is highly not recommended and highly hazardous Flight in Santa Ana Conditions is highly not recommended and highly hazardous

name: Icicle Ridge
desc:
Faces East, Southeast.
Open slope with a few skinny trees nearby and below launch.

name: Anderson Flat
desc: Near the turn-off for the Pilot Peak fire lookout (park at the junction)

name: Black Mountain
desc: The launch is about 3600' agl, reached by a gated but good logging road off the Mount Baker Highway. It is accessible for two-wheel drive vehicles, but 4-wheel drive is recommended as the last part is quite steep. You launch from the logging road, looking to the west with a spectacular view. Mt. Baker looms large over your left shoulder. Road is gated, key required for access. Needs a westerly wind component

name: Long Pool
desc: This is a very steep but smooth roll-off launch suitable for novice pilots with excellent wing control.  The LZ is directly below take-off.

name: Hayfield
desc:
One mile long North South tow road with a half mile long grass airstrip on the Northern most end.
Also directly 1 mile north is a 2 mile long East-West tow road.

name: Y Mountain
desc: Launch is just above the giant letter Y on the west side of the mountain.  Elevation is 6,300 feet above sea level or 1,700 feet above the valley below.  Great view overlooking Utah Valley just above BYU campus.

name: Cliffside
desc: Easy walk from major highway (State Highway 14). Or short steep Awd rocky road to top.

name: Hyner View
desc:

name: Rainbow Valley - East Patterson
desc:
Four launch sites allow always towing into wind, regardless of what the current wind direction is. This means that the site is flyable year-round, as long as it's not too windy, or raining (which it rarely does in Arizona)

If you come fly with the Arizona Tow Group, then winch fees will be $40 per day, tow count unlimited. Extreme heat in summer.  Violent afternoon thunderstorms in September.

name: Crested Butte Mountain
desc:
This site is in a U.S. Forest Service special use permit area issued to Crested Butte Mountain Resort. Crested Butte Mountain is a P4/H4 site and is insured and regulated by the Gunnison Valley Paragliding Association and the Crested Butte Soaring Society. 

Intermediate rated pilots (P3/H3) with a minimum of 50 hours of airtime can fly with a P4/H4 sponsor. Non-commercial tandem flights (T2 or T3) are allowed on a case-by-case basis with prior approval from CBMR and GVPA. (Allow 7-14 days for clearance from CBMR).

Visiting pilots must receive a site introduction from a local pilot, be current in high altitude launch skills with HA and TUR special skills ratings, sign a CBMR waiver and site regulations agreement, have a Colorado Search and Rescue Card (i.e hiking permit or fishing or hunting license - available at outdoor stores for $3) and stay at least 300' above and to the sides of any chairlift. 

During the summer the launch is accessed either the Silver Queen Lift or via private land and ski area leased land. Vehicle permits are required (your guide pilot will have one) and the ski resort is patrolled by security personnel. Winter access is from the Silver Queen Lift and requires a check-in with ski patrol before flying.

Launch is at 11,300' msl. It is basically a small launch only large enough for a single glider. It has been summarized as a cliff launch over a boulder field into a rotor. Combined with the tall trees and a running ski lift and the consequences for a failed launch can be grim. Potentially very complex wind flow at valley level.

name: Bill´s Hill
desc: Requires notifying the Buchanon State Forest prior to flying (717) 485-3148 - simply leave a message letting them know. Do not drive over the speed limit on the road to launch because there have been complaints.

name: Chalk Bluffs
desc:
small window for flying: tolittle wind and you'll sink out, too much and it's very hard to get off... many met links: http://karicastle.com/owens-valley-wx/
Check wind at Bishop Airport; if the wind there is already (too) strong, it's not worth the drive...

name: Beaver Creek Resort
desc:
Area is presently C L O S E D !!!!
Access to launch is by invitation only and requires membership in the Vail Soaring Club and supervision by a site monitor.  Access to Beaver Creek's lifts requires a ski pass, season pass or foot passenger pass.  We have just one launch site from the Brink of Golden Eagle Men's Downhill slope.  The site is a P4, P3 sponsored and requires current membership to USHPA and proper equipment; including reserve parachute and radio.

name: Mussel Rock aka The Dumps

name: 6K - Haleakala Ranch (Closed)

name: Glassy Mountain

name: Weaver Bally
desc: Unimproved launches on both sides of the ridge near the fire lookout. Generally east or west winds are best for launch, although the site may be launched with more southerly winds as well. Weather conditions here are complex due the interaction of the Trinity Alps with weather systems, proximity to the ocean and interior weather systems, elevation, and convective setting. Be sure to understand the weather conditions before flying.

name: The 'G'

name: Nuthouse

name: Cedar City Training Hill
desc: The launch is on top of the ridge, you can fly it in almost any wind direction. Be careful in Strong wind, there is a small window where it is really good and blown out. If you do start to get blown back I would head out towards the valley to the west. DO NOT GO TOO FAR EAST ON A STRONG DAY

name: Dinosaur
desc:
40 22 14.26N, 109 5 22.73W
See USHPA Magazine April 2012. Afternoon over development and thunder heads can develop quickly and be extreme.  Mid day thermaling can be extremely strong. A westerly component can cause rotor along the complex rock system of the ridge, so be aware of the lee side in these situations and keep your distance. This is a high desert site!

name: Quintana Beach
desc:
Small ridge that backs directly onto the beach. Inflate your wing on the beach and walk backwards towards the small ridge / cliff. 

It may also be possible to take off on the top of the ridge with a PG, but it would be difficult due to scrub and angle of the cliff.

HG could probably take off on the top without too much trouble.

name: East Beach
desc:
This area is only suitable for flying during the months of November through February.  Outside of this timeframe, the city of Galveston charges a fee to access the beach as it is very crowded.

In the past, all ultralights were banned from this area due to problems, however we have now restored access.  Do not use the beach for flying outside of the months of November, December, January, and February.

name: Texas City Levee
desc:
Launch site is on the bay side of the levee.  Access to the LZ is via approach to the Texas City Dike where one must pay the $5 toll to get onto the Dike whereby one must then take a U-turn to get onto the levee.

One can use this as a launching site for further inland travels.  Should one follow the shoreline north beyond the floodgates, be aware landing on the other side of the floodgates could result in a 4 mile walkout as the access road is padlocked shut. Only fly when the winds are from the north to the southeast.  Winds from the south and/or southwest will result in very turbulent air due to the refinery.

name: El Jardin Park
desc: This is a very tight place for PPG flights only.  Winds from the southeast to south are the only suitable launch direction.  The area open/closes at sunrise/sunset with other times being padlocked shut.  One must fly the shoreline out over the water and be prepared and skilled to do spot (< 25') landings should you encounter an engine problem.  If you do not have the skill, then you need to seek other LZ's.

name: Houser Rd - Towing
desc:
Houser Rd is a 3.5 mile stretch that runs east to west and can be towed in either direction within the bounds of the power lines at either end. Dehydration and heat exhaustion are a real hazard during hot weather. Bring plenty of water.

â€¢Desert flying is hazardous in hot weather. Inexperienced pilots should limit flights to evenings under the guidance of a local pilot. DO NOT attempt to fly this site for the first time without a local guide!

â€¢Rain or virga in the desert produces gust fronts and microbursts. Watch for overdevelopment or lines of moving dust.

â€¢Desert vegetation has teeth and eats the wings of the unwary or careless.

The Pumphouse LZ is across the valley and surrounded by larger terrain features. It may experience rotor with significant winds and is probably best left as a low/no wind LZ.

When launching or landing at Reservation Rd., Stay well away from people! (10 meters) Re- launching is only permitted from North and South Dune re-launch zones (see site map) This site takes West South West to North West winds, 13 knots to 22 knots. Wind Talker (831) 393-4042 .. https://windy.com underestimates wind at this site consistently. Windy: W @ 9 knots = likely good day.

name: 750' (San Bernardino)
desc: The 750' launch (~2500ft MSL) is so named because it is 750ft vertically above the Andy Jackson Airpark LZ (same typical LZ as Marshall). It is a less popular alternative to the Marshall launch but has some key advantages: (1) It is readily accessible from Andy Jackson via the dirt 2N40 forest service road (~10 min, moderate clearance recommended) or a 0.6mi hike on a foottrail (~30min, steep). (2) Being lower elevation, cloud cover is less of an issue than at Marshall. (3) The quick access and quick flights in non-thermic conditions are well suited for beginners (and others) to rack up a large number of flights in a short time frame (such as four flights before noon). (4) On particularly thermic days it is possible for a launch from 750' to gain altitude up to and in excess of Marshall, defeating the need for a shuttle. Hanggliders do not seem to use this launch. The launch is a 50'x80' dirt and gravel patch sloping SSW at the south end of the large pull out. A streamer on a pole gives some indication of wind. The launch area is less forgiving than Marshall (but again suited for beginners). Non-thermic flights are about 3-4min to AJX. Site is maintained by the Crestline Soaring Society. See links below for site protocols and access. Summer conditions mid-day are usually very strong and can be dangerous. Dust devils blow through the LZ. Launch is popular in mornings when Marshall is in the clouds or there are low winds in the afternoon. Headwinds arrive here earlier than at the Marshall launch. Pilots are encouraged to launch in the first four hours after sunrise or the two hours before sunset. Sometimes sea-breeze fronts blow through, you can see them coming. And occasionally gust fronts from thunderstorms, though most thunderstorms form far enough back in the mountains as not to affect flying. wx info: http://www.crestlinesoaring.org/weather

name: Pickle Butte
desc: 3 launches dubbed West Launch, Main Launch, Kalbus Launch West launch is for west days. Main Launch is good for NW to NNE winds. Kalbus launch is NNW to NNE. Expect high pressure, dry air and valley inversions which will make for small, broken punchy thermals. Great glass offs in the evening and smooth laminar wind in the mornings.

name: Pass Creek
desc:
The Training Hill Launch is a flat area on the hillside visible from the parking area with room to set up and kite before launching. The main LZ is  300 ft. below across the road. 

Midway Launch is above and north of the Training Hill Launch, it is launchable in west to southwest winds. This launch uses the same landing zones as the Training Hill Launch  and has an area behind launch with some potential for kiting. 

 Upper Knob Launch (P3 recommended) can be reached by hiking south east, above the Midway Launch until reaching a deep ravine (here you’ll be able to see the Upper Knob Launch), then turn to hike up.  The primary launch direction here is south, but  can also be launched west to fly over the Training Hill Launch and back to the parking area. From the southern aspect, the Cemetery landing zone can be seen by imagining the area between a line directly from launch to the intersection of Morgan Lane and Rocky Mountain Road, then another line due east from this intersection. 

Northeast of Upper Knob Launch is a large clearing with a slight slope for kiting in south winds. There are some boulders and bushes scattered across this area.

name: Henson Gap - Tennessee Tree Toppers
desc:
Two Launches are owned and maintained by the Local USHPA Chapter: Tennessee Tree Toppers:
- North Ramp: HG Ramp
- Burnside Launch: Slope PG & HG Launch (New in 2019)

name: Little Ellis
desc: Rocky, slightly bushy takeoff about 1.5 hours up on the spine of little Ellis. Plenty of room for 1-2 gliders to takeoff. Not recommended to try taking off in a tail wind. Soars in SW-NW with glass-off and XC potential.

Top landings are easily to do with sufficient altitude.

name: Nirgua
desc: The take off area has close to 500sqt meters at 1165mts above sea level.   During summer we can take off to the south and during raining season we take off to the north.  Our site is surrounded by pine trees and vegetation.  Our take off is always been taken care of with green short grass which protects the wing upon take off. The wind and thermals sometimes wet strong and must be able to read the weather well,  always are local pilots around  to ask advices from.

name: Langbiang
desc:
SW: Flat ground with grass. Allow open 5 canopys at the same time.
SE: smaller place, with a big rock in font!
600m high. It take 15 minute from landing to take off. good season: November to next March
during September to Octorber, have cloud suck,
rainny on June to August

The launch site is easily accessible by motorcycles and cars by newly completed asphalt pave road [see videos and pictures we made in recent trip to Son Tra flying site].
Coordinates: 16.1179 108.2738, Alt: 573 m, Timezone: ICT (UTC+7)
